FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|Rescue us…|i>Lit: <i|hosanna|i>. Ref. note of Matt 21:9*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|boxes…|i>Lit: <i|vessels|i>. (Some liberty taken by using <i|boxes|i>.)*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|designated teachers…|i>Lit: <i|Scribes|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|Have the God-kind of faith…|i>The verb tense of this verb (and the other references) insinuate continuous action. This is not a one-time h*
                                     *aving, believing, or doubting, but a continuation of it unbounded by time.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|ask for in prayer…|i>Lit: <i|pray and ask|i>. The wording here is a figure of speech called a <i|hendiadys|i>; ref. note of Matt. 3:11.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|the chief priests, the designated teachers, and the councilmen|i>…Lit: <i|the chief priests, the Scribes, and the Elders|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|You answer my question, and I’ll answer yours|i>…Lit: <i|I’ll ask you one question, you’ll answer me, and I’ll tell you by what authority *
                                     *I do these things|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|was his authority to baptize derived from heaven|i>…Lit: <i|was it from heaven|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|Since figs weren’t in season…|i>Jesus found no figs on the fig tree when it wasn’t fig season and as a result cursed the tree. Why did Jes*
                                     *us expect to find figs on a tree when it wasn’t fig season? There are two times a year in which a fig tree bears figs. The main crop is in the late su*
                                     *mmer or fall and a secondary crop (called a <i|breba|i>) is in the spring. The breba crop comes from shoots from the previous fall’s crop. Also, over *
                                     *the winter a fig tree will shed leaves. New leaves grow back in the spring, and this is what the phrase <i|in leaf|i> refers to in v. 13. Also, the ap*
                                     *pearance of these new leaves coincides with the breba crop; hence, Jesus saw the new leaves and expected to see figs. When Mark said in v.13 that “fig*
                                     *s weren’t in season,” he’s referring to the fall crop, not the breba crop.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|those who were seated selling doves…|i>Ref. note of Matt. 12:21*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|robber’s hideout…|i>The Gk. word used here and in Matt. 21:13 is for <i|robber |i>and not the one for <i|thief. |i>A robber (not a thief) *
                                     *is described in Prov. 1:8–19. He is one who lies in wait for his victim and will apply violence wantonly for even paltry gain. In modern times, you fi*
                                     *nd thugs such as these in gangs or with drug traffickers.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|Have the God-kind of faith…|i>Lit:<i| Be-having faith of-God|i>. A couple of relevant facts concerning the Gk. grammar in this short state*
                                     *ment. First, the verb tense (present) of <i|have |i>insinuates not just having once and being done with it but having continuously. Second, the lack o*
                                     *f the definite article before <i|faith |i>is conspicuous and was omitted intentionally by Mark. As a point of contrast, consider the example of Acts 3*
                                     *:16, where the definite article is used before <i|faith|i> (and this in a prepositional phrase, which often omits an expected definite article). In th*
                                     *e case of v. 22 here, the omission of the definite article emphasizes the nature of the faith. Furthermore, the word <i|God |i>is in the genitive case*
                                     *, but when a possessive is constructed in Gk. (an example in English would be, “This is Mary’s jar,” where <i|Mary |i>appears in the possessive form),*
                                     * it normally consists of the definite article first, followed by the noun, followed by perhaps another article, then the genitive form of the noun doi*
                                     *ng the possessing. Since the initial definite article is missing, this disrupts the normal pattern of a Gk. possessive form, and signals a different m*
                                     *eaning to the reader. Third, the lack of definite article before <i|faith |i>emphasizes the nature of the faith.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|Have the God-kind of faith…believe that you have received…|i>Some of the ancient manuscripts have doctored a few key words in vv.23,24. Th*
                                     *is is related to previous note. A minor change is in v. 23: some manuscripts have inserted the word <i|to|i>, changing it from: <i|have God’s faith, |*
                                     *i>to, <i|if you have God’s faith|i>. A larger change is in v. 24: some manuscripts have changed the reading, <i|believe that you have received, |i>to,*
                                     * <i|believe that you are receiving.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|believe that you have received|i>…To quote Max & Mary from <i|A Grammatical Analysis of the Greek New Testament|i> with respect to the ver*
                                     *b tense in the words <i|have received|i>: “the future regarded with such certitude that it is assumed to have been realized already, but in the presen*
                                     *t is not regarded as having been complete yet.”*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s>Verse 26’s ending, which reads, <i|but if you don’t forgive, neither will your heavenly Father forgive your trespasses|i>, is omitted as spur*
                                     *ious. Ref. note of Matt. 17:21.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|teacher…|i>Mark uses the Gk. word for <i|teacher |i>here and not the Aramaic <i|Rabbi |i>used several verses earlier (ref. Mark 9:5; 11:21*
                                     *). The shift in Mark’s choice of the word for <i|teacher|i> here shows a subtle lack of affection and respect seeping out of the mouths of the Pharise*
                                     *es and Herodians (and later in v.19, the Sadducees), while they are trying to flatter Jesus. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|God’s not a God of the dead but of the living|i>…The point Jesus is making is that in the story of the burning bush, when God speaks to Mo*
                                     *ses, he refers to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, who had died many years earlier, in the present tense, not in the past tense. If there was no life-after-*
                                     *death, he would have referred to them in the past tense; his referring to them in the present tense is proof that they still exist even though they’re*
                                     * dead.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|exceeds all burnt offerings and sacrifices|i>…The Law of Moses in the Old Testament commands Jews to offer to God burnt offerings and sacr*
                                     *ifices. Both the commandments quoted in this passage and burnt offerings and sacrifices are required by the self-same Law of Moses.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|occupy the most prestigious seats|i>…Lit: <i|first-seated|i> <i|in the synagogues. |i>In the Israel of the Bible, seating at any event, ev*
                                     *en ones not steeped in formality, was done by the relative ranking of those seated; the greater status of the guest, the closer to the front or closer*
                                     * to the host or most prominent attendee was he placed. This explains Luke 14:8.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|gobble up widows’ homes…|i>Widows were the lowest ranked and most vulnerable in the socio-economic hierarchy of ancient Israel. There are *
                                     *numerous admonitions in the Old Testament to care for widows, to not take advantage of them, to look out for their well-being.*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|the|i> <i|sign…|i>Also: <i|the portent|i>; <i|the omen|i>; <i|the supernatural wonder|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|conclusion…|i>Or: <i|consummation|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|claiming to have my authority|i>…Lit: <i|in my name|i>. Ref. notes of Matt. 24:4, Luke 21:8.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|it’s not over yet…|i>Lit: <i|It’s not the end yet|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|they’ll work you over…|i>Lit: <i|beat you; flog you|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|the Good News…|i>Also: <i|the Gospel|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|on account of you doing what I told you to do…|i>Ref. note of Matt. 24:8*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|abomination that causes things to fall into desolation|i>…Lit: <i|abomination of desolation|i>. Ref. usage of <i|desolate|i> in Luke 11:17*
                                     *.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|Oh, how terrible…|i>Ref. note of Matt. 24:19*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|Hope to God…|i>Ref. note of Matt. 24:20*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|not a single living being|i>…Lit: <i|no flesh|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|on account of the Chosen Ones…|i>Lit: <i|on account of the Chosen Ones who have been chosen|i>. The repetition in the phrase <i|Chosen One*
                                     *s who have been chosen |i>is a figure of speech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|the Man…|i>Lit: <i|the Son of Man|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|from one side of the planet to the other…|i>Ref. note of Matt. 24:31*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|period in the history of mankind|i> …Lit: <i|generation|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|timeframe…|i>Lit: <i|when the season will be|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|his various estate shops…|i>Lit: <i|each of his works|i>. These are his business ventures…warehouses, glass-making, tanneries, potteries, *
                                     *wineries…perhaps herds, fields, silos.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[r]|s><i|applies to you as well…|i>Lit: <i|what I’m telling you all, I’m saying to everyone|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|I am the one-and-only one…|i>Lit: <i|I am|i>. Same words Jesus spoke in John 8:58, which in turn is a repetition of Exod. 3:14. Saying “I *
                                     *am” implies saying “I am the eternal God incarnate.”*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|The local council|i>…In this context, though it could refer to the national council (which was like a Supreme Court), the Sanhedrin, which*
                                     * in Matthew is called the <i|Council of the Elders|i>, but more likely refers to a local tribunal of elders.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|have the one who reads this out loud to the congregation get up to speed on this ahead of time|i>…Ref. note of Matt. 24:15*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|Don’t have whoever’s on the porch go down, go in, and fetch anything out of the house…|i>Ref. note of Matt. 24:17*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|Oh, how terrible it’ll be for women at that time who are pregnant or have infants!|i>…Ref. note of Matt. 24:19*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|keep watch…stay alert…stay focused…|i>Lit: <i|keep watch|i>. The GT uses the same word for <i|keep watch |i>at the end of v.34 (<i|keep wa*
                                     *tch|i>), at the beginning of v. 35 (<i|stay alert|i>), and at the end of v. 37 (<i|stay focused|i>). *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|whether at daybreak…|i>The times listed in v.35 (sunset, middle of the night, just before daybreak, daybreak) are all times when it is dar*
                                     *k or nearly dark and are listed in the order of the Jewish day. In other words, since the Jewish day starts at sunset, the hours of darkness or near d*
                                     *arkness progress from sunset to the middle of the night, just before daybreak, and finally to daybreak. Also, in the GT, Mark inserts the word <i|whet*
                                     *her |i>before each time…<i|whether at sunset, whether in the middle of the night, whether just before daybreak, whether daybreak|i>. His point is to c*
                                     *over the entire night, from beginning to end, starting when it begins to get dark and ending when it’s still a bit dark in the morning.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[H]|s><i|But the point that I’m making in this story applies to you all as well|i>…In this parable, the servants are all assigned responsibilities,*
                                     * and their responsibilities by default include keeping watch during the day, as they’ll be up and about minding shop during daylight hours, but do not*
                                     * included keeping watch at night. The job of keeping the night watch is assigned solely to the doorman. If the estate owner were to come in the middle*
                                     * of the night and catch everyone asleep, it will be the doorman’s fault and not the servants’, since the servants are expected to sleep at night. The *
                                     *doorman is the lowest ranking servant on the estate (the Gk. word for <i|doorman |i>is alternatively translated <i|porter|i> or <i|janitor|i>); the se*
                                     *rvants are assigned more important duties. The doorman’s temptation is to neglect his night watch duties, as the servants, those senior to him, will s*
                                     *leep through the night and therefore not keep tabs on him. The admonition Jesus makes is for the doorman (and us by extension) to stay alert every nig*
                                     *ht, throughout the entire night, as the estate owner could come at any time.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|cracked…|i>Lit: <i|break|i>; <i|shatter|i>; <i|crush|i>. What Mark is conveying is the tearing or breaking of an expensive seal, elaborate*
                                     * packaging, or a one-time breaking of some sort of container. Just as it is today, expensive items back then came with elaborate seals, not just simpl*
                                     *e lids. The manufacturer of an expensive item will purposely intend the breaking open of such a container to become a pleasing ritual and a means of f*
                                     *ueling the hype and anticipation of discovering its contents.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|one who raises his glass to offer a toast|i>…Lit: <i|dips in the dish with me|i>. Some liberties taken; ref. note of Matt. 26:23.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|took a loaf of bread, gave thanks, broke it|i>…Breaking of bread was a ritual; ref. note of Matt. 14:19.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|This is my blood of the covenant|i>…Some of the older manuscripts have an alternate reading, <i|this is my blood which is of the covenant|*
                                     *i>, while others read, <i|this is my blood of the new covenant|i>. The evidence for the accepted reading is sufficient to accept what’s rendered here *
                                     *as genuine. It remains for us to accept what Jesus said at face value.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|and again he found them sleeping; they didn’t know what they would say in response to him since their eyelids were sagging|i>…Lit: <i|And *
                                     *again he found them sleeping, since their eyelids were sagging, and they didn’t know how they might reply to him|i>. They were sleeping because they d*
                                     *idn’t know how to reply to Jesus?—An example of Mark’s clumsy writing.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s>(V.48) <i|said to the party|i>…(v.50) <i|everyone standing there|i>…Lit: <i|said to them|i> (v.48); <i|all of them|i> (v.50). It’s known by t*
                                     *he context what the antecedent of <i|them |i>is in both cases, but the potential for ambiguity would otherwise exist. Another example of Mark’s clumsy*
                                     * writing.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|A certain young man…|i>Some assert that the “certain young man” referred to in v.51 is none other than Mark himself. At a minimum, Mark’s *
                                     *book is worded in such a way that the reader would understand who he was talking about. Patching together NT verses here and there and also church tra*
                                     *dition, Mark was the son of Mary, who owned the upper room where the Last Supper was held. Mark wasn’t one of Jesus’s disciples, either because he was*
                                     * too young to be so, didn’t know him until the Passover week, or both; but he followed Jesus and the Twelve Disciples after they left the upper room t*
                                     *o Gethsemane.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[H]|s><i|but he shed the garment they grabbed and ran away naked…|i>From the sounds of it, when those in the party tried to grab ahold of the young*
                                     * man, they could just barely get ahold of him. They weren’t able to arms, legs, neck, or grab him around his waist; all they could do is get a hand on*
                                     * his linen garment. He squirmed, the loin cloth came off, and he continued to bolt. This probably would’ve taken place in just a few seconds.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[I]|s><i|a rooster crowed |i>(v.68)…<i|a rooster crowed|i> <i|a second time|i> (v.72)…These words are missing from a few of the most reliable manus*
                                     *cripts. It’s possible that others added what Mark in his clumsiness neglected. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[J]|s><i|it hit him like a ton of bricks…|i>Lit: <i|Having thrown upon, he started crying|i>. The single Gk. word <i|epiballō |i>(ἐπιβάλλω /Strong’*
                                     *s 1911). Apparently an idiom of some sort; it’s not entirely certain what the exact meaning of this is when used as an idiom. Some translators render *
                                     *it, <i|He broke down and cried|i>.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|the high priests, along with all the councilmen and the designated teachers|i>…Lit: <i|the high priests with the elders, the scribes, and *
                                     *the entire Sanhedrin|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|Whatever you say…|i>Lit:<i| You say|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|the governor’s security guards…|i>Lit: <i|the praetorian|i>. Similar to the Roman Praetorian Guard but applied to the governor’s (Pilate’s*
                                     *) palace.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|placed on him…|i>Lit: <i|placed around him|i>. The use of the word <i|around |i>instead of <i|on, |i>and the fact that the word for <i|cro*
                                     *wn |i>here is something similar to a Roman laurel wreath indicates that the crown indeed was just like we see in the pictures and movies about Jesus.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|Pleased to meet you, King of the Jews…|i>Lit: <i|Joy, King of the Jews|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|they led him away to be crucified…|i>Lit: <i|they led him out in order that they might crucify him|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|to carry…|i>Lit: <i|to take up|i>. The Gk. word rendered <i|carry|i> in v.21 is the same word used in Matt. 16:24 (<i|to take up|i>).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|up on top of…|i>Or: <i|to the exact location of|i>; <i|to|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|rolling dice…|i>Some liberty taken; they cast lots instead of rolling dice.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|Now it was mid-morning when they performed the crucifixion on him|i>…Lit: <i|Now it was the third hour and they crucified him|i>. The two *
                                     *thoughts (#1: <i|it was the third hour|i>; #2: <i|they crucified him|i>) separated by the word <i|and |i>rather than combining them is a figure of spe*
                                     *ech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|one to the left of him and one to the right of him|i>…Also: <i|one at his left hand and one at his right hand|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s>Verse 28 which reads, <i|And the Scripture which says, “And he was counted with lawless men,”|i> is spurious and therefore omitted.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|designated teachers…|i>Lit: <i|the Scribes|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|let out a great cry and passed away|i>…Lit: <i|he exhaled|i>, or, <i|his spirit went out of him|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|temple curtain…|i>Ref. note of Matt. 27:52*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|a son…|i>The rendering <i|a son|i> should not insinuate that the Son of God is one of many sons of God. The GT does not say that.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|among whom were…|i>The GT includes a leading <i|and|i> to the list of women, and this <i|and, |i>though omitted in the rendering, seems to*
                                     * imply that all the women who were watching from a distance are listed in vv.40,41; that there were no other women present.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[r]|s><i|who also was himself a true believer…|i>Lit: <i|who also was personally receiving to himself the kingdom of God|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[s]|s><i|if it had been a while since he died|i>…some of the older manuscripts instead read, <i|if he had died|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|along with the revolutionaries…during the insurrection…|i>As v.8 is worded in the GT, <i|the revolutionaries|i> and <i|the insurrection|i>*
                                     * refer to a specific group of insurgents and a specific rebellion, lost to history perhaps, but known to Mark’s readers.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|a robe a nobleman would wear|i>…The Gk. word <i|prophyra |i>(πορφύρα/Strong’s 4209)<i|. |i>It means two things: it means <i|purple|i> and *
                                     *it also refers to the Murex snail from which purple dye is extracted. In modern times, dyes are synthesized at a low cost from chemical compounds, and*
                                     * so there is an abundance of cheap, multi-colored clothing. In ancient times only by harvesting Murex snails from the ocean could one produce a purple*
                                     * dye, so the clothing made from this dye was expensive. Since only the wealthy nobles could afford it, purple coloring was associated with nobility.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|spiced wine…|i>Lit: <i|myrrh-mixed wine|i>. Also ref. Matt. 27:34, Ps. 69:21. Roman soldiers normally drank a wine which was at least part*
                                     *ly vinegar; the sour taste helped quench one’s thirst, something like putting a slice of lemon in a glass of iced tea. Obviously, however, too much vi*
                                     *negar would make the drink unpalatable, and apparently they mixed myrrh to limit the extent to which the wine degraded into vinegar, as it would natur*
                                     *ally do so when exposed to the air. But the myrrh was also slightly narcotic, and Jesus apparently refuses it so that the wine won’t ameliorate his su*
                                     *ffering.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|mid-morning…noon…late afternoon…Mid-morning|i> in the GT is the third hour. The Jewish regular hours of prayer and of sacrifices institute*
                                     *d the third, sixth, and ninth hours of the day. Out of this, the third, sixth, and ninth hours became the way of specifying approximate points during *
                                     *the day (ref. Matt. 20:1–17), and they correspond to what we call mid-morning, noon, middle of the afternoon, and late afternoon. In spite of the fact*
                                     * that they are numerical values in a twelve hour day, they are not as exact as their nominal values suggest.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|a|i> <i|pre-Sabbath preparatory day|i>…The Sabbath here could be either a Saturday or a feast day. Naturally, one would want to remove dea*
                                     *d bodies immediately; furthermore, dead bodies should not remain on the Sabbath. Work was forbidden on the Sabbath, not to mention the aversion and re*
                                     *strictions the Jews had concerning dead bodies.*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|just after the Sabbath restrictions came to a close|i>…The Jewish day ended at sundown, so the Sabbath ended at sundown. Once the Sabbath *
                                     *was over, the women could conduct business.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|Very early on Sunday morning…|i>Lit: <i|very early in the first of the Sabbaths |i>(v.2). Ref. Matt. 28:1 for “Sabbaths” use in plural. Th*
                                     *e “first of the Sabbaths” is a Sunday; also ref. John 2:1; Acts 20:7 Related to this, v.9 reads lit.: <i|now having been resurrected early on the firs*
                                     *t of the Sabbath|i>…*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|refusal to believe|i>…<i|refused to believe|i>…Lit: <i|unbelief|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|the inhabited world…|i>Lit: <i|the world. |i>Refers to the people who live on the earth, rather than the earth per se.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|preach a complete round|i>…This is the word <i|preach |i>in the aorist tense, not the expected present tense. The use of aorist over prese*
                                     *nt tense views the proclamation of the gospel as a one-time event, rather than a never-ending series of proclamations. The one-time preaching of the g*
                                     *ospel views takes all the individual proclamations and views them as a single set. In other words, make sure everyone gets to hear it at least once.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|the Good News…|i>Lit: <i|the Gospel|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|anything that has two legs|i>…Lit: <i|all of creation|i>. This is a figure of speech, as Jesus isn’t commanding the disciples to preach to*
                                     * dogs or mountains or such.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|kept from destruction…|i>Lit: <i|saved|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|accompany…|i>Lit: <i|follow alongside|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|by my authority…|i>Lit: <i|in my name. |i>Ref. note of Acts 4:7.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|they will remove serpents, taking them out of the way|i>…Also: <i|they will lift up serpents|i>. Some manuscripts read, <i|they will lift *
                                     *up serpents with their hands|i>, appending the words <i|with their hands.|i> The word used for <i|lift up|i> here is translated various ways depending*
                                     * on context.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|assumed his position as God’s chief executive|i>…Lit: <i|sat at the right hand of God|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|tell his disciples and Peter|i>…If there’s any doubt that Mark was close to Peter, remarks such as these should lay that doubt to rest. In*
                                     * multiple places Mark points Peter out, mentioning what he’s doing. Furthermore, he often uses the name <i|Peter|i>, the one given to him by Jesus,<i|*
                                     * |i>instead of ones that others called him, <i|Simon|i> or <i|Cephas|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s>Those who deny that vv. 9–20 are genuine build their argument not on the manuscript evidence (which is certainly not in their favor) but inst*
                                     *ead on “internal” evidence, i.e. whether they think these verses fit Mark’s style of writing and his use of vocabulary. Their claims:*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *(a) <i|Mary Magdalene, whom he had cast out seven demons|i> (v.9). They claim that the writer is introducing Mary Magdalene here, noting the demons ca*
                                     *st out of her, but in fact she had been referred to just a few times in the preceding verses and chapters.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *(b) Some words occur in this passage that Mark doesn’t use anywhere else*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *(c) The writing is simply not Mark’s style*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *Let us look at these claims in detail.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *First, Mark mentions that Mary Magdalene had had seven demons cast out of her. Any forger would know that Mary Magdalene was brought up in v.1 and wou*
                                     *ld’ve written accordingly. But the extra statement of her having demons cast out is not an introduction but a reminder of the grace she had received, *
                                     *resulting in a tender heart which caused her to be the first to believe when the others wouldn’t. To emphasize this, Mark, when he said <i|had cast ou*
                                     *t|i>, chose to use the Gk. perfect tense over the aorist for emphasis. In support of this, v.10 begins with the words <i|that lady|i>, which invites t*
                                     *he reader to detach himself and ponder her history. The other women weren’t address in that fashion.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *Second, there are a few words which Mark uses in this passage that don’t appear elsewhere in his book (never mind the fact that every chapter of Mark *
                                     *has unique words used in its chapter which Mark uses nowhere else). Let us look at these words:*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *(i) <i|Accompany|i> (v.17). This is a more specific word that pre-pends the word <i|with |i>to <i|follow. |i>Certainly Mark knew the meaning of this w*
                                     *ord.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *(ii) <i|Serpent|i> (v.18). A common word.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *(iii) <i|Hurt|i> (v.18). Ranks 2808<s|th|s> out of 5394, where 1 is most common and 5394 is least. This word is uncommon.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *(iv) <i|Poison|i> (v.18). Derived from a very common root.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *(v) The phrase <i|so then|i> (v. 19). Two extremely common words used as a phrase. Mark certainly knew the meaning of the phrase, but didn’t use it an*
                                     *ywhere else.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *(vi) <i|Working alongside|i> (v.20). This is the verb form of the commonly-used noun <i|fellow-worker.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *(vii) <i|Confirm|i> (v.20). Appears as 2803<s|rd|s> out of 5394. This word is uncommon and is not derived from a commonly used root.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *We can strike serpent, hurt, and poison from the list, since there are no alternatives for these words; Mark would’ve asked the scribe who was doing t*
                                     *he actual writing to supply these words had he not known them and when he had need of them. This leaves four words, three of which are common, and Mar*
                                     *k certainly knew, but he hadn’t used before. The list of uncommon words is whittled down to the single word <i|confirm.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *As far as the style is concerned—and this is quite open-ended—true, Mark shifts his preference in verb tenses around, but this passage has little stor*
                                     *y-telling narrative. Another thing to note are the figures of speech used in vv.15,16. Would a forgerer risk using a figure or speech? Would a forgere*
                                     *r dwell on the disciples not believing when they should have (vv.13,14). While all these things with style are debatable, they are not definitive in d*
                                     *etermining whether the long ending of vv.9–20 is spurious or not.*

HEADING1                             *The Gospel of Luke*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Luke, the beloved physician (Col . 4:14), the faithful companion of Paul, is the author of one of the four officially-sponsored Gospels. We assume tha*
                                     *t Paul authorized Luke to write it, and since it was associated with Paul, it’s target audience was the gentile church, more specifically the Christia*
                                     *ns planted by Paul’s ministry. Evidence points to Luke being a slave or a freedman, serving or having served one Theophilus, for whose benefit he writ*
                                     *es not only the Gospel of Luke but its sequel, the Book of Acts.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *The facts Luke recorded in his Gospel were obtained from him conducting first-hand interviews (he says this in 1:2) with many eyewitnesses to the mini*
                                     *stry of Jesus. To do this, Luke would have had to have spent a few months in Israel, and would have spoken directly with Mary the mother of Jesus and *
                                     *recorded her very words in order to obtain such precise details of Jesus’s birth. The likely time of his doing these interviews would have been around*
                                     * AD 55, when Paul was in Israel during his third missionary journey. Had it been any later than this, these eyewitnesses would have been deceased alre*
                                     *ady, not to speak of the sack of Jerusalem in AD 70.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Luke was thorough and meticulous. He was likely a native Greek speaker; his command of Greek surpasses Matthew’s, Mark’s, and John’s by a large measur*
                                     *e, and is only rivaled by Paul’s and by those who wrote the epistles of Jude and Hebrews. Luke has full command of the nuanced richness of the Greek l*
                                     *anguage, and he can capture in a word or a word inflection something which takes an entire phrase to render in English.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Though Luke has the education and intelligence to write complex, sophisticated passages—which he does in Luke 1:1–4—he refrains from doing so and writ*
                                     *es in a down-to-earth manner throughout his book. From time to time, he dresses up a sentence or two, using colorful wording where more straightforwar*
                                     *d wording would suffice. An example is Luke 7:1; another example is Luke 8:15 “beautiful and morally good;” another example is the simile of Luke 22:4*
                                     *4, where Luke compares Jesus sweat to drops of blood. But throughout the book, he is mindful of detail and correctness, as what he writes must reflect*
                                     * what the eyewitnesses told him in face-to-face interviews. In the example of the Pharisee and the tax collector praying at the temple (Luke 18:11,13)*
                                     *, Luke says that both stood, but uses a different form of the same verb <i|to stand, |i>subtlety conveying the difference in their standing postures. *
                                     *Moreover in 18:13, Luke’s prose garnishes the story beautifully (literal rendering): “But the tax collector standing at a distance was not wanting nei*
                                     *ther to lift up the eyes to heaven.” Luke is sparing in his use of special forms and expressions, but by being sparing when he does use special forms,*
                                     * his usage is more effective. For example, in Luke 17:37, Luke uses the present tense to mean the past tense—he does not do that often, like in the ot*
                                     *her Gospels.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Of the four Gospels, Luke captures the most sober and chilling warnings of the judgment to come: do the right thing or pay for it later, even if the p*
                                     *ayment might be deferred to the life to come. Some examples of this are as follows. Luke 12:20: “Fool—the Grim Reaper is coming for you this very nigh*
                                     *t. Now everything you saved away: who’s it going to go to?” Luke 13:8,9: “The gardener considered things and replied, ‘Boss, leave it be this year as *
                                     *well; meanwhile, I’ll dig around it and put down fertilizer, and we’ll see if it produces figs in the coming year. But if it doesn’t, you can cut it d*
                                     *own.” Luke 13:27,28: “Get away from me, the lot of you, practitioners of wrong-doing.’ There will be the weeping and the gnashing of teeth, at that ti*
                                     *me when Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and all the prophets connected with God’s involvement with mankind (God’s kingdom) will be seen. Those people, though, *
                                     *get the boot.” Luke 14:24: “I’ll tell you this much: not a single one of those people who were invited will taste even a morsel of my dinner.” The ric*
                                     *h man and Lazarus (Luke 16). Luke 19:27: “However, my enemies, those who didn’t want me to rule over them as their king, bring them here and slay them*
                                     * right in front of me.”*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|many have attempted|i>…In these first few verses, Luke alludes to the fact that many have attempted to create a written record of the life*
                                     * of Jesus but did a mediocre job of it. He’s not referring to the Gnostic Gospels or some other heretical works, but to a few Christians who made earl*
                                     *y attempts to create what we now know as the Gospels but whose workmanship was a failure. Luke says here that he’ll correctly the problem and write hi*
                                     *s account accurately. Luke, the man of learning that he was, was versed in the correct method of writing history, the theory of which had been formula*
                                     *ted by the first century. This passage gives us valuable insight into the formation of the four Gospels. None of the four were haphazardly written, al*
                                     *l four gained the approval of the church leadership, and the “many” that Luke refers to in v.1 were rejected because they didn’t live up the standards*
                                     * set by the four that have been handed down through the ages. The four gospels were sponsored, by the church, approved by the church, and propagated b*
                                     *y the church.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *To achieve the self-set goals Luke stated in vv3,4, in addition to fulfilling the requirements for writing proper history, Luke had to have conducted *
                                     *direct, meticulous interviews with the eyewitnesses of what he wrote about. From the content in the first few chapters of his Gospel, he certainly wou*
                                     *ld’ve had to interview Mary mother or Jesus, or perhaps (and this is a stretch) one of Jesus’s siblings, at a minimum, the shepherds who were there at*
                                     * his birth, etc. Conducting these interviews and documenting them would’ve taken a few months, would’ve had to have taken place in Israel, and would’v*
                                     *e had to have taken place in the lifetime of all the witnesses. The timeframe which fits these criteria is Paul’s second and third missionary journeys*
                                     *, in particular his third, which was around A.D. 55. This would’ve been the latest date for the composition of Luke’s Gospel, as beyond that the eyewi*
                                     *tnesses of Jesus’s birth would’ve died of old age.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|Lord Theophilus|i>…Lit: <i|Your Excellency Theophilus|i>. Luke addresses Theophilus like he’s an aristocrat or that he had authority over *
                                     *him or both. This evidence has led scholars to conjecture that Luke was either a freedman, once a slave to Theophilus, or perhaps still a slave. But T*
                                     *heophilus had assigned him to be an assistant to Paul, donating Luke to Paul’s ministry like someone would donate a car to a charity. This might expla*
                                     *in why Luke was the only person still with Paul at the time of his death (2 Tim. 4:11)—he had no choice but to stick with him. In any event, slaves in*
                                     * ancient Rome were often educated, and Luke certainly was. In addition, the name Theophilus means God-friend. We’ll assume that his name’s not a coinc*
                                     *idence, that he wasn’t born with the name but changed it or acquired it when he became a Christian. In any event, both his name and the interest he ha*
                                     *s in the events surrounding Jesus’s life indicate that he devoted his life to his faith.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *It might seem remarkable to us, living in modern times, that a slave or former slave such as Luke could write a great work of theology, humanity, and *
                                     *literature, but Epictetus, the Greek stoic philosopher, was born a slave. Two great books were written by his student-followers: <i|Discourses|i> and *
                                     *<i|Enchiridion|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|who was of the priestly caste|i>…Lit: <i|of the daughters of Aaron|i>. The priesthood was a hereditary caste consisting of males who desce*
                                     *nded from Aaron, brother of Moses, of the tribe of Levi. The priests were not required to marry women from within that caste. Luke goes out of his way*
                                     * to mention the fact that Elizabeth was in the Aaronic lineage even before giving her name. This emphasizes the purity of John the Baptist’s parents’ *
                                     *pedigree, the level of sanctity, consecration, and cleanness, the Old Testament prerequisites for holiness. These John inherited as a result. The extr*
                                     *eme degree to which the couple were sanctified to God would only magnify the intensity of the view that God was punishing Zechariah and Elisabeth by n*
                                     *ot providing them with a son (v. 7), one who would propagate the priesthood on their behalf. As there was no sin that Zechariah and Elisabeth were cul*
                                     *pable of, whereby they would’ve received God’s disfavor and reproach, it must’ve been a mystery to the people why God would not give them a son.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|the holy presence of God |i>(v. 8)…<i|having entered the temple sanctuary itself |i>(v. 9)<i|…|i>This the first chamber inside the temple *
                                     *edifice, accessible only to priest. In OT times, God’s presence dwelled in the Holy of Holies, the hidden chamber behind the temple sanctuary. To a le*
                                     *sser extent, God’s presence was also in the sanctuary. The duties of the priests included entering the temple sanctuary on a regular basis to replenis*
                                     *h the incense, which must burn at all times, and to switch out the showbread.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|The Lord will use him as a herald in a spirit and power the likeness of which Elijah|i> <i|had|i>…Lit: <i|he himself will go before him |i*
                                     *>[<i|be a forerunner|i>]<i| before Him in a spirit and might of Elijah|i>. Coming back to a city after victory on the battlefield, conquering commande*
                                     *rs sent out forerunners to the towns they’d pass through to announce their imminent arrival, to stir up the people to gather in a large, enthusiastic *
                                     *crowd when the commander passed through. Also, see note of 1 Cor. 16:6 for <i|go forth |i>and apply that to <i|forerunner |i>here.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|shame in the eyes of others|i>…As the ancients didn’t have a scientific understanding of medicine, they generally assumed that it a couple*
                                     * couldn’t have a child, somehow it was because of the woman. In Elizabeth’s case, they assumed God despised her, perhaps even that she had sinned. Her*
                                     * experience was much like Job’s.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s>In this passage of vv. 47-55, Mary breaks into a poetic discourse, which is comprised of these literary elements:*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *v. 47: The two clauses in this verse constitute a figure of speech, one which consists of the repetition of two clauses, both of which in essence expr*
                                     *ess the same thought.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *v. 49: Tacking on <i|And holy is His name |i>(Lit: <i|And holy his name|i>) as a clause instead of as a clause offset by a relative pronoun, i.e. inst*
                                     *ead of saying <i|the Capable One whose name is holy.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *v. 49: The omission of the word <i|is |i>before <i|holy |i>gives this more of a poetic ring.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *v. 50: Like in v. 49, the omission of <i|is |i>or <i|is directed|i> is poetic.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *v. 51: <i|He routed…|i>Lit: <i|he scattered. |i>This is a metaphor, a comparison to an army sounding defeating another army, in the same way that <i|s*
                                     *catter |i>is used in Psalm 68:1, causing the enemy to break ranks and run in a disorderly retreat.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *v. 51: <i|The One Exuding power intervened in the affairs of man and did this…|i>Lit: <i|The one exuding might did this with his arm|i>. The “arm of t*
                                     *he Lord” or a variation of this (like in v. 51) is a Heb. idiom used throughout the Old Testament. It refers to God’s ability to intervene in the affa*
                                     *irs of mankind, and the strength and finality by which he does so.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *v. 51: Breaking a single thought into two clauses is a figure of speech. In other words, saying, <i|The one exuding might intervened in the affairs of*
                                     * man and did this|i>: <i|He routed those|i>…instead of saying, <i|The one exuding might intervened in the affairs of man and routed those|i>…*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *v. 51: <i|high-and-mighty where the intention of their heart is concerned|i>…Lit: <i|high-and-mighty in intention, their hearts|i>. Making <i|their he*
                                     *arts |i>an appositive of <i|high-and-mighty |i>and tweaking the literal meaning is a figure of speech.*

                                     *soldiers—in front of oneself, in order to move forward. This is the means by which Jesus grew in wisdom, stature, and the favor of God and of man; the*
                                     * implication is that life was not handed to him on a silver platter.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|the upstairs floor of the house they were at…|i>Or:<i| the inn|i>…Lit: <i|unharnessing|i>. The word refers to the unharnessing of horses, *
                                     *hence the derivation of the meaning <i|inn. |i>There is some uncertainty as to what the true meaning of this word is as used by Luke; the word means <*
                                     *i|inn |i>but it also means <i|upper room, dining hall, spare room, guest room. |i>The word is used elsewhere in the NT (Mark 14:14; Luke 22:11) to ref*
                                     *er to the upper room, where the Last Supper was held, which is assumed to be the same upper room as was occupied on the day of Pentecost. Some claim t*
                                     *hat this is an upper room of a house. Houses in those days were split-level, and often the downstairs was used to house the animals. The upper room wa*
                                     *s the main domicile. This could mean that Mary and Joseph were staying at the lower level of a friend or a distant relative’s house, and “there wasn’t*
                                     * any room for them in the inn” simply means that the upstairs was already filled. This is more plausible than <i|inn|i>.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|the word of the Lord (i.e. prophetic message) came|i>…This introductory phrase appears throughout the OT, appearing as the lead-in to a pr*
                                     *ophecy.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|all the rough roads will be resurfaced…|i>The quotation from Isaiah up to this point is a series of metaphors, the things described compar*
                                     *ed to people. The valleys are those who are in despair; the hills are those who are haughty; the windy roads are those who are confused or are in erro*
                                     *r; the rough roads are those encumbered by sin.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|establish descendants for Abraham from out of these stones|i>…In the mindset of some of the religious Jews of the time, God had chosen the*
                                     * descendants of Abraham to be his people, and His election was final. Jesus is saying that that is not the case; if a people whom God has chosen persi*
                                     *st in disobeying him, God will oust them and replace them. <i|These stones|i> in this verse symbolize the random, unknown, and insignificant mass of h*
                                     *umanity throughout the world. In this light, Jesus is insinuating that God will replace the disobedient Jews with obedient Gentiles, should the Jews p*
                                     *ersist in their disobedience.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|tax collectors…|i>In the Gospels, tax collectors, since they were involved in so much fraud, are generally assumed to be sinners. The expr*
                                     *ession <i|tax collectors and sinners |i>is found in various places in the Gospels.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|wilderness|i>…Also: <i|countryside|i>. The same word is translated <i|countryside |i>in prior verses. The Judean wilderness is harsh, unin*
                                     *habitable, and rocky.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|He stood up and came forward to do a reading|i>…Lit: <i|he stood to read|i>. Unlike churches today, synagogues back then allowed ordinary *
                                     *Israelites to read from the OT and deliver a homily on what they read. Also, ref. note of Acts 19:8.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|he’s bestowed upon me a special dispensation of favor and power|i>…Lit: <i|he anointed me|i>. At various times in the OT, God conferred sp*
                                     *ecial favor and granted special abilities to select individuals for specific purposes, usually to the benefit of Israel. This favor and these abilitie*
                                     *s were conferred in a ceremony where a priest or the like would cover (<i|anoint|i>) in oil the one upon whom the favor and abilities were conferred, *
                                     *while making a pronouncement to that effect. An example of this can be found in 1 Sam. 16:12–13.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|A season of freedom-celebrations sponsored by the Lord|i>…Lit: <i|an acceptable year of the Lord|i>. A “year of the Lord” refers to the OT*
                                     * Year of Jubilee, which the Law of Moses commands that Israel hold once every fifty years. There were laws specific to a Jubilee year, and these laws *
                                     *involved things like the freeing of slaves and the cancellation of debts. In the same way, this <i|season of celebration |i>is a Jubilee-like occasion*
                                     *, as described in the previous verses, where the captives are set free, the blind regain their sight, the downtrodden are released.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|put up or shut up|i>…Lit: <i|doctor, treat yourself|i>…Some liberties taken. An idiom assumed to be a common expression of the time.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|He,though, having wriggled his way out of their clutches|i>…Lit: <i|But he himself, having gone through their midst|i>. Some indications i*
                                     *n the GT here hint that Jesus didn’t conjure up a miracle that would placate the angry mob, thus allowing him to walk away, but that’s not what happen*
                                     *ed. He had to exercise a measure of force and recalcitrance on his part to escape their clutches. The evidence in the GT is that, first, Luke uses an *
                                     *explicit personal pronoun for <i|he|i>, which has connotations apart from the face-value meaning of the word <i|he. |i>Luke is telling us something by*
                                     * choosing this pronoun; he’s telling us that Jesus himself was taking some action when leaving the mob. Second, Luke chooses the verb <i|to go through*
                                     * |i>rather than <i|to go out of|i>, the latter form being expected had no force been involved. <i|Going through|i> emphasizes the opposition he faced,*
                                     * while <i|going out of|i> would have deemphasized that opposition.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *Not only this, but the phrase used in v. 30 <i|dia mesou |i>[<i|through midst|i>, διὰ μέσου, (διὰ /Strong’s 1223),( μέσου/Strong’s 3319)] is almost id*
                                     *entical in wording to the Gk. idiom <i|ek mesou |i>[<i|out of midst, |i>ἐκ μέσου) (ἐκ /Strong’s 1537), (μέσου/Strong’s 3319)], and should be considere*
                                     *d to be another idiom of similar or same meaning. <i|Ek mesou|i> (ref. 2 Thess. 2:7, Matt. 13:49; Acts 17:33; Acts 23:10; 1 Cor. 5:2; 2 Cor. 6:17; Col*
                                     * 2:14) “is a Greek idiom for being out of the way, and always implies decisive action, either of the person’s own will or of force on the part of othe*
                                     *rs,” <i|Figures of Speech Used in the Bible|i>, E.W. Bullinger, p. 838.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|vile-and-disgusting, assigned-to-harass spirit|i>…Lit: <i|spirit demonic|i> <i|unclean|i>. In the GT, the noun <i|spirit |i>is listed firs*
                                     *t followed by the adjectives<i| demonic unclean|i>. The adjective <i|demonic |i>comes from the root verb <i|daimonao |i>(δαιμονάω/no Strong’s number)<*
                                     *i|, |i>which has the primary meaning <i|to be subject to an avenging deity. Daimonao|i> is rooted in Greek mythology, where a person lost favor with o*
                                     *ne of the gods, and that god sent a lesser god or some other supernatural creature to torment said person. Also related to <i|daimonao |i>is the Gk. v*
                                     *erb <i|daimonizomai |i>(δαιμονίζομαι/Strong’s 1139)<i|, |i>which has a primary definition <i|to have an allotted fate. |i>In the case of <i|daimonizom*
                                     *ai, |i>it’s as though a god of mythology choose to use his or her supernatural power against a mortal being, and the person, being mortal, is trapped *
                                     *in the bonds of a superior, supernatural being, and therefore locked into the fate dictated by the god. Related to the use of these two words, Paul’s *
                                     *thorn in the flesh (2 Cor. 12:6–7) is actually that: a <i|daimonion |i>(δαιμόνιον/Strong’s 1140): a spirit assigned to him. Therefore, in a biblical c*
                                     *ontext, the word <i|demonic |i>means <i|a being sent to torment or harass someone|i>. The other adjective, the word <i|unclean, |i>is used throughout *
                                     *the OT for things forbidden by the Law of Moses to be touched, handled, things which are impure, unholy, and must be altogether shunned. These three w*
                                     *ords, <i|spirit demonic unclean, |i>construct a different meaning to what was tormenting this man in the synagogue. First, <i|spirit |i>means that it *
                                     *wasn’t a natural creature but a supernatural one. Second, <i|demonic |i>means that the evil spirit is given a specific assignment to torment a person.*
                                     * Third, <i|unclean |i>means that the spirit is all-around disgusting in its evil, irredeemably so.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[H]|s><i|Simon’s (Peter’s)|i>…The GT does not say <i|Peter’s. |i>In the NT, Peter has multiple names, the name <i|Peter |i>added to clarify what mi*
                                     *ght otherwise be confusing.*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|the Old Testament|i>…Lit: <i|Moses|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|the evidence be submitted for an official confirmation of the purging of the disease|i>…Ref. note of Matt. 8:4*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|everything that was dragging them down, physically|i>…Lit: <i|weaknesses|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|instructors…|i>The <i|instructors in the Law of Moses|i> (v.17)are the same as the <i|designated teachers|i> (v. 21): the Scribes*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|the Man|i>…Lit: <i|the Son of Man|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|everyone became ecstatic|i>…Lit: <i|an ecstasy took |i>[<i|ahold of|i>]<i| everyone|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|threw a huge party|i>…Also: <i|held a large reception|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|seated around the table|i>…Lit: <i|lying down|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 14:19.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|designed teachers|i>…Lit: <i|Scribes|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|live it up|i>…Lit: <i|eat and drink. |i>An idiom.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|I haven’t come to summon those who do right to turn their life around, but rather to summon sinners to turn their life around|i>…Lit: <i|I*
                                     * haven’t come to call righteous but rather sinners to repentance|i>. Mixing up the word order, namely stating, <i|call righteous but rather sinners to*
                                     * repentance, |i>instead of, <i|call righteous to repentance but rather sinners to repentance, |i>is a figure of speech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|your clique|i>…Lit: <i|those with you|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|groom’s cronies|i>…Lit: <i|sons of the groom|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|catching men, taking them alive|i>…Lit: the single Gk. word <i|zōgreō |i>(ζωγρέω/Strong’s 2221).<i| |i>This refers to capturing prisoners *
                                     *of war in combat. In this passage, the fish were hauled in alive and not dead, and Jesus is making an analogy to this. In the same way, people who rec*
                                     *eive word of God are “captured alive” in a sense; once captured they continue to live. They are like prisoners of war in that their life changes: they*
                                     * are interned, they work in captivity, but are also cared for in captivity. Those who do the capturing must make provide for those captured; this is w*
                                     *hat Jesus is also hinting at—not only will Peter capture men, but he’ll have to have some sort of plan for them after they’re captured: a plan of disc*
                                     *ipleship.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|their designated teachers|i>…Lit: (the same). It’s unclear what exactly <i|their |i>means in this verse, but it seems to indicate that the*
                                     * Pharisees were subordinate to the Scribes, or at least held them in high esteem.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|Plus, nobody while drinking the old wants the new; you see, he says, ‘The old stuff’s better.’”|i>…A few of the principal manuscripts have*
                                     * omitted v. 39, and one might speculate that this was done because the verse is awkward and enigmatic. Verse 39 describes a person who, while in the a*
                                     *ct of drinking the older wine, claims that he prefers the older to the newer, without giving due consideration to the new. While drinking the old, his*
                                     * heightened awareness of its subtle, unique flavor causes him to lose any objectivity to the different qualities that the new will possess. His fondne*
                                     *ss for the wine at the moment produces a reaction which rejects any substitute—even to his detriment, as he may thoroughly enjoy the new wine also, we*
                                     *re he to just give it a chance.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *And it reminds me of an old company in the landscape of corporate America which has an excellent product—be it an aircraft, a soft drink, what have yo*
                                     *u—and management in their hubris (or under pressure from the stockholders) thinks they can tinker with it and either to improve it or to shave a few p*
                                     *ennies off its cost. But the old product is better. Or, don’t you miss the way they built such-and-such a few decades ago?—You have to pay top dollar *
                                     *on the used market to get one, because they’re not made anymore.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *These analogies are relevant to this passage. There were movements of God going on at the time, one of austerity (John the Baptist) and one of celebra*
                                     *tion (Jesus). Both are very different from one another. When one is caught up in the one, he becomes so enthralled with it that he will not see the va*
                                     *lue in the other. Jesus says that both are necessary and that there’s a time and place for both. Another application is that the old-timers had a more*
                                     * powerful presence of the Holy Spirit in their services than we do today.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|holy bread|i>…This is what we call the <i|show bread. |i>Ref. note of Mark 2:26*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|the Man|i>…Lit: <i|the Son of Man|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|There was a man there whose right hand was all shriveled up|i>…Lit: <i|A man was there, and his right hand was shriveled up|i>. The litera*
                                     *l wording of the GT is a figure of speech. The figure of speech is breaking the two connected thoughts into two loosely connected clauses separated by*
                                     * the conjunction <i|and.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|designed teachers|i>…Lit: <i|Scribes|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|stand front and center|i>…Lit: <i|stand in our midst|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s>”<i|missionaries|i>”…Lit: <i|apostles. |i>Translated means <i|sent ones.|i> J.B. Phillip’s translation translates apostle as <i|special messe*
                                     *nger.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|vile, disgusting|i>…Lit: <i|unclean|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|directed his attention to|i>…Lit: <i|lifted up his eyes to|i>. Lift up the eyes or is an expression used throughout the Bible. It means to*
                                     * stop focusing narrowly on one thing or one task and look at things more broadly, whether to look at matters in a broader perspective, or (in this cas*
                                     *e) consider all the people and not just a few.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|chastise you in a shameful, disgracing manner|i>…Also: <i|reproach you|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|kick your reputation—and, for that matter, everything you stand for—to the curb as though you’re a bad person|i>…Lit: <i|throw out your na*
                                     *me as an evil person|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|you’re in for it|i>…Lit: <i|woe|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|evil impersonators of prophets|i>…Lit: <i|false prophets|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|follow in the footsteps of the Highest|i>…Lit: <i|be sons of the Highest|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|put|i>…<i|into your pocket|i>…Lit: <i|give|i>…<i|to your bosom|i>. <i|Bosom|i> in this context refers to the fold of clothing near your bo*
                                     *dy where cash and other items are carried. “Giving to your bosom” is a figure of speech called a <i|metonymy|i>; the items will actually be given to y*
                                     *ou, not given to your bosom.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|buddy’s|i>…Lit: <i|brother’s|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|storage|i>…Or: <i|treasure|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|one’s|i>…Or: his*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[r]|s><i|’Boss, Boss!|i>’…Or, ‘<i|Lord, Lord!|i>’…Also: ‘<i|Master, Master!|i>’. Using the word <i|Boss|i> over <i|Master|i> or <i|Lord|i>, because*
                                     * Jesus is talking about a servant or slave replying to his employer or master.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|the one who became a traitor…|i>The twelve apostles are listed here in order of their importance, from greatest to least, with a couple of*
                                     * exceptions. Andrew is listed after Peter because he’s his brother; James is listed before John because he’s his older brother, but John was actually *
                                     *the more important of the two. Judas Iscariot takes last place in the list. Bartholomew is the same as Nathanael . <i|Simon the insurrectionist|i> in *
                                     *the GT reads <i|Simon the Zealot|i>, as the Zealots were insurrectionists.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|to those who slap your face—present the other cheek too|i>…Ref. note of Matt. 5:39*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|draw conclusions|i>…<i|write people off|i>…Lit: <i|judge|i>…<i|condemn|i>. To begin to understand what Jesus means by judging and condemni*
                                     *ng, one should first learn from other Scriptures what it is not. It is not taking no account of what others do (one example: “Know them which labor am*
                                     *ong you,” 1 Thess. 5:12). In the NT, if someone who claimed to be a Christian conducted himself in an immoral manner, this person was to be treated li*
                                     *ke an infidel. But ascertaining such behavior is not judging. Judging is drawing conclusions, based on a person’s history, concluding what their fate *
                                     *or destiny must be. Condemning a person is determining that a person who has guilt due to sin will never be able to escape it, that part or all of the*
                                     *ir life is irredeemable—Even though it may in fact be irredeemable. To judge someone is to weigh them by their motives and not by their actions. To co*
                                     *ndemn someone is to assign them consequences. Concerning judging, ref. note of Matt. 7:1 also.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|Since he finished going through all of his material with those listening—a bunch of ordinary folk|i>…Lit: <i|Since he filled all the messa*
                                     *ges of his unto the listeners of the people|i>. An example of the colorful prose of Luke.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|associating with me|i>…Lit: <i|to go to you|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|under chain-of-command-structured authority|i>…Lit: <i|under authority of being commanded|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|open coffin|i>…More exactly, <i|bier|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|a deep reverence came upon everyone|i>…Lit: <i|all took a fear|i>. An idiom.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|brought to prominence|i>…Lit: <i|raised|i>*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|delicate apparel|i>…Also: <i|fine/soft/effeminate clothing|i>*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|centurion|i>…The Roman equivalent to an army captain. The issue here was that the centurion was a Gentile and that the Jews were not suppo*
                                     *sed to have any contact with the Gentiles—certainly not any close contact. This is why the centurion said in v. 6 that it’s not appropriate for Jesus *
                                     *to come pay him a visit of a personal nature.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|and|i> <i|have my servant receive healing|i>…Lit: <i|have my servant be healed|i>. The principle manuscripts diverge on this. The other pr*
                                     *inciples instead say, <i|and|i> <i|my servant will be healed|i>. The former, <i|and grant that my servant be healed, |i>is the reading chosen by the U*
                                     *BS NT, the correct choice. The UBS choice is consistent with and confirmed by the centurion’s statement in verse 8 which says,<i| I say to this one, h*
                                     *ave him come, and he comes|i>. The verb tense used in both <i|grant that my servant be healed|i> (for <i|grant…be healed|i>)<i| |i>and <i|I say to thi*
                                     *s one, have him go forth, and he goes |i>(for <i|have him go|i>) are both 3<s|rd|s> person imperatives. The meaning in the 3<s|rd|s> person imperative*
                                     * of <i|have him come |i>is more clear: the centurion is giving an order to a third party, the order being for the third party to relay another order t*
                                     *o the person, the one who’s being summoned. What the centurion wants is for Jesus to relay a command through a third party (his friends), instead of J*
                                     *esus giving a person-to-person order without the third party relay. This is the way that chain-of-command-structured authority hierarchies work; you c*
                                     *an give a command to a subordinate who will in turn pass the command down the chain of subordinates. The centurion’s faith caused him to recognize tha*
                                     *t the kingdom of God must also be a chain-of-command-structured authority hierarchy, or else if wouldn’t function.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|his mother’s only son (and she herself was a widow)|i>…With the death of her husband and only son, she had nobody to support her; this mag*
                                     *nified the pity which Jesus had for her. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|the countryside|i>…Lit: <i|the wilderness|i>. John spent all of this time out in the wilderness, avoiding cities, due to his austere lifes*
                                     *tyle; Jesus visited both wilderness and city.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|We sang a dirge, and you wouldn’t weep|i> <i|and wail|i> …Ref. note of Matt. 11:17*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|a sinner|i>…<i|be mindful of|i>…Also: (<i|for be mindful of|i>) <i|continuously aware of; ever cognizant of|i>. The way that she’s singled*
                                     * out as being “a sinner” (v.37) and the verb tense in <i|be mindful of |i>(v. 39) insinuate that she’s an adulterous or is sexually immoral in some ot*
                                     *her way. This verse literally reads, <i|he would’ve known she was a sinner, |i>leaving the implication that he would’ve done something about it.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|you didn’t greet me at the door with a kiss|i>…Lit: <i|you didn’t give me a kiss|i>. As seen in various places in the NT, it was customary*
                                     * back then to greet someone of the same sex with a kiss. The kiss was a cordial greeting, a sign of friendship and comradery. In fact, the Gk. word <i*
                                     *|philos|i> (φίλος /Strong’s 5384), usually translated <i|love|i>, sometimes means <i|kiss |i>or <i|friend.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[H]|s><i|caress my head with lotion|i>…<i|cover my feet with special oil|i>…Lit: <i|anoint my head with oil…anoint my feet with myrrh|i>. Myrrh is *
                                     *much more expensive than oil. Ref. note of Matt. 6:17 for anointing with oil.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|A word to the wise is sufficient|i>…Lit: <i|he who has ears, let him hear|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 11:15.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|left with just a bunch of stories|i>…Lit: <i|by/in analogies|i>; according to Max & Mary it means, <i|they are expressed|i>. Some guesswor*
                                     *k, heavily skewed by context, in arriving at the exact meaning of this phrase.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|fall away|i>…Also: <i|withdraw|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|he who seeks to have|i>…<i|he who won’t seek to have|i>…Lit: <i|he who would have|i>…<i|he who wouldn’t have|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|we’re going under|i>…Lit: <i|we’re perishing|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|I have no beef with you|i>…Lit: <i|What to me and to you?|i> Ref. Matt. 8:29*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|Regiment|i>…Lit: <i|Legion|i>. Ref. note of Mark 5:9*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|set straight and restored|i>…<i|come to the rescue|i>…<i|rescued from this calamity|i>…Lit: <i|saved|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|all-around good|i>…Lit: <i|beautiful and morally good|i>. This is a Gk. expression (<i|kalos kai agathos|i>/καλῇ καὶ ἀγαθῇ), (καλῇ /Strong*
                                     *’s 2570),( καὶ /Strong’s 2532), (ἀγαθῇ/Strong’s 18), two words which mean that something appears to be good when viewed from the outside and is in fac*
                                     *t good on the inside.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|the Bottomless Pit|i>…Lit: <i|the Abyss|i>. Mentioned a few times in Scripture (example: . Rev. 9:2, 9:11). This is the place where, some *
                                     *time in the future, demons will be kept locked up.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|a woman with a hemorrhage|i>…See note of Mark 5:25 for nature of illness.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|as probes|i>…Lit: <i|before his face|i>. A common idiom; ref. note of Luke 9:52.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|catapult workers out|i>…Lit: <i|cast workers out|i>*
