                                     *in the Law of Moses, a principle well-known to all Jews.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|God’s kingdom is here and now and within reach|i>…Lit: <i|God’s kingdom has come near you|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|had a change of heart and of conduct|i>…Lit: <i|repented|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|when we act using your delegated authority|i>…Lit: <i|in your name|i>. Also used in Mark 16:17.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|that you have clout in the spiritual world|i>…Lit: <i|that your names are written in heaven|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|he was filled with rapture in the Holy Spirit|i>…Lit: <i|he was exalted in |i>[or<i| by|i>]<i| the Holy Spirit|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|your intense and profound scrutiny|i>…Lit: <i|before you|i>. Short for <i|before your face |i>or similar to <i|in your sight|i>: phrases u*
                                     *sed throughout the Bible.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|mind, will, and emotions|i>…Lit: <i|soul|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|and you shall have eternal life|i>…Lit: <i|and you shall live|i>. Based on the context, the latter phrase is understood to mean the former*
                                     *.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|formulated|i>…Lit: <i|undertook|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|heading in the same direction|i>…The GT specifies that the man who was assaulted was going “down” to Jericho from Jerusalem, and that the *
                                     *priest was also going “down” as well. As a NT rule, one goes “up” to Jerusalem and goes “down” from Jerusalem. Based on this, the priest was travellin*
                                     *g in direction of Jerusalem.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|clergyman|i>…Lit: <i|Levite|i>. Some liberties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|applying lotion and disinfectant|i>…Lit: <i|pouring oil and wine|i>. Some liberties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|he handed the innkeeper cash for a couple weeks’ stay|i> …Lit: <i|he gave two denarii to the innkeeper|i>. Some liberties taken. Two denar*
                                     *ii is $200 according to the conversion in Matt. 18:28. A “couple weeks” is a crude estimate; relative to modern times, inns wouldn’t have been cheaper*
                                     * back then than they are today.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|sitting near the Lord attentively|i>…Lit: <i|sitting at his feet|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[r]|s><i|went straight up to him|i>…Also: <i|abruptly went over|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[s]|s><i|work|i>…Lit: <i|serving|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|And if there happens to be a peaceful soul there, your offer of piece will stick. Otherwise, it’ll bounce back to you|i>…Lit: <i|And if a *
                                     *son of peace happens to be there, your peace will rest upon it|i>. <i|Otherwise, it will return to you|i>. Notice the figurative language here in this*
                                     * passage, and, in fact, starting at the end of the previous chapter. Sprinkled throughout this discourse are Semitic idioms, expressions, etc. (<i|son*
                                     * of peace|i> is a good example). These appear to be literal word-for-word translations from Aramaic to Gk. of Jesus’s actual Aramaic words. In general*
                                     *, Luke uses less Semitic wording than Matthew, but there’s a noticeable difference here in this passage and in the previous chapters of Luke.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|done the burlap-and-ashes thing|i>…Lit: <i|sitting in sackcloth and ashes|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 11:21.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|Time and time again I saw, like a lightning strike, a demon get ejected from his spiritual dominion|i>…Lit: <i|I was watching |i>(imperfec*
                                     *t<i| |i>tense)<i| Satan fall from heaven like lightning|i>. Luke 10:18 is one of the most misinterpreted verses in the NT. It is commonly understood t*
                                     *o be Satan being cast out of heaven prior to the creation of man (ref. Is. 14:12; Ez. 28:16; Rev. 12:7–9). This is not the case. Instead, Jesus is see*
                                     *ing in the spiritual world (ref. “discerning of spirits”, 1 Cor. 12:10) what the seventy-two who had been sent out were doing in the natural world. Je*
                                     *sus was watching in real time; each time they cast out a demon, he saw a lightning strike.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *The elements to the correct interpretation of this passage, first, is that the word translated <i|was watching |i>is in the Gk. imperfect tense. In th*
                                     *is case, it insinuates multiple, repeated action, not a single action; plus it insinuates Jesus watching something unfold in real-time (in other words*
                                     *, watching concurrently as the disciples were doing it). Second, the Gk. word for <i|heaven |i>(<i|ouranos|i>/οὐρανός/Strong’s 3772) can mean either t*
                                     *he sky (Acts 1:1), heaven itself (Luke 10:14), the spiritual world around us (1 Cor. 12:2; Eph. 6:12), or a place of spiritual dominion. In the case o*
                                     *f Luke 10:18, <i|ouranos |i>means the third: a place of spiritual dominion. Third, the word <i|Satan |i>is used as a synecdoche/metonymy for the word *
                                     *<i|demon|i> (also in Matt. 12:26; Luke 13:16). Fourth, the word <i|fall |i>refers to somebody or something losing its authority or dominion, usually b*
                                     *y force (Rev. 18:2; Rev. 12:7–9).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *The correct interpretation of Jesus seeing multiple demons get cast down in real-time is relevant to the enclosing context. In other words, Jesus sent*
                                     * the disciples out, and in v. 17 they come back rejoicing, telling what had happened. Jesus regurgitating something which happened thousands of years *
                                     *before would be irrelevant and incongruous to the remark his disciples just made.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|legitimately claim and lay hold of|i>…Lit: <i|inherit|i>. To <i|inherit|i> or <i|the inheritance|i> or simply <i|possess |i>refer to the s*
                                     *ame biblical concept. The concept of the inheritance is that God has a specific place He has reserved for you, that you have claim to, and He promises*
                                     * to bring you to it (inheriting) and to keep you in it (salvation), and to restore you to it should you lose it (redemption). The concept of the inher*
                                     *itance starts in the OT with God promising Abraham a land, not only to him but to his descendants, and this land is eventually subdivided into continu*
                                     *ously smaller pieces, down to individual, single-family lots. Such subdividing of the land is enumerated in Joshua chapters 13–22. Though the concept *
                                     *of the inheritance begins with God communicating to His man, His tribe, His people that He has promised them a portion of land, it then extends into t*
                                     *he journey to get to that land and to the obedience required to take possession of that land. Some examples: Ps. 37:9,29; Prov. 10:30; Is. 14:21; Is. *
                                     *57:13; 60:21). The concept is applicable beyond land to anything God promises a believer to have, which in the case of v. 25 refers to eternal life.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|eternal life|i>…This phrase is used throughout the NT, particularly in the Gospel of John. From the face-value meaning of the words, <i|et*
                                     *ernal life |i>would appear to mean life after death, but there are a couple of problems with that interpretation. First, the OT, and by extension Juda*
                                     *ism, emphasizes the here-and-now and de-emphasizes life after death, to the point where some Jews (the Sadducees) didn’t even believe in life after de*
                                     *ath. Second, Jesus said in v. 28, “Do this and you shall live.” He’s talking about the here-and-now, not the life to come. This leaves the unanswered *
                                     *question: what exactly does the NT mean by the phrase <i|eternal life|i>? The answer comes from reading all the passages that talk about eternal life,*
                                     * reading them with an understanding that it’s talking about the here-and-now, not life after death, and meditating on the evidence. The answer will th*
                                     *en present itself.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|To choose the one good thing is what’s needed. You see, Mary considered her options and made the best choice; the very thing she chose wil*
                                     *l not be taken away from her|i>…Lit: <i|Of one thing is there need. For Mary chose the good part, whatsoever will not be taken away from her.|i> The r*
                                     *endering is not entirely certain. Max & Mary claim that <i|of one thing is there need |i>is short for the Semitic idiom <i|of few things is there need*
                                     * or of one. |i>It’s universally agreed that the word <i|good |i>is to be translated <i|best|i>. An inference is made with the word <i|part|i>, that it*
                                     * is one of many. Put together, it’s assumed that this paints a picture of Mary choosing between good and bad options.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|my children are all tucked in|i>…Lit: <i|my children are with me in the bed|i>. The GT hints that the parents and children are sharing the*
                                     * same bed, and if the friend could not get out of bed without stirring the children also.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|how much more will the Father give from heaven above a spirit which is indeed the Holy Spirit to those asking Him|i>…Two points to make co*
                                     *ncerning the rendering here. First, The principle manuscripts differ in the addition or omission of a single letter which changes the rendering somewh*
                                     *at. The rendering of the accepted GT reads, <i|the from-heaven-Father will give|i>; the alternate GT reads, <i|the Father will give from heaven|i>. Se*
                                     *cond, the omission of the definite article in <i|Holy Spirit. |i>Although the words for <i|Holy Spirit |i>occur in forms throughout the NT in both usi*
                                     *ng and not using the definite article, in this context the omission of the definite article indicates the nature of the gift which the Father is givin*
                                     *g, that the nature of the gift is good and never bad, and that if He’s giving the gift of a spirit, you can rest assured that it is none other than th*
                                     *e Holy Spirit.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|casting out a deaf demon (i.e., a demon of deafness)|i>…Other manuscripts read, <i|was casting out a demon, and it itself was deaf|i>. The*
                                     * majority of the principle manuscripts read the former and not the latter. The demon was a type of harassing spirit that causes deafness.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|with whose assistance do your protégés cast out demons?|i>…The only answer the skeptics could give to this question is that their protégés*
                                     * don’t rely on anyone’s help to cast out demons, because they do not nor ever will cast out demons. They’re questioning where Jesus is getting the abi*
                                     *lity to cast out demons; Jesus is asking why they don’t have any ability to cast out demons. Jesus goes on to say that whatever the answer to this que*
                                     *stion happens to be will decide whether he (Jesus) is getting help from God or from Beelzebub.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|a man who’s armed to the hilt|i>…Lit: <i|the fully-armed strong man|i>. The GT says <i|the strong man |i>instead of <i|a strong man|i> in *
                                     *the same way that John 10:10 reads, <i|the thief |i>(both are a figure of speech). Also, the GT emphasizes the fact that the man is wearing armor, as *
                                     *v. 22 literally reads, <i|he takes away the armor upon which he had relied, |i>instead of,<i| he takes away the weapons and armor upon which he had re*
                                     *lied|i>. It is the armor which turns the man a strong man, more so than the weapon he wields. His armor (and presumably a weapon to go along with it) *
                                     *makes him nearly invincible against someone who’s simply armed but is wearing no armor.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|seeking a place to take a break or to settle in, at least for a little while, and doesn’t find any|i>…Ref. note of Matt. 12:44*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|Right around now|i>…The GT suggests that the Pharisees used to clean their cups and plates before each meal, likely making a ceremony out *
                                     *of it, and Jesus was noticing them doing it and for that reason drew up a metaphor of it as they were about to do it.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[H]|s><i|avarice|i>…Lit: the Gk. word <i|harpagay |i>(ἁρπαγή/Strong’s 724). This word refers to a physical item: a hook used to draw a bucket out o*
                                     *f a well or a garden rake of some sort, something used to gather brush. In both cases, the purpose of the physical object is that of gathering and pul*
                                     *ling something in. In the context of this passage here in Luke, and perhaps for most usages, <i|harpagay |i>is the pulling in of non-material things, *
                                     *immorally so. It applies not only to wealth but to fame and to other things. Therefore, <i|harpagay|i> can alternately be translated <i|covetousness|i*
                                     *>, <i|greed|i>, or <i|rapacity|i>. In addition to the word <i|harpagay, |i>the Gk. word in the NT more frequently rendered <i|covetousness|i> or <i|gr*
                                     *eed|i> is <i|pleonexia |i>(πλεονεξία/Strong’s 4124), which is from the root word <i|pleon |i>(πλείων/Strong’s 4119), which means “too much.” <i|Pleone*
                                     *xia|i> is defined as, “a disposition to take more than one’s share”; in addition to meaning covetousness and greed, <i|pleonexia|i> can also mean, “so*
                                     *mething one feels forced to do.” <i|Pleonexia|i> is the compulsion to gather an inordinate amount of material goods; <i|harpagay|i> is the gathering o*
                                     *f such things, or the gathering of fame and the like. The word used in 1 Tim. 3:3 for “not covetous” is <i|aphilarguros |i>(ἀφιλάργυρος/Strong’s 866),*
                                     * which broken down from its concatenated roots is, <i|not-a-comradely-love-of-silver|i>. Since <i|silver|i> means <i|money|i>, it is better rendered<i*
                                     *|, not-a-comradely-love-of-money|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[I]|s><i|Just purge yourself of those things on the inside, and—presto—you can handle anything that’s off-limits from a ritualistic perspective|i>…*
                                     *Lit: <i|But rather give those inner things, alms, and behold all things are clean to you|i>. The phrase <i|give those inner things, alms|i> appears to*
                                     * be an expression or perhaps even an idiom, and its meaning is inferred from the context. It’s assumed that this phrase is a metaphor that compares th*
                                     *e purging of what’s on the inside to someone giving alms.*

                                     *i|the love of money is the root of all evil.|i>*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|add a minute to your lifespan|i>…Lit: <i|add a cubit to his lifespan|i>. Applying cubits, a unit of length, to lifespans, measured in time*
                                     *, is idiomatic. This is similar to the use of the word <i|inch|i>, a unit of length,<i| |i>in the idiom <i|within an inch of his life|i>, like in: <i|*
                                     *he had been beaten to within an inch of his life.|i>*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|Be poised for action|i>… Lit: <i|let your loins be gird about|i>. A biblical expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|keep your eyes peeled|i>…Lit: <i|keep your lamps burning|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|How much goodness and praise those servants will receive|i>…Lit: <i|Blessed be those servants|i>. Same wording as Matt. 5:3–10; Luke 6:20–*
                                     *22.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|he’ll put on his work clothes|i>…Lit: <i|he will gird |i>[<i|his loins|i>]. A biblical expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|late in the evening|i>…Lit: <i|in the second watch|i>. Approximately 10pm to 1am.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|partying|i>…Lit: <i|eating and drinking|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|rip him to shreds|i>…Lit: <i|cut him in two|i>. Same expression used in Matt. 24:51. This is an hyperbole.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|Don’t five sparrows sell for $6|i>…Lit: <i|Don’t five sparrows sell for 2 coins |i>[<i|valued at 1/10 drachma apiece|i>]. 1/10 of a drachm*
                                     *a is a small-currency coin and is equal to 1/16 of a denarius. See note of Matt. 18:28 for denarius conversion.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|God’s angels|i>…Certain angels surround the holy presence of God, who in addition to closing off visibility to Him, act as attendants, cou*
                                     *rtiers, servants, and the like. They form a king’s court of a sort, and just like in mediaeval or ancient times ambassadors or others, when they had a*
                                     *n audience with the king, had an audience with his entire court and not just with the king alone. Often, matters submitted to the king were submitted *
                                     *to the entire court, with the king presiding over it, and the court would vet and argue the matter for the benefit of the king, with the King presidin*
                                     *g over the interrogation and giving his final word at the end. Jesus saying that he’ll confess or deny a person in front of God’s angels means that he*
                                     * is doing so in God’s court, the formal venue to present matters which God presides over.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|Holy Spirit, having blasphemed, will not be forgiven|i>…Ref. note of Mark 3:29 concerning the unforgiveable sin, blasphemy of the Holy Spi*
                                     *rit.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|the Grim Reaper is coming for you|i>…Lit: <i|they demand your soul from you|i>. The literal rendering uses (howbeit by implication) the wo*
                                     *rd <i|they|i>, and in addition the word <i|demand |i>is in the active voice, not passive. This usage could have one of two meanings. First, it could b*
                                     *e an obscure reference to angels whose job it is to appear at the time of death and escort a person from this life to the next life, whether to heaven*
                                     * or to hell. Or second, it could be a tongue-in-cheek reference to some sort of ancient superstition of mythological creatures who appear at the appoi*
                                     *nted time of death to escort a person somehow.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|that swarm of difficulties that engulfs you|i>…Lit: <i|the little flock-ette|i> (<i|to mikron poimnion, |i>τὸ μικρὸν ποίμνιον), (τὸ /Stron*
                                     *g’s 3588),( μικρὸν /Strong’s 3398), (ποίμνιον/Strong’s 4168). Usage here is strange and is assumed to be an expression or an idiom. Therefore, the mea*
                                     *ning is not presumed to be the word-for-word literal interpretation; the exact meaning of this expression is inferred from the context. Some notes on *
                                     *the grammatical construct of this expression in the GT:*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *1. The appearance of the definite article (<i|to|i>) precludes this phrase from being in the vocative case; it must therefore be accusative*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *2. The word <i|poimnon|i> (ποίμνιον/Strong’s 4168)<i| |i>is the diminutive form of <i|poimnā |i>(ποίμνη/Strong’s 4167)<i|. |i>Diminutives are likely c*
                                     *andidates for usage in expressions.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *3. The use of the adjective <i|micron |i>is somewhat redundant considering that <i|poimnon |i>is already a diminutive, and by implication describes so*
                                     *mething small.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *4. Preceded by the definite article, the adjective is attributive and not predicative, which makes it more likely to be an expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *3. The use of the definite article means that Luke is referring to something specific.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|Sell…make…make|i>…The verb tense used here (the aorist) for these imperative verbs insinuate a few things. First, this tense is more empha*
                                     *tic than the default tense (the present). Second, it implies a one-time action. The one-time action of selling and giving doesn’t mean that there won’*
                                     *t be subsequent times in which this must be done, but it means that one doesn’t have to sell one’s belongings every time one accumulates belongings. J*
                                     *esus is being emphatic to get them to break a mindset of hoarding possessions, hoarding them for fear of not having enough in a time of need.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|I have to undergo|i> <i|an all-consuming, totally transformative event|i>…Lit: <i|I have a baptism to be baptized |i>[<i|in|i>]. This vers*
                                     *e (Luke 12:50), along with 1 Cor. 10:2 and with the accounts of John the Baptist, shed light on what the word <i|baptism |i>means in the Bible, and co*
                                     *nsequently what it is for a Christian to be baptized. In Luke 12:50, the baptism Jesus is referring to is his death and resurrection. In 1 Cor. 10:2, *
                                     *the nation of Israel was baptized into Moses by the cloud and the sea. And John the Baptist’s baptism was one of repentance. These passages on baptism*
                                     * reveal the following: Baptism is a totally transformative event. A person’s post-baptism life is changed entirely with respect to his pre-baptism lif*
                                     *e. The person being baptized enters into a binding contract, a covenant, of some sort. In order to undergo the transformation associated with baptism,*
                                     * the person being baptized must surrender his life to the transformation. After the baptism, the covenant which the person entered into is subject to *
                                     *terms, terms not only for the one baptized but also for God. God commits Himself to terms which consists of promises, and though a person is bound by *
                                     *the terms of the covenant, on the other hand he benefits from the terms God commits to, acquiring the promises. This baptism-covenant pattern summariz*
                                     *es Christianity: a total commitment by the one being baptized to the terms of the covenant (God’s commandments); access through faith to the promises *
                                     *of God (found in the Bible) which protects one from the depravations of life.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[H]|s><i|And now why do you also not decide amongst yourselves what’s the right thing to do about a dispute…|i>In this parable, Jesus tells his fol*
                                     *lowers that each person should objectively consider both sides of a dispute he’s embroiled in, and determine if his opponent’s case is stronger than h*
                                     *is own. Jesus is teaching them to impartially weigh the merits of both sides of the case. He repeats this point in a different parable in Luke 14:31. *
                                     *But in addition to objectively considering both sides to an argument, what Jesus says in vv. 57–59 is that once you weigh both sides of a dispute, you*
                                     *’ll find that your case is in fact the weaker of the two, and that being the situation, it would behoove you to settle the dispute between just the tw*
                                     *o of you and not let it go before a judge and have him settle it instead. This parable has several applications, the first application is that one is *
                                     *better “settling out of court” and receiving the remission of sins offered by Christ and not attempting to prove one’s own righteousness based on work*
                                     *s in a courtroom before God, where the verdict will be against you. Another application is walking in the Spirit rather than walking in your plain sel*
                                     *f. If you weight the evidence, you’ll find that plain-self, as it turns out, is dominated by the carnal nature, and as such cannot fulfill the lofty r*
                                     *equirements of the Christian life. Christians should recognize that living their life apart from the indwelling Spirit is a losing proposition and sho*
                                     *uld seek to redress the problem as soon as possible.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[I]|s><i|where he takes you before a judge, the judge rules against you, and you get thrown into debtors’ prison|i>…Lit: <i|where he hauls you befo*
                                     *re the judge, and the judge hands you over to the bailiff, and the bailiff throws you into prison|i>. Some liberties taken. Up until modern times, if *
                                     *one couldn’t pay the fine or penalty meted out by a court settlement, then that person was thrown in prison (debtors’ prison) until he could pay. The *
                                     *problem, of course, is that once in prison, the debtor is no longer free to earn money to pay the fine or penalty requisite to get out of prison. Unle*
                                     *ss someone else pays it or they cut you a break on the settlement terms, you’re stuck. And this is the point Jesus makes in v. 59: once thrown in pris*
                                     *on, you’ll get not breaks on the settlements and you’ll ever get out.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|ten and eight years|i>…This is the literal rendering of the GT. In v. 18, Luke writes <i|eighteen |i>as single word, then when quoting Jes*
                                     *us here in v. 16 he writes <i|ten and eight |i>instead of the shorter <i|eighteen. |i>The longer form is a word-for-word translation from the Aramaic *
                                     *which Jesus spoke into Gk., and is preceded by the word <i|behold |i>(rendered <i|get this|i>). Together, the words <i|behold |i>and <i|ten and eight *
                                     *|i>emphasize how long she had been afflicted.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|you need to get your head straightened out|i>…Lit: <i|whence are you?|i> The phrase <i|whence are you |i>is an expression, the keyword bei*
                                     *ng <i|whence |i>(<i|pothen|i>, πόθεν/Strong’s 4159). This expression also appears in John 7:27–28 (three times); John 8:14 (somewhat); John 9:29–30; J*
                                     *ohn 19:9. The expression roughly corresponds to the English, <i|where are you coming from? |i>Alternately, it may mean, <i|what are you all about?|i>;*
                                     * w<i|hat’s your driving motivation?; what makes you tick?; what’s your raison d’être?; I don’t know if you’re on the level; you’re a wacko. |i>On anot*
                                     *her note, this phrase is repeated in v. 27. The principle manuscripts differ in the reading. The accepted reading is lit. <i|I don’t know you, whence *
                                     *you are|i>; but other principal manuscripts read <i|I don’t know whence you are. |i>The latter is a shortened version of a well-known expression, read*
                                     *ily understood and registered as such by the hearer because of the conspicuousness of the word <i|whence.|i>*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|So now, the salt source works well|i>…Lit: <i|Therefore, the salt works well |i>[<i|or is good|i>]. It’s uncertain how this should be rend*
                                     *ered or what this is referring to (also, see Mark 9:49,50). The interpolation <i|source |i>is a best-guess. Some problems with this passage of vv. 34,*
                                     *35 is this. First, salt doesn’t just become insipid (loses its saltiness). Salt is a simple compound that doesn’t spoil like a biomass. Second, in v. *
                                     *35, the suggestion is to not put the salt in the ground or the compost pile (lit: <i|manure pile|i>). Even if salt did lose its potency, it’s still sa*
                                     *lt, and as salt it will poison any ground or compost it’s applied to. One will never put actual salt in the ground or in a compost pile. There must be*
                                     * more to the story here.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|the tax collectors and the sinners|i>…An expression repeated throughout the Gospels; ref. note of 18:10.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|the designated teachers|i>…Lit: <i|the Scribes|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|heartily welcomes|i>…Lit: <i|receives|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|I’m so glad and excited because I found my missing sheep. High-fives!|i>…Lit: <i|Rejoice with me, because I found my missing sheep|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|A certain man had two sons, and this is what he experienced with them|i>…The interpolation <i|and this is what he experience with them |i>*
                                     *is insinuated by the verb tense of the word <i|had |i>(which should actually be <i|was having |i>instead) in <i|a certain man had.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|more than enough food to eat|i>…Lit: <i|abound of loaves of bread|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|threw his arms around his neck|i>…Lit<i|: fell upon his neck|i>. As the words <i|fell upon|i> in the Bible usually refer to one person or *
                                     *party attacking another, the fervency in which the father hugged him around the neck is both a metaphor to attacking someone and also an hyperbole.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|you always have been and always will be with me|i>…Lit: <i|you are with me always|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|$100 bills|i>…Lit: <i|drachma|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 17:24 for conversion of drachmas to dollars.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|in the presence of the angels|i>…Lit: <i|before the angels of God|i>. The angels of God in this context are the angels who surround God; t*
                                     *he joy they are having is a metonymy for God’s joy, which extends to all heavenly beings surrounding Him.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|I have sinned against God and eversomuch against you|i>…Lit: <i|I have sinned unto the heaven and before you|i>. The Jews say <i|heaven|i>*
                                     * as a metonymy in place of God, to avoid speaking His name. His sin was “unto God” but it was before his father. In the Bible, before a person means t*
                                     *hat it is something that that person puts their focus and full attention on, and implies that that person is ever cognizant of.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|Premier Robe|i>…<i|ring for his finger|i>…Like Joseph’s robe of many colors, this Premier Robe (lit: <i|First Robe|i>) here is a visible i*
                                     *ndication of ranking and status. It shows that the son is reinstated to a position of authority in the family, having authority over the workers who r*
                                     *eport to the father. The ring is likely a signet ring, one used to affix the family seal on legal documents, giving him authority to transact business*
                                     * in the father’s name, similar to a credit card or even power of attorney.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|everything I own is yours|i>…This remark indicates that the older son, the faithful one, had the right to do anything he wanted with his f*
                                     *ather’s possessions, as his father considered that the elder son had joint ownership of them. Notice the word <i|them |i>is used in v. 12 and not the *
                                     *word <i|him|i>: <i|he distributed the estate among them|i>. This is further evidence that the father had given the faithful son full control over the *
                                     *entire estate. The older son’s problem is that he was waiting for the father to throw him a party; he could’ve thrown one himself.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|Everyone who gets divorced and then remarries commits adultery|i>…Lit: <i|everyone who divorces his wife and marries another commits adult*
                                     *ery, and every woman divorcee who remarries commits adultery|i>. The GT is worded this way because only the husband had the legal right to obtain a di*
                                     *vorce, not the wife.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|was dressed in the best clothing like all the other rich are|i>…Lit: <i|was clothed in purple and fine linen|i>*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|100 containers|i>…Lit: <i|100 baths|i>. A <i|bath|i> is an ancient Israeli unit of measurement equivalent to 5.8 gallons (21.9 liters). In*
                                     * all probability, olive oil containers like this consisted of large jars, pots, etc. of pottery that could hold a single bath. In today’s retail price*
                                     * for olive oil, one bath of olive oil would sell for around $240, setting the total value of all 100 baths at $23,000.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|100 barrels|i>…Lit: <i|100 measures|i>. One <i|measure|i> was ten times larger than a bath, making a measure equal to 58 gallons (220 lite*
                                     *rs). For perspective, a barrel of crude oil is 42 gallons; a measure is 6 times larger than a bushel. In today’s prices, 100 baths (600 bushels) of wh*
                                     *eat is valued around $3,000. Now, wheat production nowadays has been automated to a greater extent, relatively speaking, than other commodities, so th*
                                     *e effective dollar equivalent value for us would exceed $3,000.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|those who go with the flow in this awful world-system are shrewder than those who follow the light when it comes to dealing with their own*
                                     * kind|i>…Lit: <i|the sons of this age are more sensible |i>[or:<i| prudent; wise|i>]<i| over the sons of light unto their own generation|i>. A clearer*
                                     * meaning of the word <i|age|i> as used in this verse can be found in Eph. 2:2.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|the Almighty Dollar used for wrong-doing|i>…Lit<i|: the mammon of wrong-doing|i>. The Aramaic word <i|mammon|i> used in the NT carries wit*
                                     *h it negative connotations. The word <i|wrong-doing|i> is a repetition of the “for the wrong-doing” (v. 8), as what Jesus says in v. 9 is a reference *
                                     *to that parable.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|they just might take you into the condos |i>[<i|liberties taken; |i>lit:<i| tents or tabernacles|i>]<i| which are eternal|i>…The wording o*
                                     *f this sentence, along with the grammatical forms of these words, is a repetition of “they just might take me into their houses” ( v. 4), except <i|te*
                                     *nts|i> is substituted for <i|houses|i>. Also, the word <i|tents|i> is a Semitic figure of speech used in the OT (like in 1 Kings 12:16) which uses wor*
                                     *ds from the bygone-days of Israel that were bygone in Jesus’s time, as it hearkens back to the days before they were a nation but were nomads, like in*
                                     * the time of Abraham, still living in tents.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|custodian|i>…Lit: <i|domestic servant|i>. Not the usual words for servant, but a word having the same root as <i|account manager|i> (<i|st*
                                     *eward|i>) as used in this passage. Both <i|domestic servant|i> and <i|steward|i> take care of someone else’s possessions. The words suggest that the d*
                                     *omestic servant is in training or aspires to become a steward. As there is linking of the words for steward and domestic servant, v. 13 is a continuat*
                                     *ion of the parable of the steward.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|is confronted with agonizing choices|i>…Lit: <i|suffers violence|i>. The word for <i|suffers violence|i> is an idiom; though the exact mea*
                                     *ning is not entirely certain, it seems to mean that a person has to make difficult decisions to the point of undergoing hardships, of acting decisivel*
                                     *y, of exercising his willpower to the uttermost extent, and of challenging his most fundamental and sacred beliefs. Ref. Matt. 11:12.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[H]|s><i|to be in tight with Abraham, forever close to him|i>…Lit: <i|in the bosom of Abraham|i>. To a person to “be in the bosom of so-and-so” is *
                                     *for that person’s head to be in so-and-so’s lap while he’s reclined at the dinner table. Lazarus is reclined in such a way that his head is in Abraham*
                                     *’s lap, as John was in Jesus’s in John 13:23. “Abraham’s bosom” is a metaphor of close friendship, as the one who lies for a meal and places his head *
                                     *in another’s bosom is best of friends.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[I]|s><i|the world-to-come|i>…Lit: <i|Hades|i>. Hades is the Greek god of mythology who’s god of the underworld. It is also a synecdoche for the un*
                                     *derworld itself, the place where people go after they die. The writers of the NT used the word <i|Hades |i>in an abstract manner; in other words, they*
                                     * used it to refer to the place people go when they die. However, just because the NT uses the word Hades doesn’t mean that it concurs with all of what*
                                     * the Greeks thought of the underworld. It is simply the place where the dead go. As can be seen in this story, it consists of the place where both the*
                                     * good and the bad go after they die.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[J]|s><i|send Lazarus|i>…There is evidence that Lazarus was at one time the rich man’s servant: first, because the rich man recognized Lazarus at a*
                                     * distance; second, because he knew his name; third, the fact that Lazarus was stationed at his front gate, not far from where he had once lived; fourt*
                                     *h, that the rich man is asking for service from Lazarus, something he was accustomed to doing while alive. As it appears, when Lazarus became too old *
                                     *or too frail to perform his duties, the rich man tossed him out on the street, where he had to beg for the remainder of his life. The rich man’s wealt*
                                     *h and lavish lifestyle wasn’t directly responsible for his punishment in the afterlife, but the wealth and deceitful lifestyle fueled a disdain for hi*
                                     *s fellow man, and that ultimately is what landed him in hell. There are commandments in the Old Testament for showing kindness to the less-fortunate; *
                                     *the rich man disobeyed these.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|various means of getting tripped up or falling into sin|i>…Lit: <i|stumbling blocks|i>. Ref. Matt. 18:6.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|comrade|i>…Lit: <i|brother|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|multiple times in one day, to the point where you’ve had enough, and each time|i>…Lit: <i|seven times in one day, and seven times|i>. In t*
                                     *he Bible, the number seven is the number of completion. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|missionaries|i>…Lit: <i|apostles|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|have a seat|i>…Lit: <i|recline|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|taking my meal|i>…Lit: <i|eating and drinking|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|not effective enough as servants|i>…Lit: <i|unprofitable servants|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|purged|i>…Lit: <i|cleansed|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|because you sit down and go over everything with a fine-toothed comb|i>…Also: <i|with close inspection. |i>This is what some nowadays are *
                                     *guilty of.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|Look right here and look over there|i>…Lit: <i|behold here or there|i>. Possibly rendered, “Look—it’s right here,” or, “It’s over there.”*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|the Man|i>…Lit<i|: the Son of Man|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|Don’t go on a wild goose chase|i>…Lit: <i|Neither depart nor pursue|i>. The wording of the GT suggests that this is an expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|were living it up non-stop|i>…Lit: <i|were eating and eating, drinking and drinking|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|flaming sulfur|i>…Lit: <i|fire and brimstone|i>. An expression used throughout the Bible. It’s a figure of speech where one should remove *
                                     *the word <i|and |i>between <i|fire and brimstone.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|lying on a single bed|i>…Or possibly: <i|two reclined |i>[<i|for dinner|i>]<i| on a single couch|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|Go show yourselves to the priests|i>…Ref. note of Matt. 8:4; see also Luke 5:14*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|who’s of another nationality|i>…Ref. notes of Matt. 15:26, Mark 7:27*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|the Man will be the same way|i>…The principle manuscripts are split evenly on this, with the alternate reading, <i|the Man will be the sam*
                                     *e way when his day arrives |i>[<i|lit: in his day|i>]. The added phrase or something to that effect was insinuated by Luke, so the interpolation is co*
                                     *rrect, though it’s doubtful that these words appeared in the autograph.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|out on the back deck|i>…Lit: <i|upon the housetop|i>. Some liberties taken. Ancient Israeli houses had flat roofs, and they used their roo*
                                     *fs like we use porches and decks. Likewise, this explains Prov. 25:24.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|on that dreadful night|i>…Lit: <i|with this night|i>. Verse 31 starts out with Jesus saying <i|on that day|i>, but now he’s talking about *
                                     *“that night” instead of “that day.” He’s actually speaking of the same day, but he switches to saying night to signal that something dreadful is to ta*
                                     *ke place.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s>Verse 36 missing from the better manuscripts*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|they said|i>…Lit: <i|they say|i>. In the NT, narrative commonly switches to the present tense for effect, when the past tense is the true *
                                     *meaning. This is a figure of speech which conveys to the reader how tightly the sequential actions in a narrative are coupled; that things are unfoldi*
                                     *ng in real-time; the continuity of a conversation. The present tense puts the reader in the midst of the conversation as it’s unfolding, rather than l*
                                     *ooking at a stale description of how it turned out.*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|driving me bonkers|i>…Lit: <i|striking me in the face; treating me roughly; tormenting me|i>. An hyperbole.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|a judge who’s corrupt to the bone|i>…Lit: <i|the judge of injustice|i>. A figure of speech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|the Man|i>…Lit: <i|the Son of Man|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|the conviction that this widow had anywhere on this planet|i>…Lit: <i|the faith|i> [or, <i|conviction|i>] <i|upon the earth. |i>The assump*
                                     *tion is made that this faith/conviction refers to the widow’s faith/conviction.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|went up to|i>…This is the literal rendering; the temple sits atop a hill that overlooks Jerusalem, which in turn lies in the mountains.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|to pray|i>…The verb tense used suggests that the prayer was for a predetermined length of time, such as a prayer ritual or a session of pr*
                                     *ayer*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|tax collector|i>…Tax collectors in the NT are the stereotypical notorious sinner. Ref. note of 18:10.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|stood|i>…Lit: <i|was stood|i>. The passive voice of <i|to stand |i>is used instead of the active, a personification of some sort indicatin*
                                     *g that some inner conviction of the Pharisee animated him and caused him to stand.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|I give ten percent of everything I earn to the church|i>…Lit: <i|I tithe everything I earn|i>. Some liberties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|standing back at a distance, in the midst of his prayer was not wanting—even in the slightest way—to lift up his eyes to the sky, to heave*
                                     *n where God lives|i>…Lit: <i|standing at a distance was not wanting neither to lift up the eyes to heaven|i>. The use of the word <i|neither |i>and sa*
                                     *ying <i|the eyes |i>instead of <i|his eyes|i> is a figure of speech that gives this a poetic ring.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|with his slate wiped clean|i>…Lit: <i|having been justified|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|you see, God interacts with like kind as these|i>…Lit: <i|you see, of these such are God’s kingdom|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|vigilant to keep|i>…Lit: <i|watched carefully; guarded; protected|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|in the spiritual world, and come be my disciple|i>…Lit: <i|in the heavens, and come follow me|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|marvelous godsend|i>…Lit: <i|Son of David|i>. Ref. Matt. 12:23.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|What can I do for you?|i>…Lit: <i|What do you want me to do for you?|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|come to the rescue|i>…Lit: <i|saved|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|toddlers|i>…Lit: <i|babies|i>. When Luke states in v. 16 that he <i|called them over|i>, the antecedent of <i|them |i>is the word <i|babie*
                                     *s |i>in v. 15, and this word <i|babies |i>normally refers to newborns, but it’s inferred that Luke is referring to toddlers and not newborns, since ba*
                                     *bies are too young to respond to a person beckoning them to come. However, since the word <i|babies |i>is used, by our classification of minors from b*
                                     *irth to adulthood, this would mean very young children (toddlers) rather than just children generically, since the word children has connotations of a*
                                     * minor from the age of, let’s say, four to twelve. The word used in v. 16 for <i|boys and girls|i> (<i|paidia|i>, παιδίον/Strong’s 3813) has a broader*
                                     * meaning than <i|babies.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|Don’t prevent or otherwise hinder the boys and girls from coming to me|i>…Lit: <i|Let the boys and girls come to me and don’t prevent or o*
                                     *therwise hinder them|i>…The literal wording of the GT breaks apart what could or should otherwise be combined into a single phrase into two phrases jo*
                                     *ined by the conjunction <i|and. |i>This is a figure of speech, and since the literal wording is awkward, it’s been modified into a single phrase.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|Why do you call me ‘good’?|i>…Ref. notes of Matt. 19:17, Mark 10:18.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|The fact is, it’s easier for a camel to crouch down and crawl through a small gate portal than for a rich man to get involved with Him|i>…*
                                     *Lit: <i|For it’s easier for a camel to go into through an eye of a needle than a rich man to enter into God’s kingdom|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 19:24. Lu*
                                     *ke says <i|go into through an eye of a needle|i>, whereas Matthew says <i|to go throw the eye of a needle |i>(and they use different words for <i|eye *
                                     *|i>and <i|needle|i>).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|Gentiles|i>…Also: <i|foreigners; the nations|i>. Jesus is pointing out that his crucifixion is even more odious since it’s performed by Ge*
                                     *ntiles. The Gentiles are unclean; Jews were not supposed to associate with them; there are promises to Israel in the Old Testament of protection from *
                                     *the Gentiles. *

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|I just have to stay at your house today, you see|i>…Lit: <i|For|i> <i|I must stay at your house today|i>. A figure of speech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|descendant of Abraham|i>…Lit: <i|son of Abraham|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|the Man|i>…Lit: <i|the Son of Man|i>. Ref. Matt. 8:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|began to|i> <i|despise him, and this turned into hatred of him|i>…Lit: <i|began hating him|i>. Ref. Rom. 9:13 for similar use of word <i|h*
                                     *ate.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|a respectable representative from the community|i>…Lit: <i|an elder|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|hard-nosed|i>…Also: <i|exacting|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|take a cut of something you never invested in and expect a return on something you’re not entitled to|i>…Lit: <i|take away that which you *
                                     *didn’t place and reap that which you didn’t sow|i>. Ref. Matt. 25:24.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|people|i>…Lit: <i|they|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|at this very moment in time|i>…Lit: <i|in this day|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|what makes for peace|i>…Lit: <i|the things associated with peace|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|lay you out flat|i>…Lit: <i|dash you to the ground|i>. Figuratively speaking, somewhat.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|the timeframe of when you get checked on to see if you’re doing what you’re supposed to do|i>…Lit: <i|season of your visitation|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|designated teachers|i>…Lit: <i|Scribes|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|set in good order, preserved the way they’re supposed to be|i>…Lit: <i|salvation|i>. This meaning of the word <i|salvation |i>builds on it*
                                     *s usage in the OT (for example, Isa. 12:2; Jer. 3:23; Hab. 3:13), which has added to it additional meanings in the NT.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|$10,000 bill|i>…Lit: <i|ten minas|i>. Some liberties taken. A minas is a Middle-Eastern weight measurement amounting to 1.25 lbs. (0.57 kg*
                                     *) per minas, and for Jewish usage, 1 minas is equal to 100 denarii. A denarius is a day’s labor, or $100 (ref note of Matt. 18:28) in today’s purchasi*
                                     *ng power. However, since such this is pre-industrial era, the actual affect in ancient times of such purchasing power would make the amount seem great*
                                     *er. In other words, the amount would be similarly regarded as $10,000 would be regarded in a very poor country nowadays.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|he’s favored! he’s coming! the king! at Jehovah’s behest|i>…Lit: <i|The one being blessed, the coming one, the king, in the name of the Lo*
                                     *rd|i>. Liberties taken, as this chant, originally chanted in Aramaic, was translated tersely into Gk. As Gk. is compact due to its uses of inflections*
                                     *, representing nuances in verb tenses, noun cases, etc., it’s impossible to render this word-for-word in English while retaining the succinctness that*
                                     * a chant requires. A chant is as much about rhythm as it is about the actual words. I surmise that since this was a chant, and since chants aren’t nec*
                                     *essarily written in the same logical fashion as narratives are, this is one of the causes (though not the only one) for the disagreement in the princi*
                                     *pal manuscripts as to the precise wording of this verse.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|A certain man planted a vineyard|i>…Jesus’s parable of the vineyard here is actually a variation of the parable in Isaiah 5:1–7. The Scrib*
                                     *es and chief priests were caught up in the telling of the parable (v. 16 <i|Heaven forbid!|i>), instead of thinking on their feet and recollecting the*
                                     * theme of Isaiah’s original parable, which they would’ve surely been familiar with.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|Everyone falling upon that stone will be crumbled; whoever it happens to fall on, it will pulverize|i>…Ref. note of Matt. 21:44*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|coin (a denarius)|i>…Lit: <i|denarius|i>. This was a Roman coin. The Jews were forced to use currencies from other nations, but in so doin*
                                     *g were benefitting from the Roman system which supported the currency. As beneficiaries of this system, they were obligated to support it through taxa*
                                     *tion, the point that Jesus makes. In their hypocrisy, they were reaping the benefit but despising the system bestowing it.*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|laying their offerings on the offering plate|i>…Lit: <i|tossing offerings into the treasury |i>[<i|box|i>]. Some liberties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|I am the-one-and-only one|i>…Lit: <i|I am|i>. Same wording as in Mark 13:6. Ref. note there.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|The timeframe is right around the corner|i>…Lit: <i|the season has drawn near|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|directed by me|i>…Lit: <i|my name|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|rhetoric|i>…Lit: <i|mouth|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|Bad news|i>…Lit: <i|woe|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|utterly dominated and disrespected|i>…Lit: <i|trampled underfoot|i>. A NT expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|timeframe|i>…Lit: <i|season|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|run its course|i>…Also: <i|completed|i>; <i|fulfilled|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|the laws of physics that govern the sky above and the universe beyond will be perturbed|i>…Lit: <i|the powers of the heavens will be shake*
                                     *n|i>. Some liberties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|Man|i>…Lit: <i|Son of Man|i>. Ref. Matt. 8:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|your having things restored for you and your having things put back to the way they’re supposed to be for you is just around the corner|i>*
                                     *…Lit: <i|your redemption draws near|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|generation|i>…This word is taken literally in this context, but on the other hand, perhaps instead it could mean a collection of people of*
                                     * the same mindset or an era of thought in the history of mankind.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|grow old and fade out of existence|i>…<i|grow old and fade into irrelevance|i>…Lit: <i|pass by|i>. A NT expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|come all of a sudden and relentlessly oppress you|i>…Lit: <i|stand upon you|i>. The word <i|upon |i>used here in v.34 and also in v.35 has*
                                     * the same meaning as the way it’s used in <i|nation upon nation, kingdom upon kingdom|i> (v. 10, lit.), which talks about one group attacking another *
                                     *in some way or fashion.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|everywhere all over the planet, those simply relaxing and keeping to themselves|i>…Lit: <i|sitting upon the face of the entire earth|i>. <*
                                     *i|The face of the earth|i> is an idiom used in the OT, Gen. 7:23 for example.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|in all the various circumstances of life and in the change in current events|i>…Lit: <i|in all seasons|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|two dollars|i>…Lit: <i|two leptons|i>. A lepton was the smallest denomination of Greek coin, and is traditionally 1/100 of a drachma, and *
                                     *a drachma is roughly equal to a denarius (ref. note of Matt. 18:28 for denarius conversions).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|claiming to have my authority|i>…Lit: <i|upon my name|i>. Note that it is <i|upon my name |i>rather than <i|in my name|i>, which is used i*
                                     *n Mark 16:17 and elsewhere. <i|Upon|i> has connotations of forcefully taking something that belongs to another, as used in v. 10, lit: <i|nation shall*
                                     * be risen up upon nation|i>. Also, ref. notes of Mark 13:6, Matt. 24:4.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|famines & plagues|i>…The two Gk. words used for <i|famine |i>and <i|plague |i>in the phrase <i|limoy|i> <i|kai|i> <i|loimoy |i>(λιμοὶ καὶ *
                                     *λοιμοὶ) are the words <i|limos |i>(λιμός /Strong’s 3042) and <i|loimos|i> (λοιμός /Strong’s 3061) form an alliteration/assonance, giving credence to t*
                                     *he notion that this is an expression and as such is a generalization for all sorts of calamities, not confined to the literal meaning “famine and plag*
                                     *ue.”*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|a clamor of the waves and the sea|i>…In the Bible (for example, Rev. 13:1), the sea represents the masses of mankind; random people throug*
                                     *hout the globe.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|pull yourselves together and lift your spirits|i>…Lit: <i|straighten up and lift up your heads|i>. <i|Straighten up|i> implies straighteni*
                                     *ng up after a fight. <i|Lift up your heads|i> means to perk up, become optimistic, see the opportunities around you, no longer be downcast, shed your *
                                     *self-abasement.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|enter into|i>…An idiom; ref. note of Acts 19:8.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|ordeal|i>…Lit: <i|cup. |i>The word <i|cup |i>used this way is a biblical idiom.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|Let’s strike with a sword, shall we, Lord?|i>…Or perhaps: <i|Lord,|i> <i|you’d better believe we’re going to strike with a sword|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|Enough—leave ‘em alone|i>…Lit: <i|permit up to this|i>. This appears to be an expression, the meaning is not quite certain. Could also mea*
                                     *n, <i|let it slide.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|councilmen|i>…Lit: <i|elders |i>or <i|elders of the people|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|the Man will be assuming the position of God’s powerful chief executive|i>…Lit: <i|will be the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of pow*
                                     *er of God|i>. The phrase <i|sitting at the right hand of power |i>is worded as a figure of speech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|With the longings of eager desire, I eagerly desire|i>…Lit: (in Gk.) <i|epithumia epethumasa |i>(Ἐπιθυμίᾳ ἐπεθύμησα), (Ἐπιθυμίᾳ /Strong’s *
                                     *1939), (ἐπεθύμησα/Strong’s 1937). This redundant use of the same word, howbeit in noun and participle forms, is likely an expression, and if not an ex*
                                     *pression, would be a figure of speech (alliteration/assonance).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|just forget it, ok…|i>Also: <i|enough on this topic|i>…Or: <i|That’ll work|i>…Lit<i|: it is enough|i>. Some ambiguity, as Jesus could be t*
                                     *aken to mean “enough of this nonsense” or “that’ll be enough swords.” The former is assumed to be correct, as it is connected to what Jesus said in v.*
                                     * 36: “have him sell his jacket [lit: cloak] and have him buy a sword.” What Jesus meant by this statement of v. 36 is that you’ll no longer need your *
                                     *cloak. Everyone owned a cloak, and most people owned just one, and it was used as a blanket at night—which would be your only blanket too. In the long*
                                     *-term, a cloak was an essential need of life, but in the short-term is not a necessity, like when one is engaged in moderate physical activity, since *
                                     *the body generates enough heat to keep oneself warm without needing a cloak for warmth. The cloak becomes necessary after the activity, of course. The*
                                     * sword refers to going to a war. Together, what v. 36 means is for you to get rid of your cloak since you won’t be needing it anymore, but acquire a s*
                                     *word in its place, since you will be needing that: You’re going to war and you’ll probably be killed. Jesus didn’t literally mean to buy a sword and g*
                                     *o off to battle; his meaning was figurative. But the twelve didn’t see it as figurative, taking the statement literally. Jesus didn’t have enough time*
                                     * to explain himself, so he simply dropped the subject by saying “just forget it, ok.”*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s>Verses 43 and 44 are not found in some of the most important manuscripts (KJV: “43And there appeared an angel unto him from heaven, strengthe*
                                     *ning him. 44And being in an agony he prayed more earnestly: and his sweat was as it were great drops of blood falling down to the ground.”)This passag*
                                     *e has always been controversial, and that because of its content. Verse 43 has the same spurious feel to it as John 5:4, and verse 44 has been debated*
                                     * for centuries (see next note).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|his sweat happened to drip on the ground like when drops of blood from a cut drip on the ground|i>…Jesus didn’t actually sweat drops of bl*
                                     *ood; this is a simile. The rate at which his drops of sweat dripped onto the ground is compared to the rate at which, say for example, you cut your fi*
                                     *nger with a knife—the rate at which that cut bleeds. That’s a high rate of perspiration, one which occurs when a person is engaged in highly strenuous*
                                     * exercise, usually complicated by warmer temperatures. The fact that Jesus wasn’t physically moving and that it was chilly enough later in the night f*
                                     *or Peter to have to warm himself around a fire makes this extraordinary. On the other hand, there’s dubious (at best) scientific evidence to back up t*
                                     *he claim that people under extreme duress sweat blood. It simply does not happen. So if Jesus did actually sweat drops of blood, as many assert, that *
                                     *removes that experience of prayer out of the realm of human experience and into the super-human, even supernatural, and in this instance would have ex*
                                     *empted him from suffering as an ordinary human being.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|Why do we need to find any more witnesses|i>?…By the Law of Moses, a conviction in the Jewish court required two or three witnesses.*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|a Messiah-king|i>…Lit: <i|Christ king|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|Whatever you say|i>…Lit: <i|You’re saying |i>[<i|it|i>]; or possibly: <i|You said it, not me|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|designated teachers|i>…Lit: <i|scribes|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|Crucify him and crucify him some more|i>…Lit:<i| crucify crucify him|i>. Appears to be an expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|Dear ladies|i>…Lit: <i|Daughters of Jerusalem|i>. More precisely, it means the society women of Israel’s leading metropolis, Jerusalem, as*
                                     * for example used in Song of Solomon 1:5.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|Jesus proceeded to say, “Father, forgive them, since they don’t know what they’re doing.”|i>…The principal manuscripts are divided as to w*
                                     *hether this sentence is spurious or not.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|rolled dice|i>…Lit: <i|cast lots|i>. Some liberties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|assume your preordained position in your kingdom|i>…Lit: <i|come into your kingdom|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|noon|i>…<i|three in the afternoon|i>…Lit: <i|the sixth hour|i>…<i|the ninth hour|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|bright, colorful, beautiful clothing|i>…In ancient times, kings, noblemen, and the rich were distinguished from the peasants by wearing th*
                                     *is sort of clothing; hence Herod’s mocking of Jesus’s kingship.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s>Verse 17 omitted by the better manuscripts*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|If they’re doing these things with pieces of freshly-cut lumber, then whatever happened to the dried-out pieces|i>?…The lumber Jesus is re*
                                     *ferring to is the lumber used to make a cross. The answer to Jesus’s question, <i|what happened to the dried-out pieces, |i>is that the dried-out piec*
                                     *es are already in use with bodies still hung on them being crucified. As a result, there are no more pieces of wood lying around which can be used to *
                                     *crucify everyone who’s about to be crucified. The Romans crucified criminals on a regular basis, and undoubtedly reused the same crosses over and over*
                                     *, keeping them in a back room or a warehouse, as this would be easier than finding wood and building a cross each time a criminal needed to be crucifi*
                                     *ed. So they kept enough crosses in storage to handle the day-to-day crucifixions, and these crosses are the “dried-out<i| |i>pieces”<i| |i>referred to*
                                     * in this verse. However, there were instances when the Romans performed mass-crucifixions, and the fall of Jerusalem in 70AD would be one such instanc*
                                     *e. In that case, they wouldn’t have been enough crosses in storage to perform all the crucifixions, as the roads would be lined for miles with those c*
                                     *rucified. In that case, they’d have to cut down trees to get the lumber needed for all the crucifixions, hence the “pieces of freshly-cut lumber.”*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|It was a preparation day, preparation for the Sabbath which would start the following day, and the sun was about to set and consequently b*
                                     *egin the next day, the Sabbath|i>…Lit: <i|It was a preparation day, and it was |i>[<i|starting to|i>]<i| dawning a Sabbath|i>. Though the Gk. word for*
                                     * <i|dawn |i>is used in the verse, scholars agree that this is referring to the beginning of a new day, which for the Jews is evening, not morning, and*
                                     * not sunrise per se. Some liberties taken with the wording to make this clearer to the reader.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s>The sentence begun at the end of this chapter is completed in the next chapter.*
SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER

HEADING1                             *The Gospel of John*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *John’s Gospel stands apart from the other three—Matthew, Mark, and Luke, the Synoptic Gospels—in more ways than one. It’s content is different, it’s c*
                                     *hronology is different. The Greek that John uses is very simple and is, for the most part, readily translated word-for-word into English. However, und*
                                     *erneath the simplistic wording is an enigmatic book which makes vague, abstract generalizations it does not explain. John’s epistles are even more sim*
                                     *plistic yet enigmatic and vague.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *On the one hand, John’s writing needs a good copy editing. Among other things, he uses the wrong verb tenses, is too ambiguous, assuming that the read*
                                     *er will have no problem filling in the missing content. Had I submitted something comparable to the way that John writes as a high school term paper, *
                                     *my English teachers would’ve marked it all up in red.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *On the other hand, John has his own peculiar meaning of words and phrases that differ from everything else in the NT and which can only be learned by *
                                     *studying his writings, the simple, vague phrases which are enigmatic and profound. In fact, from a language perspective, John’s Gospel should be viewe*
                                     *d in a separate light from the remainder of the NT, so different is his writing. Inside this simple fisherman was a deeply spiritual man, one who was *
                                     *Semitic and not Western, one who used words and grammatical constructs his own ways and not the way everyone else does.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Of all the books in the NT, John’s Gospel has enjoyed preeminence from the days of the early church. This is proven by the fact that the oldest surviv*
                                     *ing manuscripts NT manuscripts, and the most numerous of the oldest, are of John. And if Matthew was written to Jews, Mark to Romans, Luke to Greeks, *
                                     *then John was written to Christians.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|take it down, overpower it, or contain it|i>…Also: <i|suppress it|i> (NASB); <i|hold it down. |i>Same word used with the same meaning in J*

                                     *t is a concept, has a gender which is neuter.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|know|i>…Also: <i|understand|i>, <i|comprehend|i>, <i|recognize|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|whole-heartedly welcome and embrace him|i>…Lit: <i|receive alongside|i>*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|out of a best-effort of self nor out of carnal desire|i>…Lit: <i|from flesh|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|has been the center of my attention|i>…Lit: <i|before me|i>. Common phrase throughout the Bible.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|grace piled on top of grace|i>…Lit: <i|grace in place of grace|i>. As if the subsequent grace replaces the previous grace.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|clergymen|i>…Lit: <i|Levites|i>. Some liberties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|He gave them a straight-up answer saying forthrightly|i>…Lit: <i|He confessed and didn’t deny and confessed that|i>. A figure of speech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|the Messiah|i>…Lit: <i|the Christ|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|Who do you claim to be?|i>…Lit: <i|What do you say about yourself?|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|countryside|i>…Lit: <i|wilderness|i>*
