FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|In the beginning|i>…Lit (Gk): <i|en archai |i>(Ἐν ἀρχῇ), (Ἐν/Strong’s 1722), (ἀρχῇ/Strong’s 746). Same two-word introduction as is found i*
                                     *n Gen. 1:1 of the Septuagint; this is not a coincidence. The rendering therefore the typical English Bible’s Genesis beginning so that the reader woul*
                                     *d notice the similarity. Otherwise, variations in translation could render <i|en archai|i> as “in ancient times” or something like that, as the defini*
                                     *te article is missing from <i|beginning, |i>which means there’s no specific beginning epoch referred to.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|the Concept|i>…Lit: <i|the Word|i>. <i|Concept|i> (short for <i|Conception|i>)<i| |i>taken from H.D.F. Kitto’s book <i|The Greeks|i>: “In *
                                     *the works of Man, Reason and Perfection assume a symmetrical form…The Greek for Reason, in the present sense, is ‘logos’, from which the adjective ‘lo*
                                     *gical’. ‘Logos’ is usually mistranslated ‘word’: is rather ‘speech’, or, the idea which is conveyed by speech. ‘In the beginning was the Word’ really *
                                     *means ‘In the beginning was the Conception’…Here is the culmination of the search made by Greek thinkers for the inner reality, the ‘logos’; The Word *
                                     *was God.” Also, ref. note of Rom. 10:8.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|in the midst of it all the light shined|i>…Lit: <i|the light shines|i>. The use of the present tense for the past tense is a common figure*
                                     * of speech used in the Gospels. Ref. note of Luke 17:37. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *But for this verse, this is a special figure of speech, a subcategory of the usage of present for past, one where in two consecutive, related clauses *
                                     *(first clause: <i|the light shines in the Darkness|i>; second clause: <i|the Darkness couldn’t take it down|i>), the first clause uses the present ten*
                                     *se, but is understood by the reader to be the past tense, and the following clause uses the past tense as expected. This same figure of speech is used*
                                     * in Rev. 12:4a, Rev. 13:14b. The usage of such a figure of speech begs the question: what idea, notion, etc. is the writer communicating beyond the fa*
                                     *ce-value meaning of the words? Some guesswork is involved, but it appears that the present tense in the first clause is similar to some of the modes o*
                                     *f the imperfect tense, where in the imperfect directs the reader to pause and ponder what was going on as the event was unfolding. In the present-then*
                                     *-past-tense clauses, the present tense seems to emphasize a difficulty of some sort—perhaps even a long, drawn-out ordeal—and the follow-up past tense*
                                     * clause states with emphasis the outcome of the difficulty.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|set up camp|i>…Lit: <i|dwelled in a tent |i>or <i|pitched tent|i>. Hearkens back to the days of Abraham and also to the sojourning in the *
                                     *wilderness when the people of God lived in tents. As such, it is a Figure of Speech, one used here and there in the Bible. Ref. note of Luke 16:9. It *
                                     *also indicates that Jesus was only to take on flesh and live among us for a brief period of time, then he would—like a nomad—fold up his tent one day,*
                                     * break camp, and go somewhere else.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|in tight with the Father|i>…Lit: <i|being in the bosom of the Father|i>. Same word <i|bosom |i>used for <i|the bosom of Abraham|i>; it is *
                                     *the same concept. Ref. note of Luke 16:22.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|the Judean Jews|i>…Lit: <i|the Judeans|i> or <i|the Jews|i>. John uses this word several times when he writes. It can be translated <i|Jew*
                                     *s |i>or <i|Judeans |i>depending on the context. When translated <i|Jews, |i>it refers to Jews in general, non-Gentiles. When translated <i|Judeans |i>*
                                     *(ref John 2:18, 3:1 for example), it refers to the Jews who live in Judean, as opposed to Jews who live in Galilee, etc. Also by referring to Judeans,*
                                     * the implication is that these are the Jews who occupy the positions of power in Israel.*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|up to a keg or a keg and a half apiece|i>…Lit: <i|up to two or three metretes|i>. A <i|metrete|i> is 8.75 gallons (40 liters); three metre*
                                     *tes make 26.25 gallons (120 liters).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|spectacular miracle|i>…Lit: <i|sign|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|that he had authority bequeathed on him|i>…Lit: <i|in his name|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|spell out plainly and clearly|i>…Lit: <i|testify|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|human nature|i>…Lit: <i|the man. |i>The definite article <i|the |i>before <i|man, |i>like <i|the thief |i>in John 10:10, specifies an arch*
                                     *etype rather than a specific person.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|on a Tuesday|i>…Lit: <i|with|i> <i|the Third Day|i>. John’s use of the attributive form of the adjective in conjunction with the definite *
                                     *articles means that he’s referring to something which he’s confident that the reader will know about. In fact, <i|the Third Day |i>is a variation of <*
                                     *i|the third of the Sabbaths; |i>ref. notes of Math 28:1, Mark 16:2, 1 Cor. 16:2.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|I have no beef with you, lady|i>…Lit: <i|me and you, woman|i>; and expanding the inflections, <i|to me and to you, woman|i> (<i|me|i> and *
                                     *<i|you|i> are in the dative case; the addition of the preposition <i|to |i>is necessary when rendered to English). <i|Me and you |i>is an expression u*
                                     *sed in the NT, and appears in Matt. 8:29, Mark 1:24, Mark 5:7, Luke 8:28 (and perhaps more). Its meaning is deduced by its usage in these various vers*
                                     *es.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|I have no beef with you, lady—my time has not yet arrived!|i>…This is the first miracle Jesus ever performed (ref. v. 12), and it’s signif*
                                     *icant that it occurred at a wedding. This wedding has a symbolic meaning, and what Jesus says here addresses the symbolism of the event. The wedding s*
                                     *ymbolizes God’s plan for the human race. God intended all of mankind to live life as though it were one long wedding celebration of a sort, but then s*
                                     *in entered into the world and spoiled the party. Wine is what generates the frivolity and lightens the mood, causing the guests to loosen up and celeb*
                                     *rate. Wine symbolizes the means by which mankind can enter into life’s celebration. But also, as red wine has a color similar to blood, at the same ti*
                                     *me it’s symbolic of the blood Jesus shed on our behalf. The symbolism is this: the party is over until someone supplies the wine (the blood), which br*
                                     *ings life back to a dead party. When Mary tells Jesus they have no wine, on the symbolic level, she’s telling him to give the blood which will restore*
                                     * the human race to its festivities. This is why Jesus replied, <i|my time has not yet arrived|i>—the time for him to shed his blood had not yet arrive*
                                     *d.*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|one night|i>…Lit: <i|at night|i>. The verb tense of <i|went |i>insinuates that this was a one-time visit.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|spectacular miracles|i>…Lit: <i|signs|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|a first-hand understanding|i>…Lit: <i|see|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|not a baby|i>…Lit: <i|old|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|give formal account|i>s…<i|our formal accounts|i>…Lit: <i|testify|i>…<i|testimony|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|the Man|i>…Lit: <i|the Son of Man|i>. Ref. Matt. 8:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|in the authority bequeathed upon|i>…Lit: <i|in the name of|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|a missionary|i>…Lit: <i|a sent-one|i>. Same root that word <i|apostle |i>is derived from.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|is overwhelmed with joy|i>…Lit: <i|in joy rejoices|i>. An expression; ref. note of Matt. 2:10.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|put his stamp of approval on|i>…Lit: <i|sealed|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|He does not limit the quantity of the Spirit which He gives|i>…Lit: <i|He does not give the Spirit from out of a measure|i> [or, <i|from o*
                                     *ut of a fixed, finite quantity|i>]. A figure of speech. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|placed under his direct control|i>…Lit<i|: given into his hand|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|hovers over him|i>…Lit: <i|dwells upon him|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|born from that spiritual plane where God exists|i> …Lit: <i|born from above|i>. In the NT, the three concepts of the sky above, heaven, an*
                                     *d the spiritual domain are conflated. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|water and spirit|i>…The water refers to the water of repentance, such as the water baptism that John the Baptist performed. The water symb*
                                     *olizes a change in lifestyle. The spirit is the spiritual experience of regeneration which a person must undergo at the same time. In this regeneratio*
                                     *n, a person is reborn spiritually and the Holy Spirit comes and dwells in his regenerated spirit which is inside of him. The two, water and spirit, ar*
                                     *e the two elements of Christianity that go hand-in-hand: a change to live the right way and a spiritual life, a life in the Spirit.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|the wind blows|i>…Also: <i|the Holy Spirit breathes wherever He pleases, and you hear the sound He makes, but you don’t know where He come*
                                     *s from or where He’s going to|i> .The Gk. word used for <i|wind |i>here is <i|pneuma |i>(πνεῦμα/Strong’s 4151), the same one used for <i|spirit; |i>an*
                                     *d since the definite article precedes <i|pneuma, |i>it would be <i|Holy Spirit |i>instead of <i|spirit. |i>Jesus is referring to both the actual wind *
                                     *and the Holy Spirit in this sentence.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|takes possession of|i>…Also: <i|is having|i>. First, <i|is having|i> means that this is the moment when the woman is no longer under the a*
                                     *uthority of her father but instead comes under the authority of her husband. Second, it means directly or insinuates indirectly that the groom is havi*
                                     *ng sex with the bride.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|hardly anybody at all|i>…Lit: <i|nobody|i>, as in the fuller context, <i|Nobody received his testimony. |i>(v.33)<i| The one who received *
                                     *his testimony sealed that God is true. |i>Note how John says in v. 32 that nobody received his testimony, then states the opposite in v.33, that some *
                                     *did receive his testimony. The word <i|nobody |i>is not to be taken literally; it is a figure of speech which is something like a combination of a syn*
                                     *ecdoche and an hyperbole. A key to detecting this figure of speech is that the contradiction occurs immediately after the premise. In this case the wo*
                                     *rd <i|nobody |i>is followed up just a few words (not a few verses) later in v.32 with <i|the one who received his testimony. |i>John uses this figure *
                                     *of speech a few times in both his Gospel and in his epistles, and it can confuse the reader if he is unaware that this is a figure of speech, and to b*
                                     *e taken with a grain of salt and not literally. A usage of a figure of speech similar to this in English might be: <i|I posted all of the pictures of *
                                     *my vacation on social media, and—like—nobody commented on them. But the two people who did…|i>*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|ancestor|i>…Lit: <i|father|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|well-put to have said|i>…Also: <i|well-stated to have said|i>; <i|you did good when you said|i>; <i|good job to have said; correct answer *
                                     *to have said|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|the guy you’re sleeping with now|i>…Lit: <i|whom you have now|i>. Similar usage of <i|have |i>as in John 3:29; ref. note there*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|on|i>…Lit: <i|in|i>. The usage of <i|in |i>when referring to being on a mountain idiomatic; John repeats this idiomatic usage of the word *
                                     *<i|in |i>in Rev. 1:9, <i|on the island of Patmos.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|trust|i>…Also: <i|believe|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|rescue program|i>…Lit: <i|salvation|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|God is a spirit by nature|i>…Lit: <i|God is spirit|i>. The lack of a definite article emphasizes the fact that this is God’s nature.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|in the true way: in spirit|i>…Lit: <i|in spirit and truth|i>. A figure of speech called a hendiadys. Ref. note of Matt. 3:11.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|What are you up to?|i>…Lit: <i|What are you looking for?|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|Come see a man who told me everything I did wrong in life, in a nutshell|i>…In a reading of the GT, the woman insinuates the added words.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|stop with the tunnel-vision and look at what’s going on around you|i>…Lit: <i|lift up your eyes|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|gets no respect|i>…Lit: <i|has no honor|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|welcomed him whole-heartedly|i>…Lit: <i|received him|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|a malady of some sort|i>…Lit: <i|a weakness|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 4:23.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|spectacular miracles|i>…Lit: <i|signs and wonders|i> (v.48); <i|sign|i> (v. 54)*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|held their worship services|i>…Lit: <i|worshipped|i>. Some liberties taken, as the worship John is referring to are the appearances before*
                                     * priests at the temple in Jerusalem, where animals were offered as sacrifices, etc., and not a church or synagogue service as we know it. The feud bet*
                                     *ween the Jews and the Samaritans originated years ago when the northern tribes of Israel under Rehoboam (and the Samaritans are descended from them) s*
                                     *evered ties with Judah. A political problem arose for Rehoboam, in that the temple was in Jerusalem, which is in Judah. He figured if his newly-secede*
                                     *d kingdom were to continue their pilgrimages to the Jerusalem temple, their sentiments and affections, and hence their political loyalty, would eventu*
                                     *ally return to Judah. For this reason, Rehoboam instituted religious observances in the north; this Samaritan woman refers to this.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|worship|i>…Jesus refers to worship, both to the OT and the NT forms of worship. The OT worship consisted of appearances before priests at *
                                     *the temple, which included (but was not limited to) sacrificial offerings. NT worship is not like that; NT worship in its essence is spiritual. Humans*
                                     * are spiritual beings, God is a spirit, and we offer Him worship out of our spirits. No physical forms are necessary to do this, but man with his reli*
                                     *gious tendencies yields to the temptation of supplanting spiritual worship with physical or emotional forms.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|feeble with sicknesses of one sort or another|i>…Lit: <i|weak|i>. Commonly used word in the NT to describe a person who’s run-down with an*
                                     * unknown medical condition, as they couldn’t diagnose diseases back then very well. Ref. note of Matt. 4:23.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|While it’s agitated and I’m on my way to the pool, someone else cuts in front of me|i>…Lit: <i|In it I’m going another goes down in front *
                                     *of me|i>. Assumption is that, since this is a conversation, the man omitted a few words.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|all of this…this|i>…Lit: <i|these things|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|my Father’s been doing good deeds, and is doing good deeds, and so am I|i>…Lit: <i|my Father works, and I also work|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|the Man|i>…Lit: <i|the Son of Man|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|in the graveyard|i>…Lit: <i|in the tombs|i>. The Jews buried their dead in tombs, not graves; some liberties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|depart from that place: those who did the good things that one’s supposed to do will depart to an afterlife|i> <i|of that special fullness*
                                     * of life, but those who were in the habit of doing the petty, careless, thoughtless, mean, ugly things that one’s not supposed to do to an afterlife o*
                                     *f judgment resulting in a guilty verdict…|i>Lit: <i|And they will go out, those who did the good to a resurrection |i>[<i|a raising up|i>]<i| of life,*
                                     * but those who did the bad to a resurrection |i>[<i|raising up|i>]<i| of judgment|i>. Ref. note of John 6:40.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|formally assert claims|i>…Lit: <i|testify|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|take to heart and embrace|i>…Lit: <i|receive|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|the human race|i>…Lit: <i|man|i>*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s>Verse 4 is one of several spurious verses added to the NT well-after the NT was written. Besides missing from best manuscripts of John’s Gosp*
                                     *el, it has the familiar characteristics of the spurious embellishments…attempting to protect God’s majesty; more condemnation; odd-sounding miracles. *
                                     *Translated here for reference:*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<i|For an angel of the Lord from time to time went down into the pool and was agitating the water. So now, the first to get in after the agitation of *
                                     *the water was becoming whole of whatever disease he was having for some time|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|water’s been agitated|i>…For centuries, people have been taking dips in pools, saunas, baths, springs, etc. for therapy, to heal them of w*
                                     *hatever ails them. This is the case here. The question here is how the water got agitated (stirred up). Attendants may have stirred it for a few minut*
                                     *es from time to time, or perhaps some of the water was discharged from a feeding aqueduct and as a side-effect of the pool being refilled, the rushing*
                                     * water caused the agitation. *

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|miracle after miracle|i>…Lit: <i|signs|i>. The verb tense for <i|were seeing |i>changes the rendering somewhat.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|for|i>…Lit: <i|upon|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|$20,000|i>…Lit: <i|200 denarii|i>. For conversions to dollars, ref. note of Matt. 18:28.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|grilled|i>…Lit: <i|cooked|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|find a spot, have a seat, and relax|i>…Lit: <i|recline|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 14:19.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|miracle|i>…Lit: <i|sign|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|3 or 3.5 miles (4.5 or 5.5 km)|i>…Lit: <i|25 or 30 stadii|i>. 1 stadia = 184 meters. See also Luke 24:13.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|the Man|i>…Lit: <i|the Son of Man|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|decreed and guaranteed that this person is the man who is approved by Him|i>…Lit: <i|sealed this |i>[<i|man|i>]. Also, see the way John us*
                                     *ed the word <i|sealed |i>in Rev. chapters 6, 7.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|reels him in|i>…Lit: <i|drags him|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|the back half of the Old Testament|i>…Lit: <i|the prophets|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|receive instruction|i>…Also: <i|be|i> <i|taught|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|my true flesh is true food, and my true blood is drink|i>…Or perhaps:<i| my flesh is true food, and my blood is true drink|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|sticks to me|i>…Or: <i|dwells in me|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|what things|i>…Or:<i| whom|i>. The text is ambiguous.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|So they gathered and filled twelve baskets of scraps from what was leftover by those who had eaten, leftovers from out of the five loaves *
                                     *of the barley-bread|i>…Lit: <i|So they gathered and filled twelve baskets of scraps out of the five loaves of the barley |i>[<i|bread|i>]<i| that they*
                                     * leftover by those who had eaten|i>. The way John penned this sentence in its literal form is not lock-tight from a logical perspective, even given th*
                                     *e leeway which Gk. allows in reordering sequences of words. In other words, what John should’ve written is this: <i|So they gathered and filled twelve*
                                     * baskets of scraps that were leftover by those who had eaten out of the five loaves of the barley |i>[<i|bread|i>]. The movement of the clause <i|that*
                                     * were leftover by those who had eaten |i>and the changing of it from active to passive voice (from <i|that they leftover |i>to <i|that were leftover|i*
                                     *>) would’ve had made what he said more logically coherent. Of course, we understand what he meant.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|in no time|i>…Lit: <i|immediately|i>. John again (see previous note from v. 13) loosely constructs the logic of a sentence; in its literal*
                                     * rendering, it appears to the reader that once Jesus boarded the boat, the boat miraculously transported itself in a split-second (as insinuated by th*
                                     *e word <i|immediately|i>)<i| |i>to the destination shore. I doubt if that was the case—rather, it was near the destination in the first place.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|miraculous sign|i>…The Jews were following the guidelines outlined in the OT for vetting a prophet (Exod. 7:9; Deut.13:1–5). As John has s*
                                     *tated in length in earlier parts of his gospel, Jesus did miraculous signs. In fact, the crowd had just chased him down because he’d walked on water. *
                                     *The problem was that that wasn’t good enough—they wanted him to produce a miracle on-demand. This is symptomatic of unbelief, the stubborn refusal to *
                                     *believe.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|I will usher him into an afterlife of bliss on the Day of Reckoning|i>…Lit:<i| I will raise him up |i>[<i|resurrect him|i>]<i| in the Last*
                                     * Day|i>. This is connected to what Jesus said in John 5:29. In 6:39 here, <i|raise him up|i> in Gk. is equivalent to <i|resurrect him|i>, and in the N*
                                     *T resurrection refers to <i|life-after-death|i>. A phrase like the Last Day is similar to other phrases found in the Bible, such as the <i|last days|i*
                                     *> [plural] (Isa. 2:2; Mic. 4:1; Acts 2:17; 2 Tim. 3:1; 2 Pet. 3:3); <i|the last hour|i>; <i|those days|i>; <i|that day|i>; etc. All these phrases in g*
                                     *eneral refer to the time of a fulfillment of a prophecy or a promise of some sort. According to its usage in the NT, we are living in the Last Days. T*
                                     *his means we’re living in the fulfillment of the promises in the OT and in the Gospels of the fulfillment of Jesus’s mission to die and to be resurrec*
                                     *ted and the consequent access to God through faith in him, even for the Gentile; the indwelling of the Holy Spirit in all believers; God working throu*
                                     *gh the church; etc. But the Last Day [singular] refers to the fulfillment of a different promise, that is, what God will do with those who died, in th*
                                     *is case with believers who died trusting in Him. For unbelievers, the Last Day is the Day of Judgment.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|Don’t we know about the father and the mother?|i>…The word <i|about |i>doesn’t appear in the GT, but the insinuation—which is present when*
                                     * carried over into English via a literal rendering—is a result of the GT saying <i|the father and the mother |i>rather than <i|his father and mother|i*
                                     *>, or something. Furthermore, the Judeans just finished Joseph as Jesus’s father, then a few words later refer to him as <i|the father |i>instead of s*
                                     *aying <i|Joseph |i>again. The insinuation is that they have a low opinion about Mary and Joseph. This could be for a few reasons, because Mary and Jos*
                                     *eph don’t live in Judea and aren’t part of the political hierarchy. Or because they’re poor, they’re common laborers. Or perhaps Mary’s virgin birth w*
                                     *as assumed to be an adulterous relationship. But whatever low opinion they had of Mary and Joseph, it could not have been because of their genealogy.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|Would it make any difference if you were to see me ascend into heaven from the spot I was just standing at?…|i>Lit: <i|So then, if you wer*
                                     *e to see the son of man go up from the place he was just at?|i>…This is a best-guess at what Jesus meant; I’m not exactly sure. *

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|the Law of Moses|i>…Lit: <i|Moses|i>. The man Moses is a metonymy for the code of Law he wrote, the Torah, the first five books of the Bib*
                                     *le.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|the patriarchs of old|i>…Lit: <i|the fathers|i>. This refers to Abraham and his heirs. Though circumcision was included in the Law of Mose*
                                     *s, it has an earlier origin and is therefore subject to the covenant where it was introduced. Paul reiterates this point in Gal. 3:17.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|no one’s been able to figure out|i>…Lit: <i|no one knows|i>. John writes the phrase <i|where he’s from |i>three times in short succession:*
                                     * twice in v. 27 and once in v. 28. The word for <i|know |i>(<i|ginōskō|i>, γινώσκω/Strong’s 1097) in this occurrence (<i|has been able to figure out|i*
                                     *>)<i| |i>is a different word for <i|know |i>than what he uses for the other two occurrences (<i|oida|i>, οἶδα/Strong’s 1492). Generally speaking, John*
                                     * prefers <i|oida |i>over <i|ginōskō, |i>so he’s signaling the employment a meaning which differs from <i|oida|i>, and hence <i|ginōskō |i>as used here*
                                     * more accurately means <i|to|i> <i|figure out |i>rather than <i|to know.|i>*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s>Verses 1-11 of this chapter (and John 7:53b, the verse right before) are the story of the woman caught in adultery. For reference, this is tr*
                                     *anslated in the note following. This story indeed is a beautiful illustration of the gospel, and this is the reason why it was spliced into the Gospel*
                                     * of John after John wrote it, as it is a spurious addition: the external evidence (i.e. the manuscript evidence) is overwhelming.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *As far as the internal aspects of this passage (and this is quite subjective), the GT of this passage appears to be more polished than what John write*
                                     *s (John’s text is herky-jerky); this passage is more fluid and therefore easier to translate that what’s found in John’s gospel. Furthermore, John ten*
                                     *ds to shy away from using specific, descriptive words such as v. 4/<i|in the very act |i>(<i|ep autophoros|i>,  ἐπ' αὐτοφώρῳ); vv. 6,7,8,10/<i|crouche*
                                     *d down|i> and <i|stood up|i> (<i|kata kuptō|i>/κάτω κύψας<i| |i>and <i|anakuptō|i>/ἀνακύψας)<i|.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *The fact that Jesus was writing on the ground with his finger is a bit weird. It also begs the question, if Jesus was teaching in the temple, and all *
                                     *the temple flooring is made of stone, then how could he write something with just his finger, seeing that there’s no soil wherewith to form recognizab*
                                     *le letters in?*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s>7:53And each one went home, 8:1and Jesus went to the Mount of Olives. 2He appeared in the temple early in the morning, and all the folk-peopl*
                                     *e began to come to him, and he sat teaching them. 3The Scribes and the Pharisees brought him a woman caught by surprise in adultery, and stood her rig*
                                     *ht in front of everyone. 4They said to him, “Teacher, this here woman was caught in the very act of adultery. 5Now in the Law of Moses it’s commanded *
                                     *that such a person be stoned to death. So what do you have to say?” 6They were saying this to test him, so that they would have something to accuse hi*
                                     *m of. Jesus was crouched down and kept on writing on the ground. 7As they persisted in questioning him, he straightened up and asked them, “Let he who*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|judge|i>…Refers to actual judging in a court of law and judging outside of a court of law, so as to draw conclusions about people so as to*
                                     * write them off. Ref. Matt. 7:1.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|die in your sins|i>…Or: <i|not a chance in hell you’ll succeed|i>; <i|you’ll die trying|i>. This is an expression, and the first time Jesu*
                                     *s uses it (v. 21), he uses it as an expression. When he uses it the other times (v. 24), he means it literally.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|down below…up above|i>…The definition of these as the carnal domain and the spiritual domain respectively is confirmed in Col. 3:1,2,5*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|Do I need to repeat whatever I’ve been saying from day one?|i>…Various translators disagree on what exactly he meant by this fragment. In *
                                     *my opinion, John left out some words that he assumed the reader would understand and fill in. This is common in conversational speech, English include*
                                     *d. In addition, it may be that the text in the UBS Gk. NT, which inserts a space and renders three letters as two words <i|o ti |i>(ὅ τι), (ὅ/Strong’s*
                                     * 3739), (τι/Strong’s 5100)(could instead be rendered with no space in the single word <i|hoti (|i>whatsoever; whatever), which is the nominative singu*
                                     *lar neuter form of <i|hostis |i>(whosoever; ὅστις), (ὅστις/Strong’s 3748).*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|pay any regard|i>…Lit: <i|hear|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|devout|i>…Lit: <i|God-fearing|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|shunned him|i>…Lit: <i|cast him outside|i>. Obviously, from its usage in v. 35, this is an expression. Ref. note of John 15:6.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|the Man|i>…Lit: <i|the Son of Man|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|sticks to you|i>…Lit: <i|remains|i>. Ref. John 6:56.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|We must continue to work doing the works of He who sent me|i>…Or perhaps: <i|The works of He who sent me must continue to be done by us |i*
                                     *>[or <i|among us|i>]. An unusual or incorrect grammatical case for the word <i|we |i>causes this verse to be ambiguous. Some ancient manuscripts were *
                                     *modified in an attempt to resolve the ambiguity (Textus Receptus replaces <i|we |i>with <i|I|i>, for example).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|until we run out of daylight|i>…Lit: <i|until a day is|i>. The phrase <i|until a day is|i> can also be translated, <i|until the day ends.|*
                                     *i> John’s referring to the end of a Jewish day which occurs at sundown. A field worker would normally work—say—ten hours, but quit work early enough s*
                                     *o there was enough time to walk home in the daylight, receive your daily wage (ref. Matt. 20:8), or whatnot. When night arrives, it gets too dark to g*
                                     *et any work done, etc. He would only work in the field until sunset if he had to, like during harvest, when there was too much work and barely enough *
                                     *time to do it. This is what Jesus meant by working until there’s no more daylight—there’s way too much to do and not enough time to do it in (i.e. wor*
                                     *king overtime; crunch time). Jesus uses a similar analogy about daylight in John 11:9,10 also.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|Go on over to the Siloam (translated ‘Sent’) pool and wash yourself off in it|i>…The likely reason why Jesus had him dip in the pool after*
                                     * rubbing the saliva-mud on him is because bodily discharges of any and every sort (spittle included) are specified as unclean in the Law of Moses (ref*
                                     *. Lev. 15, the entire chapter). Lev. 15:5 states that one should wash himself after being in contact with a bodily discharge of any sort; hence Jesus’*
                                     *s instruction for the man to bathe himself. Why Jesus rubbed the saliva-mud on the man’s eyes in the first place is anyone’s guess…*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|This person has doorway access|i>…Lit: <i|the door opens to |i>[i.e., <i|for|i>] <i|him|i>. A personification.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|The thief’s sole purpose in coming is|i>…Lit: <i|The thief doesn’t come except that he would|i>. A figure of speech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|puts his life on the life|i>…<i|I lay my life down|i>…Lit: <i|puts his life|i>…<i|I put my life|i>. This same idiom used in v. 11, 15, 17,*
                                     * 18 have similar, howbeit different, meanings. It is both the decision to risk one’s one life (v. 11, 15) and the loss of one’s life as a consequence *
                                     *of such a decision (v. 17, 18).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|pick it back up again|i>…Lit: <i|take it again|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|directive|i>…Lit: <i|commandment|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|How much longer are you going to leave us in the dark? We’re dying to know|i>…Lit: <i|How much longer are you going to take our life away|*
                                     *i>. An hyperbole.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|the Messiah|i>…Lit: <i|the Christ|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|at the behest of my Father and of by His authority|i>…Lit: <i|in the name of my Father|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|make a statement|i>…Lit: <i|testify|i> or <i|witness|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|the Old Testament|i>…Lit: <i|the Law|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|assuming that|i>…Lit: <i|if|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|the Bible|i>…Lit: <i|the Scripture|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|commissioned|i>…Lit: <i|set apart|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|acquire the understanding and continue in the understanding|i>…Lit: <i|know|i> [aorist subjunctive] <i|and know|i> [present subjunctive]. *
                                     *A figure of speech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|escaped from their clutches|i>…Lit: <i|exited their hands|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|miracle|i>…Lit: <i|sign|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|climbing over the wall|i>…Lit: <i|goes up|i>. In ancient Israel, sheepfolds were enclosed with tall, formidable, stone walls, higher than *
                                     *the average person. These walls were to not only contain the sheep but to prevent predators and thieves from getting in.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|a thief, and not only a thief but a violent, villainous thug of a thief|i>…Lit: <i|a thief and a robber|i>. This is a hendiadys; ref. note*
                                     * of Matt. 3:11. The two Gk. words here for <i|thief |i>and <i|robber |i>are differentiated in a similar fashion to their English renderings. Generally*
                                     * speaking, a thief attempts to avoid confrontation when stealing; a robber, on the other hand, assaults the person or persons whom he steals from. A r*
                                     *obber therefore employs physical harm and violence on a regular basis, and is a much rougher, belligerent, and violent criminal than the ordinary thie*
                                     *f. In this hendiadys, Jesus explains that this thief is not your ordinary thief, but one who commits unwarranted and wanton acts of violence in additi*
                                     *on to his thievery. When Jesus speaks of the thief in v. 10, the thief he refers to is the same one he describes in vv. 1,8. So the thief of v. 10 is *
                                     *a violent destructive thief, not just simply a larcenist.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|came by|i>…Lit: <i|came prior to |i>[or <i|in front of|i>] me. First, <i|in front of me |i>could be rendered <i|prior to me, |i>resulting *
                                     *in, <i|came prior to me. |i>Second, the best manuscripts are split fairly evenly on whether the phrase <i|in front of |i>me/<i|prior to me |i>is spuri*
                                     *ous or not. The Gk. phrase <i|pro emou|i> (πρὸ ἐμοῦ) (πρὸ /Strong’s 4253), (ἐμοῦ/Strong’s 1700) could be rendered <i|in front of me |i>or <i|prior to *
                                     *me|i> (while a face-value reading would prefer <i|prior to me, |i>the more sensible rendering would be <i|in front of me|i>). No matter what’s chosen,*
                                     * the reader is left scratching his head trying to figure out the point that Jesus through John was trying to get across. My guess (and it is very much*
                                     * a guess) is that the phrase is spurious; I have added the word <i|by |i>as a weak guess at an interpolation, which leaves unspecified the time which *
                                     *these thieves came by.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|he will enter and exit through the door and find pasture to graze in|i>…Lit: <i|he will enter and exit and find pasture|i>. Jesus compares*
                                     * himself to a sheep pen door for a couple of verses. The sheep must pass through the door to get into the pen and must pass through the door to get ou*
                                     *t of the pen. While they are in the pen, they are <i|kept safe from harm |i>(also v. 9). While they are out of the pen, they can <i|find pasture, |i>i*
                                     *.e. eat, drink, etc. The sheep must divide their time between the pen and the pasture; they cannot stay in the one or the other for too long a period.*
                                     * Therefore, they are constantly being shuttled into and out of the pen, and must pass through the door—and this door is narrow—each time. If they’re i*
                                     *n the pen for too long, they’ll need to get out; if they’re in the pasture for too long, they’ll need to get in. They must pass through the door in or*
                                     *der to have their needs met, in summary.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|Awesome Shepherd|i>…The Gk. word behind <i|Awesome |i>is <i|kalōs |i>(καλῶς /Strong’s 2773) and not <i|agathos |i>(ἀγαθός/Strong’s 18). <i*
                                     *|Kalos|i> describes something which is beautiful on the outside; in this context, it speaks of something which is beautiful because it does what it’s *
                                     *supposed to do so well. Applied to being a shepherd, it describes an utra-competent, excellent, diligent, hard-working shepherd, one who excels at wha*
                                     *t a shepherd is supposed to do. A <i|kalos |i>shepherd is one that others, who by viewing his actions, confirm that he’s excellent at being a shepherd*
                                     *—to the point of being beautiful—at his job. <i|Kalos |i>describes excellence by viewing what’s on the inside of a person, his actions, and does not d*
                                     *escribe (not necessarily) what’s on the inside, the attitudes of the heart, etc. On the other hand, <i|Agathos|i> describes someone who’s good on the *
                                     *inside. Choosing to describe Jesus as the <i|Kalos|i> Shepherd rather than the <i|Agathos|i> Shepherd doesn’t mean he’s not good on the inside, it sim*
                                     *ply means that the emphasis is on Jesus’s competency as a shepherd.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *Furthermore, the term <i|Awesome Shepherd|i> is rendered in English as capitalized because of the use of the Gk. attributive adjective here.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|don’t frequent this|i> <i|sheep pen compound|i>…Lit: <i|out of this|i> <i|courtyard|i>. The definition of the Gk. word for <i|courtyard |i*
                                     *>is a courtyard enclosed by a house around its perimeter. In this verse, instead of a house, the perimeter of the courtyard is the stone wall of the s*
                                     *heep pen; the courtyard is the pen itself. Jesus is saying that there are other sheep out there which he owns. The sheep in the pen comprise the natio*
                                     *n of Israel; those other sheep are the Gentile nations.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|edited out|i>…Lit: <i|broken |i>[primary word <i|loosed|i>]; Gk. <i|luo |i>(λύω/Strong’s 3089)<i|. |i>The word <i|kataluo |i>(καταλύω/Stro*
                                     *ng’s 2647)<i|, |i>derived from <i|luo|i>, is used in Luke 21:6 to describe the destruction of the temple by the disassembling of its stones. The templ*
                                     *e was comprised of tightly-fitting stones; its destruction consisted of tearing these stones apart and casting them aside, completely out of place; th*
                                     *e use of the word <i|kataluo |i>describes this, with the prefix <i|kata |i>meaning <i|to the ultimate extent. |i>Therefore, a meaning of <i|luo |i>is *
                                     *to tear something out of its tightly-fitting location within a larger structure and casting it aside. This is what John means by his use of <i|luo |i>*
                                     *in this verse: removing a single verse from the Bible as though you were tearing a carefully-placed stone out of larger structure.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|poured oil over the Lord|i>…Lit: <i|anointed the Lord in oil|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|twin|i>…Lit: <i|Didymus|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|1 ¾ miles/2.7km|i>…Lit: <i|15 stadia|i>. Ref. note of Luke 24:13*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|the Day of Reckoning|i>…Lit: <i|the Last Day|i>. Ref. John 6:39.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|groaned deeply|i>…Same Gk. word used in Mark 1:43; ref. note there.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|come out|i>…In the Gk. text, the polite form of <i|come |i>is used.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|miracles|i>…Lit: <i|signs|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|because the objects in this world are illuminated by the daylight, and he sees them|i>…Lit: <i|he sees the light of this world|i>. The Gk.*
                                     * word for <i|light|i> is not quite the same as the English word <i|light|i>. In addition to its core meaning, light also means the images of objects a*
                                     *s seen by the eye when they are illuminated by a light source. This is way it’s used here in vv. 9,10. This is usage also applies, although to a lesse*
                                     *r degree, to Matt. 6:22,23.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|because nothing’s illuminated|i>…Jesus is referring to the daylight analogy that he spoke about in 9:4,5, and assumes the disciples rememb*
                                     *er the point he made then. His point is that you have to strike while the iron is hot. There are just a finite number of instance where God performed *
                                     *spectacular miracles like raising Lazarus from the dead, and Jesus had to act swiftly and decisively to ensure that they took place.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|Let’s go too so that we get to die with him too|i>…Thomas is being sarcastic, thinking that if they go to Bethany, which is near Jerusalem*
                                     *, those who are trying to stone Jesus to death will catch them and have them all killed. Thomas sees no sense in risking a visit to a dead man, and it*
                                     * doesn’t occur to him that Jesus is going to raise him from the dead.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|fair citizens of that glorious land over the rainbow|i>…Lit: <i|Zion-daughter|i>. Some liberties taken. The word <i|daughter |i>is a synec*
                                     *doche of all those who belong to Zion, with the implication that the daughters are those who love it and never want to depart from it. Zion is the eth*
                                     *ereal, uncorrupted land that God promises Israel, and not just land but the state of living. It is the fulfillment of His promises; it is the eliminat*
                                     *ion of the shortcomings of what is achievable in this life; it is the existence to come for those who love and follow God.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|the world’s gone chasing after him to be his follower|i>…Or perhaps: <i|the world’s left to be his disciples, to be in subjection to him|i*
                                     *>…Lit: <i|the world’s departed behind him|i>. The expression <i|behind him/go behind him |i>is used in Matt. 4:19 to mean <i|be my disciple, |i>and is*
                                     * used in Matt. 16:23 to mean <i|be in subjection to.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|Greek-speaking Jews|i>…Lit: <i|Greeks|i>. Assumed that these are the same people as the <i|diaspora of the Greeks|i> referred to in John 7*
                                     *:35. Some, however, argue that these people are <i|God-fearers |i>(ref. Acts 13:16):<i| |i>Gentiles who adhered to Jewish practices buy hadn’t convert*
                                     *ed to Judaism per-se. Whether Greek-speaking Jews or God-fearers, they are likely one or the other and not Gentiles (the word used here could also be *
                                     *rendered <i|Gentiles|i>), since Jews wouldn’t have any interactions with Gentiles, especially during a festival.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|enjoys|i>…Gk: <i|phileō |i>(φιλέω/Strong’s 5368). <i|Philos|i> is typically rendered <i|love|i>, but is not to be confused with <i|agapā |*
                                     *i>(ἀγάπη/Strong’s 26), which is also rendered <i|love|i>. The philos-kind of love is the love of another person, or in this verse of another thing, fo*
                                     *r the friendship, comradery, and enjoyment that one receives from such association; agapā<i| |i>is the love of another because one treasures that othe*
                                     *r person.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|honor him, including providing his financial support|i>…Lit: <i|honor him|i>. The Gk. word for honor means both to honor as the face-value*
                                     * of the word means and to provide financial support. Ref. Matt. 15:3–6, 1 Tim. 5:17–18.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|hoisted up|i>…The Gk. word also means <i|exalted |i>and also means <i|killed|i>. The verse has multiple meanings, based on the Gk. word ha*
                                     *ving multiple meanings. On the one hand, Jesus will be hoisted off the ground by being put on a cross. Another meaning is that he’ll be killed, just a*
                                     *s the same Gk. word is used to mean <i|killed|i> in Acts 7:28. On the other hand, Jesus will be exalted, lifted up as a spectacle for everyone to see,*
                                     * but afterwards exalted above every name (ref. Phil. 2:9).*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|placed all matters under his control|i>…Lit: <i|given all things to him into the hands|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|can’t be a part of my inner-circle|i>…Lit: <i|you don’t have a portion with me|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|sat back down at the table|i>…Lit: <i|reclined|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|emissary|i>…Lit: <i|apostle|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|I am the One-and-Only-One…|i>Lit:<i| I am|i>…Ref. note of Mark 13:6*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|went on record|i>…Lit: <i|testified|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|a small slice|i>…Lit: <i|a morsel|i>; <i|a hunk|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|the Man|i>…Lit: <i|the Son of Man|i>. Ref. note of Matt 8:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s>Some of the early manuscripts here insert the phrase, <i|If God has been glorified in him|i>, but the better manuscripts do not, so it has be*
                                     *en omitted.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|fellas|i>…Or: <i|boys|i>. Lit: <i|children|i>. Similar to usage in John 21:5.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|directive|i>…Also: <i|commandment|i>. Ref. usage in John 10:18.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|put my life on the line|i>…Or: <i|lay my life down|i>. Same phrase used in John 10:11,17.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|clean|i>…The word <i|clean |i>here has two meanings. First, the obvious meaning, the one based on the context: physically clean from a bat*
                                     *h with water. Second, the word <i|clean |i>here means <i|pure |i>or <i|holy.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|He who dines with me in a fellowship setting|i> …Lit: <i|he who munches on my bread|i>. The eating of bread here symbolizes the bond of fe*
                                     *llowship and unity between those who partake of it together. This makes the Judas’s betrayal all the more wicked.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|One of his disciples, whom Jesus loved and loved, was seated next to him, and since he was a close companion was in physical contact with *
                                     *him, leaning against him|i>…Lit: <i|He was reclining, one of his disciples, in Jesus’s bosom, whom Jesus was loving|i>. Liberties taken here; also in *
                                     *vv. 12, 25. The disciples were reclined, not sitting (ref. note of Luke 16:22). It’s likely that John was propped up on his arm (hand on side of head,*
                                     * elbow on the couch); in v. 25 the Gk. text literally says that he <i|fell back |i>[<i|leaned back|i>] <i|at Jesus’s bosom|i>. One can deduce that he *
                                     *took away his arm-prop, laid down completely, and leaned back. This change in position caused his head to be in contact with Jesus’s bosom, specifical*
                                     *ly his stomach and chest. He leaned back so that his head would be in close proximity to Jesus’s head, so that he could speak a few words with him tha*
                                     *t no one else could hear.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|Satan entered into|i>…Though speculation, it may be that Jesus placed the morsel of bread directly into Judas’s mouth, similar to how a br*
                                     *ide and a groom put wedding cake into each other’s mouth—a similar type of symbolism. It may be that John is implying that, just as the bread was phys*
                                     *ically placed into Judas’s mouth and entered his body, on a parallel level Satan entered Judas’s heart.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|I’m giving you a brand-new directive, that you would love one another|i>…Lit: <i|I’m giving you a brand new commandment, so that you would*
                                     * love one another|i>. The wording is a figure of speech: instead of stating the commandment, the end-result of the commandment is stated instead; the *
                                     *commandment is insinuated.*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|have faith|i>…Also: <i|believe|i>; <i|trust|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|on my Father’s estate|i>…Also: <i|in my Father’s house|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|collect you and keep you by my side|i>…Lit: <i|receive you to myself|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|does His stuff|i>…Lit: <i|does His works|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|that person will do the same—better even|i>…Lit: <i|that|i> [<i|person|i>] <i|will do and greater than these will do.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|acting in my delegated authority|i>…<i|upon my authorization|i>…Lit: <i|in my name|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|by means of|i>…Or: <i|in|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|If you’re set on loving me|i>…Lit: <i|if you were to love me|i>. The subjunctive verb form is of someone who’s faced with a choice of doin*
                                     *g something or not doing it.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|I will not have|i>…Lit: <i|I will not|i> [Gk. <i|ou |i>(οὐ/Strong’s 3756 )]. The Gk. word <i|ou |i>is unexpected, whereas the word <i|ma |*
                                     *i>is expected here, skewing the meaning.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|don’t let your heart be troubled|i>…The same exact wording as used in v. 1.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|he can accuse me of nothing, tempt me with nothing, or intimidate me in any way|i>…Lit: <i|he has nothing in me|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|And if I manage to prepare a place for you—and I will|i>…Lit: <i|If I were to prepare a place for you|i>. The tentativeness of the subjunc*
                                     *tive verb tense used in the GT is a figure of speech. But what is actually meant is arduousness. In order for Jesus to prepare a place, he must first *
                                     *endure the cross, and only then afterwards, being resurrected and ascending to the Father, can he prepare a place. He having to go to the cross is not*
                                     * tentative but arduous; hence the figure of speech. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|Let me repeat—If you were to ask me to do something while acting in my delegated authority, I will do it|i>…Lit: <i|If you were to ask me *
                                     *something in my name, I will do|i>. Obvious to the reader of the GT, v. 14 is a repetition of v. 13a. The difference between the wording in these two *
                                     *verses is that v. 13 is a more compact repetition, omitting a few words with the confidence that the reader will understand that they were omitted for*
                                     * brevity. Therefore, the repetition of the statement is a figure of speech, one where Jesus wants to be clear about what he’s saying and to emphasize *
                                     *it.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|I’ll ask the Father to give you a helper of a different kind|i>…Lit: <i|I’ll ask the Father|i> [<i|to give you another helper|i>] <i|and H*
                                     *e will give you another helper|i>. The Gk. text omits the phrase <i|to give you another helper|i>, with the wording shortened to <i|I’ll ask the Fathe*
                                     *r and He will give you another helper. |i>This short form is a figure of speech.*
SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER

VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|1|s><r|”I am the True |r><ir|Grape |ir><r|Vine, and my Father is the gardener. |r><s|2|s><r|He removes all branches that are attached to me that do*
                                     *n’t produce|r><s|[A]|s><r| any grapes|r><s|[a]|s><r|, but He prunes all|r><ir| branches |ir><r|which produce grapes and trims off their dead growth so*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|grapes|i>…Lit: <i|fruit|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|system of thought|i>…Lit: <i|the word|i>. Same thing spoken in John 14:23,24.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|stay attached to|i>…Lit: <i|remain|i> or <i|dwell|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|you’re the branch|i>…Lit: <i|you all are the branches|i>. The gospel writers frequently use plurals forms when we in English would render *
                                     *the equivalent using the singular.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|making the request once|i>…This interpolation reflects the verb tense of the word<i| ask |i>in this verse.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|My Father was glorified to see to it that you continuously yield a lot of fruit and that you would achieve the status of being my disciple*
                                     *s|i>…Lit: <i|In this my Father was glorified, so that you would |i>[<i|over and over again|i>] <i|bear much fruit and|i> [<i|in a single leap|i>] <i|b*
                                     *ecome my disciples|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|on the whole|i>…the Gk. verb tense for the word <i|keep |i>insinuates keeping the commandments viewed in its entirety.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|put his life on the line|i>…Or: <i|lay his life down|i>. Ref. note of John 10:11.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|set you up|i>…Or: <i|positioned|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|while acting in my delegated authority|i>…Lit: <i|in my name|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|a part of|i>…Lit: <i|out of|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|reputation and the authority I’ve delegated to you|i>…Lit: <i|my name|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|be in sin|i>…Lit: <i|have sin|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|sacred book|i>…Lit: <i|Law|i> [<i|of Moses|i>]*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|Helper|i>…Also: <i|Advocate|i>, <i|Comforter|i>, <i|Intercessor|i>. Same word used in John 14:16. The Gk. word refers to someone who, nowa*
                                     *days, fills the role of an attorney.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|proceeds forth|i>…Lit<i|: goes out|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|He removes all branches that are attached to me that don’t produce|i>…The meaning of this remark should be understood in light of what Jes*
                                     *us said in Matt. 3:10, 7:19, and also later in John 15:6; in other words, branches that don’t produce fruit are unbelievers: those who are presented w*
                                     *ith Jesus’s message but refuse to believe. It is not the believer who makes mistake after mistake.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|discarded|i>…Lit: <i|thrown outside|i>. This expression (the keyword in the expression being <i|outside|i>) appears in Matt. 5:13, 13:48, *
                                     *21:39; Mark 4:11, 12:8; Luke 14:35, 20:15; John 6:37, 9:34 (and perhaps more) and has the consistent meaning of <i|categorically rejected |i>in all th*
                                     *ese occurrences.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|If I had not done the miraculous works among them that no one else ever did, they wouldn’t be in sin|i>…This is consistent with what’s fou*
                                     *nd in Mark 3:29, namely blaspheming the Holy Spirit. The rejection of an irrefutable display of God’s miraculous power is a deep sin.*

                                     *g|i>. A figure of speech of a sort, to forget about the previous remark because the next one is so much more severe.*

                                     *hey scrub themselves with soap and water.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|every imaginable being|i>…Lit: <i|all flesh|i>. An expression and figure of speech used throughout the Bible.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|Your reputation and everything you stand for|i>…Lit: <i|your Name|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|system of thought|i>…Lit: <i|the word|i>. Same thing spoken in John 14:23,24.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|whole-heartedly took it all in|i>…Lit: <i|received|i>*

                                     *iters are called garcon (boy).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|anything that’s edible|i>—<i|namely fish|i>…The Gk. word here for <i|edible |i>occurs once in the NT and the lexicon is sparse on detail. *
                                     *The word is derived from <i|food|i>, and I’m guessing the prefix changes its meaning to <i|ready-to-eat. |i>The Gk. experts say that the word means <i*
                                     *|fish|i>, but they probably deduce this from the context.*

                                     *name, plus the middle and last names (for example: <i|William Patrick Smith|i> instead of just <i|Bill|i>).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|you will stretch your hands out and another will get you ready|i> [Lit: <i|gird you|i>] <i|and will carry you where you don’t want to go|i*
                                     *>…Church tradition says that Peter was crucified in his old age, and that this statement refers to his crucifixion. <i|Stretching your hands out |i>re*
                                     *fers to Peter stretching his hands out to have them nailed to a cross, and <i|carry you where you don’t want to go |i>refers to taking the cross and p*
                                     *osting it in the ground.*

HEADING1                             *Acts*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Luke writes another long treatise for Theophilus, who may have been his former master, a sequel to his Gospel. He picks up the story as he left off in*
                                     * his Gospel, and by the time he reaches Acts 16:10 the narrative switches from <i|they |i>to <i|we|i>, as Luke joins Paul on his journeys.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *The book is named Acts of the Apostles, but it might be better named Acts of the Early Church.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Luke at times will break into long sentences, like Acts 2:30,31. Of course, this long sentence is a quotation from Peter, and in that passage Luke cap*
                                     *tures a side of Peter which is unseen in the Gospels. In that spontaneous oration of Acts 2—which is one of the high points of the entire book—Peter f*
                                     *ollows a train of thought through a few quotations from the Old Testament with remarkable clarity and agility, to the point that even his opponents ma*
                                     *rveled at his newly-found rhetorical abilities (Acts 4:13). These came from the Holy Spirit which came upon him on Pentecost.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *More so than the other Gospel writers, Luke’s command of Greek allows him to pepper the text with a word here or there, broadening the meaning with nu*
                                     *anced implications, some of which take an entire half-sentence to convey to the English reader. An example this is in Luke 2:39, where he adds an addi*
                                     *tional word (<i|and|i>).*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Luke has a knack for finding imaginative metaphors. For example, in Acts 1:17 he compares Judas’s misfortune of being the one who betrays Jesus to som*
                                     *eone who casts lots and loses. In Acts 2:1, the counting of days until Pentecost uses a term commonly used by ship captains as they fill their quota o*
                                     *f cargo or tackle or whatnot before setting sail. In Acts 9:1, Paul is “still huffing [lit: breathing] murderous threats at the Lord’s disciples.” Int*
                                     *erspersing hyperbole with metaphor, Acts 17:21 says, “Now all Athenians and foreigners who reside in Athens have no time for anything other than talki*
                                     *ng about or hearing about something novel.”*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Luke quietly introduces Paul (Saul)—who after Jesus is the most influential figure in Christianity—in Acts 7:58 by showing him in the backdrop of the *
                                     *stoning of Stephen, letting the circumstances describe who Paul was rather than a description itself. Luke uses this introduction to transition from S*
                                     *tephen’s stoning at the end of the seventh chapter into Paul’s zealous persecution at the beginning of the eighth, eventually culminating in Saul’s co*
                                     *nversion. In his deft use of indirection, in Acts 12:18, instead of directly saying “…a lot of commotion took place..,” he says instead, “When dayligh*
                                     *t came, no small amount of commotion took place among the soldiers.”*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *An additional benefit gleaned from Luke’s narrative here is that it sheds light on expressions and idioms used throughout the NT. There are several oc*
                                     *currences of the expression “name of Jesus” where a character is doing this or that in the name of Jesus. The student of the Bible deduces the underly*
                                     *ing meaning of the name of Jesus by its preponderance in Acts. Another example is “enter God’s kingdom” (Acts 14:22): the context of this verse indica*
                                     *tes that this is an idiom, and one should keep that in mind when Jesus says how difficult it is for a rich man to enter God’s kingdom.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *In the earlier chapters of Acts, much of the dialog and wording sheds light on certain NT concepts. The fourth chapter specifies what the name of Jesu*
                                     *s is; in Acts 4:9, we have captured in writing an incident of testing the Lord, and this expanded understanding of what it is to test the Lord sheds l*
                                     *ight on other NT verses, in this case for example, Matt. 4:7, 1 Cor. 10:9.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *To top it off, a pattern emerges in the story line, and it goes like this: a miracle occurs, the miracles draws the undivided attention of those who w*
                                     *itness it, as their attention is captured, the message of the Gospel is delivered, and those who hear it are converted. Treats like that are found by *
                                     *those who look for them.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|got himself in a head-first direction and|i> <i|killed himself in such a way that his torso ruptured…|i>Lit: <i|became head-first and burs*
                                     *t |i>[<i|the|i>]<i| middle|i>. The verb form for <i|head-first|i> (πρηνής/Strong’s 4248) from verb <i|pranizō|i>/no Strong’s number) means to throw on*
                                     *eself head-first or to fall headlong, so other translations say that he dove head-first and that the impact of the fall caused his body to split open *
                                     *and his intestines to come out. But the word <i|head-first |i>also refers to the prone position, so the phrase <i|became head-first |i>could mean <i|b*
                                     *ecame prone |i>instead. There’s not enough content and enough clarity to conclude with certainty that he dove head-first off a high cliff or off some *
                                     *other precipice—not to mention the practicalities of what that entails. Suffice to say that there remains ambiguity and uncertainty of what exactly Lu*
                                     *ke was talking about in this verse. *
