FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|on the same page|i>…Lit: <i|upon the same|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|being swept in|i>…Lit: <i|being carried|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|across the globe|i>…Lit: <i|under the sky|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|What in the world’s going on?|i>…Lit: <i|What does this want to be?|i> Likely an idiom.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|call for the Lord to act on his behalf in the way He is reputed to act|i>…Lit: <i|call upon the name of the Lord|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|spared calamity|i>…Lit: <i|will be saved|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|In the area I was most concerned about|i>…Lit: <i|before me|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|He is right where I need Him|i>…Lit: <i|he is out of my right hand|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|I rejoiced in heart and uttered exultations, and, what’s more, my physical well-being will occupy the spot where hope exists|i>…Lit: <i|my*
                                     * heart rejoiced and my tongue exulted and what’s more my flesh will dwell at hope|i>. A mixed figure of speech, a mixture of synecdoche and personific*
                                     *ation. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|the essence of my life-being in the graveyard|i>…Lit: <i|my soul to Hades|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|with your undivided attention|i>…Lit: <i|with your face|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|Men, Judeans|i>…<i|Men, Israelites|i>…<i|Men, comrades|i>…Ref. note of Acts. 1:11.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|promoted him to the position of God’s Chief Executive|i>…Lit: <i|having been exalted to the right hand of God|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|Assume the role of being My right-hand man until such time I choose to subjugate your enemies in obeisance to you|i>…Lit: <i|sit at My rig*
                                     *ht|i> [<i|hand|i>] <i|until I would place your enemies under your feet|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|Israeli ethnicity-nation|i>…Lit: <i|house Israel|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|it caused their hearts to melt|i>…Lit: <i|they were pierced the heart|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|Have a change of heart and of ways|i>…Lit: <i|repent|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[r]|s><i|by the authority of|i>…Lit: <i|upon the name of|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[s]|s><i|escape|i>…Lit: <i|be saved|i>. The rendering of the Gk. word <i|save |i>or <i|saved |i>is context-specific. This rendering is the same as *
                                     *that of Matt. 19:25.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[t]|s><i|contemporary Zeitgeist|i>…Lit: <i|generation|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[u]|s><i|took to heart and acted upon|i>…Lit: <i|received|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[v]|s><i|fellowship-dinners together, dinners culminating in a communion memorial|i>…Lit: <i|the Breaking-of-the-Bread-Fellowship|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[w]|s><i|properties and possessions kept on being sold|i>…Lit: <i|properties and possessions kept on selling|i>. The GT uses the active voice inste*
                                     *ad of the passive, perhaps an expression similar to what we use in English.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|When all the days had been checked off until fifty were reached|i>…Lit: <i|in the day of the fifty filling-together|i>. The Gk. word for <*
                                     *i|filling-together |i>refers to manning a ship with a full complement of sailors. In other words, <i|filling-together |i>is a metaphor which compares *
                                     *the counting of the days until fifty is reached to a ship captain who desires to set sail but needs a nominal number of sailors, and sailors with a li*
                                     *st of essential skills. The captain cannot depart until he fills out his quota, so he searches the harbor looking to recruit sailors needed to staff h*
                                     *is ship. He sets sail immediately once the quota has been filled.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|sweet wine|i>…This is a young, sweet wine, the wine known as <i|must|i>. It’s likely a wine that’s drunk undiluted, a wine which has a hig*
                                     *her alcohol content, is less expensive, or both: the beverage-of-choice when the goal of is to get drunk as easily and as cheaply as possible.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|it is just as much given to the one as to the other|i>…This phrase is not an interpolation but is justified by the insertion of the word <*
                                     *i|and |i>before the word <i|children|i>, an <i|and |i>which is in addition the <i|and |i>between <i|children |i>and <i|everyone who’s far away. |i>In *
                                     *v. 39 here, Luke says that the promise is for those closest to you and that you have the closest human bonds to—your children—and for those who are fu*
                                     *rthest from you geographically and for whom you have no human bond whatsoever. The point he’s making (and he clears this up immediately after) is that*
                                     * if the promise is for both extremes relationally and physically, then certainly it is for everyone else.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|stating|i>…Lit: <i|witnessing|i>. The Gk. word <i|witness |i>is used throughout Acts, John’s Gospel and his epistles, and elsewhere in the*
                                     * NT. This usage in v. 40 here is about as good a definition of what is meant by witnessing as can be found anywhere in the NT. First, begin with an un*
                                     *derstanding of the usage of <i|witness |i>in the OT, which is a person testifying in a court of law. After that, study the context of v. 40 here, and *
                                     *the definition of <i|witnessing |i>becomes apparent. Apply this understanding to other places in the NT where <i|witness |i>is used (Acts 1:8 for exam*
                                     *ple).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|distributed to every person according to whoever happened to have a need|i>…Some have said that this (and Acts 4:35) rings of Karl Marx’s *
                                     *quotation, “From each according to his ability, to each according to his need.” Keep in mind the following, however. First, Luke states this as a fact*
                                     * and does not say that it was a command, confirmed by what Peter said in Acts 5:4. Second, the apostles were convinced that Jesus would return to eart*
                                     *h any day now—certainly no more than a few weeks hence—so what’s the use of owning property? Third, Acts 8:1 said that there was a great persecution a*
                                     *gainst the church in Jerusalem. In such a persecution, those persecuted would surely have had their property confiscated, so they might’ve anticipated*
                                     * this and sold what they owned preemptively. Fourth, not everyone sold what they owned; otherwise they wouldn’t have been able to meet from house to h*
                                     *ouse (v. 46), as there wouldn’t have been any houses to meet at. Fifth, this was an extraordinary period of revival, and extraordinary things happen i*
                                     *n extraordinary revivals, things that don’t otherwise happen.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|I don’t have any cash on me|i>…Lit: <i|silver and gold I don’t possess with me|i>. This sounds like an expression, as one would expect Pet*
                                     *er to say he has no silver, as the word silver itself is a synonym for money. Furthermore, one doesn’t usually give a gold coin to a beggar.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|security and protection for our natural and spiritual lives|i>…Lit: <i|salvation. |i>Also see Luke 1:69*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|person of impeccable reputation and of authority|i> …Lit: <i|name|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|among the breadth of the varieties of peoples everywhere|i>…Lit: <i|under the sky|i>. An expression, one similar to the expression <i|unde*
                                     *r the sun, |i>found in Ecclesiastes 1:9.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|that the human race has ever produced and put forward as a candidate of such|i>…Lit: <i|that has been given in men|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|rescued from our deplorable spiritual, mental, and physical condition|i>…Lit: <i|saved|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|recognizable miracle|i>…Lit: <i|known|i> [or <i|recognizable|i>] <i|sign|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|using this authority as the basis for their speaking|i>…<i|acting on the basis of Jesus’s authority|i>…<i|through the authority placed in|*
                                     *i>…Lit: <i|upon this name|i>…<i|upon the name of Jesus|i>…<i|through the name of|i>. Ref. notes of vv. 7,10.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|not to teach—not even to utter a peep|i>…Lit: <i|neither to utter|i> [<i|a word|i>] <i|nor to speak|i>. A figure of speech, a hendiadys of*
                                     * a sort.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|their own particular group of people|i>…Lit: <i|their own|i>. An expression; also used in John 1:11.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|servant|i>…Or: <i|boy|i>. Ref. Acts 3:13.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|insolent|i>…In regard to the usage of this word, quoting Max & Mary: “properly of prancing and whinnying of high-spirited horses”*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|You singled out to be specially chosen and to be given special, supernatural abilities|i>…Lit: <i|anointed|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|situational control|i>…Lit: <i|hand|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|You supernaturally intervene|i>…Lit: <i|extend Your hand|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[r]|s><i|account|i>…Lit: <i|witness|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[s]|s><i|to the apostles, placing the proceeds under their care and ownership|i>…Lit: <i|putting|i> [<i|it|i>] <i|near the feet of the apostles|i>.*
                                     * A NT idiom, one which is a variation of the expression found in Eph. 1:22.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[t]|s><i|the epitome of one who fills the role of|i>…Lit: <i|son of|i>. Expression used throughout the Bible. Also, ref. note of Matt. 8:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[u]|s><i|clergyman|i>…Lit: <i|Levite|i>. Some liberties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|who authorized you to do this in their agency|i>…Lit: <i|in what name you did this|i>. The phrase <i|in his name |i>or something akin to i*
                                     *t is used throughout the NT, and this occurrence here in vv. 7 and 9 provide one of the best examples of what the phrase means. To do something in the*
                                     * name of someone else means one or several of the following: To do something at one’s bidding or command; to do something as one authorized by another*
                                     *, using delegated authority which the other grants; to acquire the right to do something that one naturally has no right to do, only because of the re*
                                     *putation or authority of the one whose name is invoked. Related to <i|in his name|i>, ref. notes of Matt. 21:9; Mark 9:41; Mark 16:17; Rom. 2:24.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|distributed to each person in proportion to what a given person happened to need|i>…Ref. note of Acts 2:35*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|assistant, advocate, counselor, and encourager|i>…The well-known Gk. word <i|paraklātos |i>(παράκλητος/Strong’s 3875) is used here, and th*
                                     *e word has several meanings. The specific meaning of <i|paraklātos |i>which best applies to Barnabas, however, can be discovered by studying what Barn*
                                     *abas did through the Book of Acts (Acts 11:23–26, for example) and drawing conclusions based on that. Barnabas assisted Paul in his missionary journey*
                                     *s, but also advocated for Mark, thereby causing a dispute between him and Paul. In the end, though, Barnabas’s judge of Mark’s character was vindicate*
                                     *d by Mark’s maturity.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|While you still had it, wasn’t it yours to keep|i>…Lit: <i|a remaining to you kept remaining|i> [Gk: <i|menon soi emenen |i>(μένον σοὶ ἔμε*
                                     *νεν), (μένον/Strong’s 3306), (σοὶ/Strong’s 4771), (ἔμενεν/Strong’s 3306)]. In the GT, the terse wording of the phrase, the repetition of the verb <i|m*
                                     *enō, |i>and the fact that this is a quotation of someone speaking and is not narrative leads to the conclusion that this is an expression, and therefo*
                                     *re has a meaning beyond the face-value word-for-word transliteration. The bottom line is that an equivalent English expression for this Gk. expression*
                                     * would be, “what’s yours is yours.”*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|to try to pull a fast one on|i>…Lit: <i|to test|i>; <i|to tempt|i>. The context of the usage of the Gk. word <i|peiradzō |i>(πειράζω/Stron*
                                     *g’s 3958) used here in v. 9 sheds light on the meaning of this multi-faceted word, aiding in one’s understanding of how it’s used in other passages, M*
                                     *att. 4:7, 1 Cor. 10:9 for example.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|Take a look at the feet|i>…Of course, Peter meant <i|take a look at the young men |i>instead. The word <i|feet |i>is a synecdoche for the *
                                     *young men themselves. Throughout the Bible, the word <i|feet |i>is symbolic of what a person does at a high-level, or the things a person does which a*
                                     *re more involved than simple actions. The word <i|hand |i>is for simple actions, but <i|feet |i>is symbolic of something which requires a sequence of *
                                     *actions to complete. In this verse here, Peter’s synecdoche indicates what the young men are about to do. Of particular interest is how deeply rooted *
                                     *such figures of speech were in the Israelis of that time, that they were used in impromptu, conversational speech such as this. We can assume that Jes*
                                     *us talked the same way; passages such as Matt. 18:8, though they sound out of place to the modern ear, were commonplace remarks for the time and place*
                                     *. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|at the door|i>…One possible reason that those who carried off Ananias where standing at the doorway instead of being in the building could*
                                     * be because, having handled a dead body, they were unclean according to Jewish purity law and therefore were banned from rejoining the others.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|peer down and check in on any one of them|i>…Lit: <i|the shadow would cast a shadow on|i> [or <i|overshadow|i>] <i|any one of them|i>. Not*
                                     * absolutely certain, but this appears to be an idiom/expression. This phrase paints a picture of someone sitting or lying on the ground when the sun’s*
                                     * shining, and someone else walks up to this person stands near them in such a way as to block the sun. Sometimes movies, especially Westerns, have sce*
                                     *nes like this where a stronger person approaches a weaker person and blocks the sun when close. The weaker person squints up until when the stronger p*
                                     *erson is close, and he no longer needs to squint because of the shadow provided by the stronger person. The stronger person has come by to have an enc*
                                     *ounter of some sort with the weaker person—in this case, for Peter the stronger, the one standing, to heal the weaker one, who’s sitting or lying due *
                                     *to his weakness.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|an angel|i>…Lit: <i|an angel of the Lord|i>. At times the NT uses the phrase <i|angel of the Lord|i> instead of simply <i|angel|i> (Luke 2*
                                     *:9 for example) to clarify any ambiguity as to the meaning of <i|angel|i>, specifying the angelic being as opposed to a human being. Since the word <i*
                                     *|angel |i>is rendered a couple different ways into English, once in English there’s no need to retain the words <i|of the Lord |i>as the ambiguity has*
                                     * been stripped. Also, ref. usage in Rev. 1:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|having hung him on a wooden cross-beam|i>…A figure of speech—a synecdoche—where instead of using the obvious words <i|crucify, cross, |i>e*
                                     *tc.<i|, |i>which the listener normally hears used, the act of crucifixion is described in more detailed, graphical terms. To illustrate by analogy, if*
                                     * we were to describe someone being executed by electrocution in the following way: “We shaved his head, strapped him in a chair, put electrodes on his*
                                     * head and legs, and jolted him with electricity,” instead of simply saying, “We electrocuted him,” which every listener would understand. The point of*
                                     * such figures of speech is to illustrate how barbaric the act was, as the well-known words, being overly used, desensitizes one to the reality of what*
                                     * was perpetrated. *

                                     *hyperbole than a completely accurate description of what the apostles were doing.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|widows|i>…Widows were the poorest in society, since they had no one to care for them and no way to earn a substantial living. Ref. note of*
                                     * Mark 12:40.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|spirit|i>…In this context, the word <i|spirit|i> means <i|deeply-rooted fervor, dedication, etc|i>. It is listed as a personal quality jus*
                                     *t as <i|wisdom |i>is listed as such<i|. |i>It does not mean <i|Holy Spirit, |i>in spite of other translations rendering this <i|the Spirit|i>, short f*
                                     *or <i|the Holy Spirit|i>. In the Bible the word <i|spirit |i>has multiple meanings; sometimes it means <i|Holy Spirit|i>, sometimes it means a person’*
                                     *s spirit, sometimes it refers to a deeply-rooted disposition of one sort or another (example of that is 2 Tim. 1:7). The NT writers understood the pot*
                                     *ential for ambiguity, and if, when writing, they were referring to the Holy Spirit, they added qualifiers to the word <i|spirit |i>where ambiguity mig*
                                     *ht exist. (Or they added qualifiers for emphasis.) The qualifiers consist of adding an article, adding the word <i|Holy|i>, or<i| |i>forming a full pr*
                                     *edicative construct. So in v. 5, such a qualifier is added, as Stephen is <i|full of the Holy Spirit|i>, not <i|full of spirit|i>. But the usage in v.*
                                     * 3 has no qualifiers, is paired with another personal quality <i|wisdom|i>, so therefore does not refer to the Holy Spirit.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|put in charge of this matter|i>…This key phrase indicates why the seven—the first church deacons—had to be filled with spirit and wisdom i*
                                     *n order to do their job. They were put in charge of the food distribution in order to ensure that it was being done fairly, that widows were not being*
                                     * overlooked because of their ethnicity. This required spirit and wisdom. But it is not a necessary prerequisite for the ordinary church worker to be f*
                                     *illed with spirit and wisdom in order to do the simple, mundane labor that all churches require (such as being an usher, a greeter, etc.). Faithfulnes*
                                     *s and a willingness to work with others is about all such a worker needs. Furthermore, the takeaway from this passage is that a deacon is an overseer,*
                                     * one who can oversee an area of responsibility which is fraught with moral challenges; the run-of-the-mill church worker is not a deacon. If the quali*
                                     *fication for every church worker was that he had to be filled with spirit and wisdom (in addition to being faithful and getting along with others), th*
                                     *en there would be very few church workers, and much work would remain undone. Also, see description of <i|deacon |i>in note of 1 Cor. 15:24.*

                                     * is a NT expression (Matt. 8:12; 13:42,50; 24:51; 25:30; Luke 13:28) typically describing agony.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[t]|s><i|the Man|i>…Lit: <i|Son of Man|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|his descendants—his progeny|i>…Lit: <i|his seed|i>. This is actually singular, not plural, but the meaning is plural. However, in Gal. 3:1*
                                     *6, Paul, using the same word, emphasizes that this is not plural but singular, singular referring to Christ.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|be our banner on the march and in battle, ensuring success at every turn|i>…Lit: <i|go before us|i>. Images of gods were put on carts whic*
                                     *h preceded those going into battle or those on the march, just as a strong warrior preceded the host.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|I will exile you to a place which is somewhere out beyond Babylon|i>…As it says in Ps. 37:29, “The righteous shall inherit the land, and d*
                                     *well therein forever.” Going back to Genesis, God promised the land which is Israel to the Israelites. If they obeyed, God would have them live in the*
                                     * land. If they disobeyed, they would eventually be driven out. <i|Out beyond Babylon |i>shows how far away they’ll be removed from the promised land.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|unyielding and unchanged in hearts and ears|i>…Lit: <i|stiff-necked and uncircumcised in hearts and the ears|i>. The words/phrases <i|stif*
                                     *f-necked|i> and <i|uncircumcised|i> <i|of heart|i> are OT expressions (Exod. 32:9, Deut. 10:16). Stiff-necked means a person won’t bend his head eithe*
                                     *r downwards in contrition or upwards in hope and faith. Circumcision is the OT pact, the acceptance of and entry into God’s covenant. Also, the remova*
                                     *l of the foreskin in the circumcision ceremony symbolizes the peeling away and discarding of a hardened outer layer surrounding the heart (Deut. 10:16*
                                     *).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|took their jackets off and set them next to an aspiring young man named Saul|i>…The removal of the jackets (cloaks actually) was done so t*
                                     *hat the witnesses would be able to move about more freely when casting the stones. It’s also a gesture of intent, analogous to high school boys who ar*
                                     *e about to get into a fight and taking off their jackets and showing how tough they are while doing so. Once the high school boy takes off his jacket,*
                                     * he turns a person next to him and hands him his jacket for safekeeping. Now the boy who’s about to get into a fight would’ve been flanked by his clos*
                                     *e friends, so the person he hands his jacket to is a close friend. All of this paints a picture of who Saul was; he was standing next to the witnesses*
                                     *, so he was part of the inner clique, someone who was trusted, someone who, though younger, was permitted to tag along closely with the high-priest-ca*
                                     *ste. When the witnesses put their jackets next to Saul, the assumption was that Saul was responsible for their safekeeping. As the witnesses quickly s*
                                     *canned their throng looking for someone to entrust their jackets to, Paul was the logical choice because of his trustworthiness, his close proximity t*
                                     *o the witnesses (indicating his zeal), and his youth (indicating that he was the younger among elders). It’s more appropriate to give a young man meni*
                                     *al duties than someone who’s older and more senior.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|the Holy Spirit|i>…the definite article (<i|the) |i>isn’t in the GT, but in Acts 5:3 the definite article is present in <i|the Holy Spirit*
                                     *. |i>Although there are several reasons for inclusion or exclusion of the definite article, it appears that the inclusion of the article in Acts 5:3 e*
                                     **
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|fallen|i>…There is a distinction between the Holy Spirit being in a person and the Holy Spirit falling upon a person. The Holy Spirit went*
                                     * into the eleven when Jesus breathed on them in John 20:22. Later, the Holy Spirit fell on the eleven (plus one) on Pentecost.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|they only existed in a state where they had been baptized|i>…<i|Existed in a state|i> is the Gk. word <i|huparchō |i>(ὑπάρχω/Strong’s 5225*
                                     *), and the words <i|had been baptized |i>reflect the Gk. perfect participle <i|to be baptized|i>. This adds clarity to the fact that they had become b*
                                     *elievers and were baptized in water but that the Holy Spirit had not come upon them. It is the rule and not the exception that the Holy Spirit comes u*
                                     *pon a person a span of time after he becomes a believer.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|God’s offering|i>…Or: <i|God’s gift|i>. The Gk. word for <i|gift |i>here (<i|dōrean|i>), (δωρεάν/Strong’s 1432)<i| |i>is not the same word*
                                     * for <i|gift |i>used in 1 Cor. 12:4 (<i|charisma|i>), (χάρισμα/Strong’s 5486); the word <i|charisma |i>is expected. A <i|dōrean |i>is a gift brought a*
                                     *nd offered to another, like the offerings of the OT Mosaic Law. A dōrean is also a gift that the recipient has earned or deserves, whereas a charisma *
                                     *is a gift a person hasn’t earned. Charisma comes from <i|charis |i>(grace), (χάρις/Strong’s 5485); ref. note of Rom. 12:6). Therefore, the gift (<i|dō*
                                     *rean|i>) of the Holy Spirit is something that God brings to mankind and presents as a gift, as an offering.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|heard him reading|i>…In ancient times, those who could read always read aloud and never silently to themselves, even when alone.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s>vs. 37 would read: <i|Philip said, “If you believe with all of your heart, you may.” He said in response, “I believe the Son of God to be Jes*
                                     *us Christ.”|i> This verse is not to be found in almost all of the best manuscripts, and is therefore a spurious addition. Verse 37 is instructive of t*
                                     *ext added years after Luke wrote Acts. Rather than attempting to propagate a lie, it attempts to embellish the text.*

                                     *ting Judaism altogether.*

                                     *ly Spirit; being baptized in the Holy Spirit almost always occurs at a time after believing in Jesus. Therefore, Saul was a believer already, when he *
                                     *was baptized in the Holy Spirit. Since the Holy Spirit comes to live in every believer at the time they receive Christ, the baptism in the Holy Spirit*
                                     * must be something different.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|was in the habit of making|i>…From the sounds of it, Tabitha used to make clothing and donate it to the needy. Those whom she showed the m*
                                     *ost generosity to in life (i.e. the widows) wept the hardest when she died.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|battalion|i>…Lit: <i|cohort|i>*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|reptiles|i>…Lit: <i|creatures which crawl on the ground|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|isn’t kosher|i>…Lit: <i|is profane and unclean.|i> A hendiadys. <i|Profane |i>is something which one should never indulge in; <i|unclean |*
                                     *i>is something which you shouldn’t indulge in until it flips back to <i|clean |i>(assuming it can or ever does). Also, ref. Rom. 14:14.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|comrades|i>…Lit: <i|brothers|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|prostrated himself before him in worship|i>…Lit: <i|fell at the feet and worshipped|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|praying just like we pray during the Three-in-the-Afternoon-Prayer-Time|i>…Lit: <i|praying a ninth|i>[-<i|hour prayer|i>]. <i|Ninth |i>ref*
                                     *ers to <i|three in the afternoon|i>. Ref. Acts 3:1.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|really, really floored|i>…Lit: <i|upon a truth overtaken|i>. <i|Upon a truth |i>is an expression. <i|Overtaken |i>is the same word rendere*
                                     *d John 1:5 <i|take him down.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|who reverence Him and go about doing right are acceptable to Him|i>…Lit: <i|who fear Him and work righteousness are acceptable to Him|i>. *
                                     *Also, <i|acceptable to Him |i>means <i|accepted by Him, |i>meaning that He accepts them if they were to ask.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|God|i> <i|singled out and specially chose Jesus of Nazareth and put on him|i>…Lit: God <i|anointed Jesus of Nazareth|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|an oh-so-powerful-dose|i> of <i|the miracle-working power of the Holy Spirit|i>…Lit: <i|the Holy Spirit and power|i>. A hendiadys similar *
                                     *to the one in Matt. 3:11; ref. note there.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|wooden cross-beam|i>…Lit: <i|wood|i> [<i|beam|i>]. This is a synecdoche for crucifixion. Ref. 5:30.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|through his authority and what he stands for|i>…Lit<i|: through his name|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|the men who were dedicated to a strict form of Judaism|i>…Lit: <i|the faithful from out of circumcision. |i>This phrase is an expression w*
                                     *hich wraps a metonymy. Circumcision is the metonymy; the expression is Jews who believe one must adhere strictly to edicts of the Law of Moses. Simila*
                                     *r wording as Acts 11:2.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|offering—the gift|i>…Ref. note of 8:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|water for someone to be baptized in can’t be denied to|i>…A figure of speech; water here is a synecdoche for baptism itself. What he means*
                                     * is, <i|baptism can’t be denied to|i>…*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[r]|s><i|by the authority of|i>…Lit: <i|in the name of|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|From (the Roman Province of)|i> <i|Italia|i>…Lit: [<i|from|i>] <i|Italia|i>. The Gk. word <i|Italia |i>in the ablative case; hence the ins*
                                     *ertion of <i|from.|i> Just like Waffen-SS divisions had names given to them, and some American divisions have nicknames, in the same way this battalio*
                                     *n was given a name. It’s reasonable to assume that all the soldiers in this battalion were conscripted from the Roman province of Italia.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|a devout Gentile who was a sympathizer and near-convert to Judaism|i>…Lit: <i|pious and fearing God|i> [<i|a God-fearer|i>]. God-fearers w*
                                     *ere Gentiles who followed Jewish practices but weren’t converts to Judaism.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|have percolated upwards to where they’ve garnered God’s attention, and He’s quite pleased by what He sees|i>…Lit: <i|have ascended for a m*
                                     *emorial before God|i>. This literal wording is taken from Lev. 2:2; Therefore, OT offerings such as the gift offerings of Lev. 2 are a metaphor for Co*
                                     *rnelius’s prayers and alms. The metaphor made a few times in the NT (2 Cor. 2:15; Eph. 5:2; Heb. 13:15; etc.) compares Christian duty to the aroma tha*
                                     *t went up in the smoke in the burning of OT offerings. The way it is presented, God left commandments in the OT for His people to burn offerings, then*
                                     * way up in the sky sniffs the air for the smell of the sacrifices being burned as He commanded, and is pleased when He smells them.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *Also, the fact that this angel spoke to Cornelius using an OT metaphor means that Cornelius must’ve known the OT pretty well, or he wouldn’t have unde*
                                     *rstood what the angel was saying.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|back deck|i>…Lit: <i|the rooftop|i>. Some liberties taken. Houses in that time and in that part of the world used their rooftops the same *
                                     *way we use back decks, and they had ladders or stairways which led up to them. A rooftop provided privacy from the confines of the house (ref. Prov. 2*
                                     *5:24), and one presumes that Peter sought such privacy for prayer. Peter got a whiff of the smoke from the midday meal, he was hungry already, and it *
                                     *distracted him. God used this distraction as a vehicle to teach him something new.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|the thing which God has purged of its non-kosher-ness is permissible for you to eat|i>…Lit: <i|that which God has cleaned is not profane|i*
                                     *> [<i|for|i>] <i|you|i>. The kosher laws are listed in the Law Moses in chapters such as Lev. 11. Various creatures are specified to be clean or not c*
                                     *lean, and if clean, permissible to eat. However, there are other passages in the Law of Moses where a person, for example, will be unclean for a while*
                                     *, but then can purge the uncleanness from himself and thereby become clean again. Verse 14 here alludes to this concept.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *The vision came to Peter when he was hungry and the vision was concerning food—at least superficially. In a broader sense, it was redefining what is a*
                                     *nd isn’t permissible for Peter to do, according to Jewish beliefs, and the lifting of the ban on non-kosher foods is applicable to the lifting of the *
                                     *ban on Gentiles themselves. And—incidentally—this is one of a few NT passages which teaches that Christians are not subject to certain taboos enumerat*
                                     *ed in the Law of Moses.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|all of us are on the edge of our seats waiting|i>…Lit: <i|we all exist before God|i>. This appears to be an idiom; it’s not entirely certa*
                                     *in if this rendering is correct. In fact, some manuscripts have been redacted to change the wording here so this verse reads, <i|we’re present here be*
                                     *fore you.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|healing all who were being oppressed by the devil|i>…The Gk. word used for <i|healing |i>here <i|iaomai|i> (ἰάομαι/Strong’s 2390<i|)|i> re*
                                     *fers specifically to physical healing; Luke selected this word over the all-encompassing Gk. word for healing <i|therapeuō |i>(θεραπεύω /Strong’s 2323*
                                     *), which generally means <i|treated |i>and can and often does encompass more than physical healing; in the NT, <i|therapeuō |i>is generally preferred *
                                     *over <i|iaomai |i>when describing the treating of a person who’s demon-possessed (i.e., casting the demon out). The point being made is that this is a*
                                     *nother instance in the NT where physical sickness is said to be an oppression of the devil. If this is so, how can sickness be a means which God uses *
                                     *to teach people something?*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|comrades|i>…Lit: <i|brothers|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|whole-heartedly embraced and acted upon|i>…Lit: <i|received|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|they who adhere to Judaism strictly|i>…Lit: <i|they from out of circumcision|i>. The phrase <i|they|i> <i|from out of circumcision |i>is a*
                                     *n abbreviated form of <i|the faithful from out of circumcision, |i>which appears in Acts 10:45.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|those outside of Judaism|i>…Lit: <i|uncircumcised|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|by which you will be rescued you from your spiritual malaise|i>…Lit: <i|by which you will be saved|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|in|i>…Lit: <i|upon|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|who was I to stand in God’s way|i>…Lit: <i|was I somebody who could block God|i>?*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|Complete-Changeover which leads to|i>…Lit: <i|repentance to|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|The Lord was supernaturally and spectacularly working behind the scenes in conjunction with them|i>…Lit: <i|the Lord’s hand was with them|*
                                     *i>. An expression found throughout the Bible.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s>first part of v. 24 moved to v. 23.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|using Barnabas and Saul as couriers|i>…Lit: <i|through the hand of Barnabas and Saul|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|men sent as messengers|i>…The participle used here is the root word for apostle. The usage here provides insight into what an apostle is.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|you and your entire household|i>…Some have taken this (along with Acts 16:15,31,33; Acts 18:8) to be a promise that God will cause your im*
                                     *mediate family to become believers if you simply have faith in that promise. This is a principle, not a promise. The principle is that those who submi*
                                     *t to and follow you in natural affairs will do the same with spiritual affairs; if a person submits his will to another, it will carry over into spiri*
                                     *tual things also. Cornelius was the head of his household, which included his family, his relatives that were living with him, and his servants, and h*
                                     *is household were following his spiritual lead (Acts 10:27) before Peter arrived. The literal wording of Acts 16:33b confirms this; the entire half-ve*
                                     *rse says, “He himself was baptized and all they of his immediately”; the confirming phrase is “all they of his.”*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|advised, encouraged, and in every way helped|i>…This is the verb from which the well-known Gk. word <i|paraklātos |i>(παράκλητος/Strong’s *
                                     *3875) is derived<i|.|i> Ref. note of Acts 4:36. This passage demonstrates what the “the Son of Encouragement” (Acts 4:36, NASB) is all about. In the r*
                                     *ole of Son of Encouragement , Barnabas had a knack for knowing who was needed, where and when they were needed, and this urged him to bring Paul to An*
                                     *tioch (v. 26). In the rift between Barnabas and Paul in Acts 16:36–41, Barnabas’s instincts derived from his gift of Encouragement caused him to stand*
                                     * against Paul on John-Mark’s behalf. His instincts were later vindicated as some of Paul’s last words, spoken in 2 Tim. 4:11, attested to Mark’s faith*
                                     *fulness.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|Christians|i>…It’s insinuated that the renaming of the disciples as <i|Christians |i>was a result of Barnabas’s and Paul’s teaching, just *
                                     *after Cornelius’s conversion, who was the first Gentile to become a believer. We can deduce that Paul at this time was teaching that a non-Jew could b*
                                     *ecome a believer, and this new teaching was the crux of this new movement called “Christianity.” Therefore, technically-speaking, a Christian is one w*
                                     *ho circumvented Judaism and became a believer directly, as opposed to a person who’s a part of “the Way,” which is a Jew who becomes a believer in Jes*
                                     *us (ref. Acts 9:2). Consequently, in terms of technicalities, it is not possible for a Jew to become a Christian; a Jew who believes in Jesus the same*
                                     * way that a Christian does becomes a part of the Way, and not a Christian. A Jew can be a genuine believer in Jesus and not renounce his Judaism.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|the entire civilized world|i>…Or: <i|the entire inhabited world|i>. Assumption is that Luke was principally speaking of the Roman Empire.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|the presiding board, the leaders of the church in Jerusalem|i>…Lit: <i|the elders|i>. In the early days of Christianity, passages such as *
                                     *these indicate that the churches were led similar to the way synagogues were: they were led by a board of elders. To claim that, according to the Bibl*
                                     *e, the only true and proper model for governing a church is that the church be headed by one and only one person fails to reconcile verses like this.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|Mark|i>…Lit: <i|John|i>. Some liberties taken.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|designated ad-hoc rulers|i>…Lit: <i|granted judges|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 19:28.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|clan|i>…Lit: <i|tribe|i>*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|the wooden cross-beam|i>…Lit: <i|the wood|i>. A synecdoche for the cross; ref. note of Acts 5:30.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|bodily decomposition|i>…Or: <i|decay|i>. A synecdoche for death, one taken from the OT in the quotation in v. 35. When Paul uses this word*
                                     * in v. 34, he’s thinking ahead about the OT verse which he quotes in v. 35.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|holy things|i>…<i|Holy-One|i>…Plural and singular forms of the same word. Since the word itself is uncommon, Paul appears to be associatin*
                                     *g the two OT quotations, and that’s why he begins v. 35 with the word <i|therefore. |i>In other words, one of the things referred to by “David’s holy *
                                     *things” in v. 34 is the “Holy-One” (Jesus) in v. 35.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[r]|s><i|destine|i>…Lit: <i|grant|i> [or perhaps, <i|allow|i>]*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[s]|s><i|expired|i>…Lit: <i|fell asleep|i>. A NT expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[t]|s><i|get the better of you|i>…Lit: <i|come upon you|i>. A well-known biblical expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[u]|s><i|because I’m doing something special in your lifetime|i>…Lit: <i|I am working a work in your days|i>. <i|Working a work|i> is a figure of s*
                                     *peech, emphasizing that the work is something special, unusual, and to be anticipated.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[v]|s><i|wiped their hands of it…|i>Lit: <i|shook the dust off their feet. |i>This is an expression; it’s questionable—doubtful—whether Paul and Ba*
                                     *rnabas actually did this. Ref. Matt. 10:14; Mark 6:11.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[w]|s><i|a Holy-Spirit-fueled-joy|i>…Lit: <i|joy and the Holy Spirit|i>. A hendiadys; ref. note of Matt. 3:11.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|Joshua-2.0|i>…[<i|2.0|i> is <i|two-point-oh, |i>a remake of the original]…Lit: <i|Bar-Joshua|i> [which some render <i|Bar-Jesus|i>]. <i|Ba*
                                     *r |i>is the Hebrew prefix for <i|son of. |i>It’s unlikely that he knew anything about Jesus, so <i|Bar-Joshua |i>is the logical choice over <i|Bar-Jes*
                                     *us. |i>By the sounds of his name, he fancied himself as another Joshua, one who assumes the leadership of the people and takes them into the Promised *
                                     *Land.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|This fellow Sergius Paulus|i>…Lit: <i|This fellow|i>. The context suggests that <i|this fellow |i>refers to Sergius Paulus, not Bar-Joshua*
                                     *, as the grammatical inflections more strongly suggests it refers to Bar-Joshua. The conclusion is that Luke should’ve done a better job at resolving *
                                     *this ambiguity and should’ve avoided any insinuation that <i|this fellow |i>refers to Bar-Joshua. Along these same lines, in v. 8 the interpolation “J*
                                     *oshua-2.0’s name, that is”<i| |i>was added to clarify that Luke means that Bar-Joshau and Elymas are not two different people.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|also “Paul”|i>…From here out, Saul is mostly referred to as <i|Paul|i>. Notice how the spelling of <i|Saul |i>and <i|Paul |i>differ only b*
                                     *y a single consonant; <i|Paul |i>is the Gentile-equivalent of the Jewish name Saul. To give an analogy, let’s say there’s a man from Central America w*
                                     *ith the Spanish name <i|Jaime|i> who’s working in an English-speaking company in the U.S. Among his coworkers, he goes by <i|Jimmy|i>, an English-equi*
                                     *valent of <i|Jaime.|i> But in the Spanish conversation among his family and friends, he’s still <i|Jaime|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|if any among you has an encouraging word|i>…Paul and Barnabas were strangers attending the synagogue for the first time and were asked if *
                                     *they wanted to stand up and speak to the audience, which Paul proceeded to do for a few minutes. This was standard practice back then; nowadays, churc*
                                     *hes won’t even invite those who itinerate in their denomination (if there’s any still around) to speak at their church for the weekend that the pastor*
                                     *’s on vacation. Pastors these days completely monopolize the pulpit only, occasionally throwing out a bone to their obsequious staff underlings, and o*
                                     *nly so they don’t get discouraged and quit…and—after all—who’s going to speak when the pastor’s on vacation anyways? Churches claim to faithfully adhe*
                                     *re to the practices of the Bible. They do not. In this day and age of the abundant availability of information, over the years they have further restr*
                                     *icted what is spoken in their church instead.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|you reject it and render yourself unworthy of that special fullness of life|i>…Lit: <i|you reject it deliver a judgment |i>[<i|on|i>]<i| y*
                                     *ourselves |i>[<i|as|i>]<i| those unworthy of eternal life. |i>From v. 48, <i|the very ones who were appointed to eternal life believed. |i>In the deba*
                                     *te between free will and predestination, the two sides of the coin are presented in these two verses. Rejecting Christ, an act of their free will, mad*
                                     *e them unworthy of eternal life. Those who rejected Christ were not appointed to eternal life (v. 48). Free will and predestination are in harmony wit*
                                     *h one another, not in opposition.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|Greek-speaking Jews|i>…Lit: <i|Greeks|i>. The assumption (which is not certain) is that these are Jews, not Gentiles, as is the case in Jo*
                                     *hn 7:35; John 12:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|succeed in their life of faith (enter God’s kingdom)|i>…Lit: <i|into-go into[enter] God’s kingdom|i>. This verse is key in the assertion t*
                                     *hat the NT phrase <i|enter God’s kingdom |i>is an idiom. (Being an idiom, perhaps this explains the double-use of the word <i|into |i>in the phrase.) *
                                     *In the context here of Acts 14:22, Paul is giving advice to those who are already disciples, telling them what they must do to “enter God’s kingdom.” *
                                     *If one takes <i|enter God’s kingdom |i>literally, then this makes no sense, since they are already in God’s kingdom. It only makes sense if <i|enter G*
                                     *od’s kingdom |i>is taken as an idiom.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|presiding boards|i>…Lit: <i|elders|i>. Paul did not appoint pastors to rule these churches but committees of elders. Though bishops would *
                                     *eventually replace the elders, both forms of church government are legitimate, not one or the other. Ref. note of 11:30.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|comrades|i>…Lit: <i|brothers|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|presiding board|i>…Lit: <i|elders|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|no one discriminated against them|i>…Lit: <i|no one discriminated between us and them|i>, or, <i|no one made a distinction between us and *
                                     *them|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|miracles|i>…Lit: <i|signs and wonders|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|condo|i>…Lit: <i|tent|i> [<i|tabernacle|i>]. Liberties taken. Ref. note of Luke 16:9.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|My mark of ownership|i>…Lit: <i|My name|i>. Similar to, “And I will write my God’s name upon him,” from Rev. 3:12.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|and|i> <i|who’s been making this|i> <i|known from eternity|i> <i|past|i>…The principle manuscripts differ for this verse.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|decided what was best to do|i>…Lit: <i|thought|i> [<i|it right|i>]*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|Greetings|i>…Lit: <i|To be rejoicing|i>. Standard introductory remark for letters back then.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|mind|i>…Lit: <i|soul|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|dedicated their lives to|i>…Lit: <i|given their lives over to on behalf of|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|all that our Lord Jesus Christ stands for|i>…Lit: <i|the name of our Lord Jesus Christ|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|make you shoulder any more burden|i>…Lit: <i|place much on your neck|i>. The metaphor of placing a yoke, and thereby a load to pull, on an*
                                     * oxen. This metaphor is used here and there throughout the NT, and in fact is used in v. 10.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|short prophetic messages|i>…Lit: <i|words|i>. The usage of <i|words|i> in v. 32 should be applied to understanding what <i|word |i>means i*
                                     *n the phrases <i|word of wisdom, word of knowledge, |i>and <i|prophecy |i>found in 1 Cor. 12:8.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|putting the churches on a firm footing|i>…Same Gk. word used in Acts. 14:22 (ref. note there), which is rendered <i|rely on the Lord.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|tell them how things ought to be done, instructing|i>…Lit: <i|teach|i> [Gk: <i|didaskō |i>(διδάσκω/Strong’s 1321)]. <i|Didaskō, |i>while n*
                                     *ormally translated <i|teach, |i>has the additional meaning of instructing a person on how he should conduct his life, as it does in v. 1 here, and als*
                                     *o in 1 Tim. 2:12, where Paul says that a woman shouldn’t teach a man (i.e., tell a man how to conduct his life).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|James|i>…Verse 13 quietly introduces James the brother of Jesus, the context insinuating that he’s the head of the church in Jerusalem and*
                                     * also that the Jerusalem church consists solely of practicing Jews who believe in Jesus.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|for the first time, God paid a visit—a caring, helping type of visit—in order to form a unique group of people from out of the Gentiles, a*
                                     * people consecrated to everything He represents|i>…Lit: <i|God visited to receive a people to His name out of Gentiles|i>. The wording that James spea*
                                     *ks with here in v. 14 are phrases, expressions, idioms, etc. plucked out of the OT. Since this is a snippet of conversational speech and is impromptu,*
                                     * we deduce that James spoke this way all the time, his speech heavily seasoned with OT phraseology. Since he grew up with Jesus, Jesus spoke the same *
                                     *way also. Or perhaps he picked up the habit from Jesus himself.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|bizarre sexual immorality|i>…Lit: <i|fornication|i>. This is a reference to the prohibitions in Lev. 18:6–23, sexual practices that even t*
                                     *he world, jaded as it sometimes is, generally disdains. Both the usage of the word <i|fornication |i>here and the usage in 1 Cor. 5:1 refer to extreme*
                                     * practices. In the NT, the Gk. word for <i|prostitute |i>is the female form of <i|fornicator, |i>and keep in mind that a lot, if not most, prostitutes*
                                     * were temple prostitutes and fornication was combined with the pagan cult rituals. A preponderance of evidence indicates that the NT word for fornicat*
                                     *ion implies something more severe than simply shacking up with your fiancée a few months before getting married, which is commonplace in the West nowa*
                                     *days.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|drinking the blood remaining in the body of an animal after it’s been killed by having its neck broken|i>…Lit: <i|the strangled and the bl*
                                     *ood|i>. A figure of speech, apparently: an expression built out of a hendiadys. This apparently refers to the practice of slaughtering an animal in su*
                                     *ch a way that no blood is spilled, so none of the blood is spilled and wasted, preserving more blood to be drunk.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|certified letter so there would be no doubt of its authenticity|i>…Lit: <i|having been written from a hand of theirs|i>. This appears to b*
                                     *e an idiom. The idiom helps explain Gal. 6:11.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|released|i>…One might have expected the word <i|departed |i>to be used instead of <i|released|i>, a word which is used twice, once in v. 3*
                                     *0 and again in v. 33. The context together with the choice of this word seems to insinuate that Paul and Barnabas’s bed and board was provided by some*
                                     * other party, whoever was hosting them at the moment. When they were “released,” the hosts were relieved of the responsibility of providing for them. *
                                     *In v. 33, <i|they were released back to the ones who sent them, |i>means that the ones who sent them were to start providing meals for them. Here and *
                                     *there in his epistles, Paul addresses the support which he receives (or doesn’t receive) from his hosts; 1 Cor. 9:11 is one example. The support of mi*
                                     *nisters of the Gospel has been a thorny issue from the inception of Christianity, and not only that but in the OT as well in regard to Priests and Lev*
                                     *ites. Suffice to say that congregations, like the example in vv. 30,33 here, should assume the responsibility of providing for the pastor or pastors w*
                                     *ho lead their congregation and furthermore for the itinerating speakers who speak at their church. Like this passage here in Acts, congregations shoul*
                                     *d take ownership of that responsibility rather than the pastor having to force the issue.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[H]|s><i|in good standing|i>…Lit: <i|with peace|i>. The word <i|peace |i>in this context has an idiomatic meaning. Ref. usage of <i|peace |i>in Mat*
                                     *t. 10:12,13. The word <i|peace |i>here means not only that they left in good standing but the folks they were visiting weren’t anxious to get rid of t*
                                     *hem because they were annoying, nettlesome, or a burden, but rather felt sorry when they left.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[I]|s>Verse 34 missing from the better manuscripts*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|comrades|i>…Lit: <i|brothers|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|presiding board|i>…Lit: <i|elders|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|from speaking|i>…Lit: to <i|speak|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|over|i>…Lit: <i|down|i>. They were coming down in elevation, coming out of the mountains.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|trying|i>…The word used here implies that each attempt to go into Bithynia was a trial*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|luxurious cloth|i>…Lit: <i|purple cloth|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|sympathizer and near-convert to Judaism|i>…Lit: <i|fearing God|i>. Ref. note of Acts 10:2.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|wouldn’t take “no” for an answer|i>…Lit: <i|urged|i>; <i|compelled|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|bosses|i>…Or: <i|overlords|i>; or perhaps <i|owners|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|what you need to do to set things right with God|i>…Lit: <i|the way of salvation|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|by the authority vested in me by Jesus Christ|i>…Lit: <i|in name of Jesus Christ|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|we|i>…First occurrence of <i|we|i> instead of <i|they|i>, as Luke joins up with Paul at Troas.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|the women who had formed a group there|i>…Many believe that this group of women were the seed out of which the church at Philippi was form*
                                     *ed, and as a result the Philippian church—the one Paul’s epistle was addressed to—consisted entirely of women. Upon examining Paul’s epistles, the Phi*
                                     *lippian church stands out as one of the more mature and spiritual congregations written about in the NT.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|Exasperated|i>…The Gk. word <i|diaponeuomai |i>(διαπονέομαι/Strong’s 1279) used twice in the NT, here and in 4:2, literally means <i|being*
                                     * toiled throughout|i>. Though <i|exasperated |i>is in line with 4:2, and also that the NIV renders it <i|became so annoyed |i>and the NASB <i|greatly *
                                     *annoyed, |i>this context seems to insinuate something different, closer to the KJV’s rendering of <i|diaponeuomai |i>as <i|grieved. |i>It’s as though *
                                     *Paul didn’t know that this woman was possessed by a demon spirit until the Holy Spirit revealed it to him instantly, at a discrete point in time. He b*
                                     *ecame grieved that moment and immediately cast the spirit out of her. Paul wouldn’t have procrastinated for several days in dealing with a spirit.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|flew off the handle|i>…Lit: <i|tore their cloaks|i>. Some liberties taken. Ref. note of Matt. 26:65. Strange thing is that this is a Jewis*
                                     *h practice and one would assume that the magistrates here are Gentiles. Perhaps the magistrates were Jews after all, and this would explain their anim*
                                     *osity towards Paul and Silas. Also, in vv. 21,22 the bosses who dragged Paul and Silas before the magistrates harp on the fact that Paul and Silas are*
                                     * Jews encouraging Romans to adopt Jewish practices. This would mean that the bosses are painting Jews (Paul and Silas) as troublemakers in front of ot*
                                     *her Jews (the magistrates) for their own personal gain (playing the race card, as we say nowadays).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|all who were under his authority|i> …Lit: <i|all them of his|i>. Obviously, this refers to those in his household, but the literal, face-v*
                                     *alue meaning of these words insinuates anyone who’s “his,” or anyone who is under his authority, which would include any other jailers who worked unde*
                                     *r him too. Ref. note of 11:14.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|brought them upstairs|i>…Lit: <i|he led them up|i>. As this is rendered literally, the jailer must’ve lived in an apartment on a floor abo*
                                     *ve the prison. This agrees with other details in the narrative. In v. 27, the jail keeper was awakened from his sleep by the earthquake, as he was sle*
                                     *eping on the upper floor of the same building which was shaken. Also, the problem of sending a message across town in the middle of the night to awake*
                                     *n his family and have them come to the prison (and many cities had curfews back then too) is solved. Verse 33 says that all of them were baptized <i|i*
                                     *mmediately. |i>So when the jail keeper took Paul and Silas and served them a meal, he took them upstairs to his apartment, never leaving the jail. Tak*
                                     *ing Paul and Silas out of the building in the middle of the night likely would’ve cost the jailer his job and probably his life too.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|Some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers|i>…Or: <i|certain Epicurean and Stoic philosophers|i>. In the GT for, Luke is explicit in say*
                                     *ing that the philosophers here were only Epicurean and Stoic, and no other kinds. As the two schools of philosophy, stoicism and epicureanism, have de*
                                     *bated each other since their inception, Luke is insinuating that they’re wanting to see how Paul and his teaching fit into the framework of the stoici*
                                     *sm vs. epicureanism debate.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|What point is this dilettante-intellectual here trying to make|i>?…Lit: <i|What would this logic-dabbler keep saying|i>? What Luke wrote h*
                                     *ere, and what was originally spoken, here and in the surrounding verses shows a marked upturn in the sophistication of the Gk. used—unlike what is fou*
                                     *nd in the Gospels or other places. It demonstrates the intelligence, education, and sophistication of those speaking (as recorded by Luke), speaking i*
                                     *n their native language. This is more on the level of something from the classical era.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|God’s offspring|i>…Lit: <i|offspring of |i>[<i|Him|i>]. This is a quotation from the Gk. poet Aratus, Paul knows those listening are famil*
                                     *iar with the entire poem and therefore its context. We, however, receive a fragment of the poem, and the fragment taken in isolation is ambiguous. But*
                                     * what Paul says next in v. 29 clarifies the ambiguity and states explicitly what he meant by <i|of Him |i>in Aratus’s quotation in v. 28. In v. 29, Pa*
                                     *ul says <i|has its existence from God|i>, the words <i|from God |i>refer to <i|of |i>[<i|Him|i>]. *

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|You’re to blame for your own destruction|i>…Lit: <i|Your blood|i> [<i|be|i>] <i|upon your head|i>. A biblical idiom.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|I’m wiping my hands of it|i>…Lit: <i|I clean|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|was taken into the home of|i>…Lit: <i|entered into the house of|i>. <i|Entered into |i>in the context of entering someone’s house is a NT *
                                     *expression that means that the homeowner extended an invitation to stay for several days.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|Don’t fall into fear|i>…<i|fall silent|i>…Lit<i|: don’t be afraid|i>…<i|don’t be silent|i>. The Gk. grammar suggests that Paul was not alr*
                                     *eady afraid nor was he silent; the encouragement was to stay away from fear and avoid silence, rather than to pull oneself out of one or the other or *
                                     *both.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|a dedicated group of people|i>…<i|A|i> [<i|folk|i>] <i|people|i>. The word for <i|people |i>here is the same used throughout the NT to des*
                                     *cribe the people of Israel. It means ordinary people who share a common bond, to the point of comprising a nation. The interpolation <i|dedicated |i>i*
                                     *s insinuated by the context.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|filled the role of teacher|i>…Lit: <i|sat|i>. The word <i|sat |i>is similar in meaning to when we when we refer to a professorship as a ch*
                                     *air.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|courtroom where Gallio sat as judge|i>…<i|right there in the courtroom|i>…Lit: <i|judgment seat|i>…<i|before the judgment seat|i>. Some li*
                                     *berties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|Everyone|i>…This is a figure of speech, a type of synecdoche, which does not literally mean everyone. Ref. note of Matt. 3:5.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|comrades|i>…Lit: <i|brothers|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|schooled|i>…Lit: <i|taught by word-of-mouth|i>. Probably referring to something learned in a lecture-style classroom environment, rather t*
                                     *han self-studying books.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|joined in tight unison|i>…The lectionary says this word was used for the confluence of streams or for soldiers locking their shields toget*
                                     *her during battle*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|Priscilla and Aquila|i>…Noteworthy is that Priscilla is named before Aquila, though in v. 2 Aquila is named first. This is a hint that Pri*
                                     *scilla was of greater assistance to Paul than Aquila.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|Arrived in Ephesus|i>…Rev. 2 gives hints that the Ephesian church was stamped with Apollos’s characteristics, namely his scholasticism. Fo*
                                     *r more info, ref. book <i|A Path through Revelation.|i>*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|Jewish exorcists|i>…<i|I exorcise|i>…Same base-word used for <i|exorcists|i> and <i|exorcise|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|to invoke the delegate authority of|i>…Lit: <i|to name the name of|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|half-naked|i>…Lit: <i|naked|i>. Assuming that “naked” means “half-naked” and not “completely naked,” same as in Matt. 25:36.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|what the Lord Jesus is all about|i>…Lit: <i|the name of the Lord Jesus|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|Paul determined by the Spirit|i>…Lit: <i|Paul put himself by the Spirit|i>. The word <i|put |i>when<i| |i>used concerning one’s heart is a*
                                     *n expression. This expression appears in 5:2 also.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|engage the mob|i>…Lit: <i|enter into the mob|i>. Same expression used in v. 8; see note there.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|Gentlemen, fellow Ephesians|i>…Ref. note of Acts 1:9*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|Not only did we not receive it, but we’ve not heard of there being a baptism in the Holy Spirit|i>…This sentence doesn’t lend itself to wo*
                                     *rd-for-word translation; the GT reads like conversational Gk., needing interpolations, rather than written Gk. In other words, what we see in the firs*
                                     *t half of this verse is a the sort of language everyday people spoke in back then—not formal Gk.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|they were baptized by the authority of the Lord Jesus|i>…Lit: <i|they were baptized in|i> [<i|by|i>] <i|the name of the Lord Jesus|i>. Thi*
                                     *s is when they received Christ as Lord. An open question is whether they were baptized in water a second time after this, as all Christians are baptiz*
                                     *ed when they believe, or whether John’s baptism sufficed. But in any case, after being “baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus” (after believing in Je*
                                     *sus), they were baptized in the Holy Spirit, thus demonstrating once again that, generally speaking, the baptism in the Holy Spirit happens after one *
                                     *accepts Christ as Savior—not at the same time.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|the Holy Spirit came upon them|i>…The Holy Spirit coming upon a person is an expression. It does not refer to the indwelling of the Holy S*
                                     *pirit that a person receives as part of believing in the Lord; rather, it means that a person receives the baptism in the Holy Spirit, which is almost*
                                     * always an event distinct from receiving the Lord and one which occurs afterwards.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|he introduced himself to the synagogue and became affiliated with the people there|i>…Lit: <i|he entered into the synagogue|i>. This idiom*
                                     * is used in elsewhere in the NT, specifically in Mark 3:1; Luke 4:16; Luke 6:6, 13:14; 14:1; 17:1,2,10; 18:19; 19:30; 28:8; James 2:2. It has a few di*
                                     *fferent meanings (or multiple meanings at the same time). What should be kept in mind is that a synagogue is first and foremost an assembly of people,*
                                     * in the same way that a church is an assembly of people, and secondly a building or some other premise. Therefore, this expression means: He introduce*
                                     *d himself to those in the synagogue and attended one of their meetings; He became a member of the synagogue; He became affiliated with the synagogue; *
                                     *He visited the synagogue. It may be that this expression denotes a formal custom of introduction where a new member is greeted by those in the synagog*
                                     *ue. As part of this, the new member’s credentials are submitted, and if he’s learned enough in the Scriptures, he’ll be given the opportunity to stand*
                                     * before the synagogue and teach—or at least to talk in smaller, more informal groups. This idiom is also used in phrases like “enter into the kingdom *
                                     *of heaven,” “enter into eternal life,” etc., as in Matt. 7:21; 19:17,23; 25:21, 26:41; Luke 11:52; 22:40,46.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|and the diseases left them, and the Evil Spirits went out|i> <i|of them|i>…Yet another example of disease and evil spirits lumped into the*
                                     * same category. If God causes disease, does He cause evil spirits to afflict people as well?*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|$6.25 million|i>…Lit: <i|50,000 silver|i> [<i|coins|i>]. Assume that the coin is a drachma. Ref. conversion notes in Matt. 18:28 and elsew*
                                     *here.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|two of his helping-assistants|i>…Lit: <i|two of those serving him|i>. The word for <i|those|i> <i|serving |i>here is translated <i|deacon *
                                     *|i>elsewhere<i|. |i>These were Paul’s servants, doing his bidding. Timothy started out at a young age helping Paul, and as he proved trustworthy, Paul*
                                     * assigned him more and more challenging tasks, as Timothy continued to prove his faithfulness and dedication, to the point where a couple of letters P*
                                     *aul sent him are enshrined in the NT. All of this is included in the post of NT deacon.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[H]|s><i|The Ephesians’ Artemis is awesome!|i>…Since the same exact wording appears in v.34 and since these words are blurted repeatedly, this was *
                                     *likely a popular, well-known, often-repeated chant. Whenever the crowd got whipped into a frenzy, they would repeat this chant. This is like something*
                                     * that goes on nowadays at a sporting event, protest, or political rally.*
