SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|Sunday|i>…Lit: <i|first of the Sabbaths|i>. Ref. note of Mark 16:2.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|pronounced dead on the spot|i>…Lit: <i|taken away dead|i>. When they got to his body, they immediately pronounced him dead and instead of *
                                     *trying to treat him proceeded to take away his dead body.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|vigorously attended to him|i>…Lit: <i|fell to him|i>. The word <i|fell |i>is similar to usage in the common NT expression <i|fall upon|i>,*
                                     * which means to assault. <i|Fell to him |i>here has the same meaning as when paramedics attend to a person in an emergency. They are acting quickly, d*
                                     *ecisively, and aggressively, appropriate for the life-threatening situation.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|he’s alive|i>…Lit: <i|his soul is in him|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|prayed over the meal|i>…Lit: <i|broke the bread|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|ate to his heart’s content|i>…Lit: <i|tasted upon|i> <i|a good amount|i>. An expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|change of heart and of ways|i>…Lit: <i|repentance|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|compelled|i>…Lit: <i|bound|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|the good-news-message|i>…Lit: <i|the Gospel|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|never set eyes on me again|i>…Lit: <i|no longer see my face|i>. An expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|I can’t be blamed for the destruction of the lives of anyone|i>…Lit: <i|I am clean from the blood of all|i>. A biblical idiom. Ref. note o*
                                     *f Acts 18:6*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|flock of Christians|i>…Lit: <i|flock of sheep|i>. The metaphor of shepherd as leaders and sheep as followers is extensive throughout the B*
                                     *ible, particularly in the NT.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|monstrous|i>…Lit: <i|heavy|i>; metaphorically means <i|ruthless, grievous, troublesome|i>; when speaking of soldiers, it means <i|heavily-*
                                     *armed|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|will join up with you|i>…Lit: <i|will go into you|i>. Similar wording as 19:8; ref. note there.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|God’s end-goal plan for your lives|i>…Lit: <i|the inheritance|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|those who’ve been set apart and have been made holy|i>…Or: <i|the ones who have been sanctified|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|Any kind of cash, checks, or clothing|i>…Lit: <i|Of gold and of silver and of clothing|i>. The words <i|gold |i>and <i|silver |i>refer to *
                                     *gold and silver coins. Some liberties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[r]|s><i|wrapped their arms forcefully around Paul’s neck|i>…Lit: <i|they fell upon Paul’s neck|i>. Same expression used in Luke 15:20. <i|Falling *
                                     *upon |i>in other contexts means <i|assaulting; |i>in this context it is used metaphorically to insinuate a physical—to the point of being forceful eve*
                                     *n—kind of embrace.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|kept on explaining to them in depth the logic behind what he taught, pointing out to them the logical fallacies of the opposing points of *
                                     *view, and in general covering a given subject with them from top to bottom|i>…Or: <i|reasoned to them|i>. The Gk. word for <i|reasoned |i>here is the *
                                     *same word used in 17:2,17; 18:4,19; 19:8,9; 20:9, and in those verses means the same thing. Paul’s epistle to the Galatians show him “reasoning” in th*
                                     *is way, and this is what Luke says he was doing here in 20:7. Nowadays, this would fall under the category of “teaching,” but the Gk. words for reason*
                                     *ing and teaching don’t correspond exactly to the English words reasoning and teaching. The Gk. word for teaching implies dictating moral instruction (*
                                     *ref. 15:1), whereas the word for reasoning is explaining the logic behind something, the topic at times being difficult to understand.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|church governing board|i>…Lit: <i|the elders of the church|i>. The church at Ephesus, a Gentile church, was run by elders. Later in Acts, *
                                     *we see churches run by bishops. Both forms of church government were in use in the NT; therefore, both forms are sanctioned.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|overseers|i>…<i|leading|i>…Lit: <i|bishops|i>…<i|shepherding|i> [or <i|pastoring|i>]. This is the first occurrence of the word <i|bishop |*
                                     *i>[<i|overseer|i>] in the NT. In modern times, we often use the word <i|pastor |i>when we technically-speaking mean <i|bishop.|i> Note that these bish*
                                     *ops are the elders referred to in v. 17. Also, the word rendered <i|leader |i>here is actually <i|shepherd |i>or <i|pastor. |i>Throughout the Bible, t*
                                     *he word <i|shepherd|i> means <i|leader. |i>In the NT, the word means <i|pastor, |i>and it is where we get the word in its modern usage.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|causing some of the disciples to commit apostasy by becoming their followers|i>…Lit: <i|drawing away the disciples after them|i>. The word*
                                     * <i|drawing away |i>is the same base-word that is rendered <i|apostasy|i> in 2 Thess. 2:3. The words <i|after them |i>are used throughout the NT to me*
                                     *an one person following another, or submitting to the will of another (same usage in Matt. 4:19; ref. note there).*

                                     *ar circumstances as 16:37, refutes certain preconceived ideas connected with “turning the other cheek” (Matt. 5:39). Namely, when Jesus said to turn t*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|the council|i>…Lit: <i|the Sanhedrin|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|for God|i>…Lit: <i|to God|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|hit you back|i>…Lit: <i|be striking you|i>. The Gk. verb tense used in the word <i|hit |i>insinuates an open-ended retaliation rather than*
                                     * a tit-for-tat retaliation.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|bogus judge|i>…Lit: <i|whitewashed wall|i>. Liberties taken. A commonly-used idiom used in Israel at that time. Ref. Matt. 23:27, Luke 11:*
                                     *44.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|very product|i>…Lit: <i|son|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|for the hope that life after death offers|i>…Lit: <i|about hope and resurrection of dead people|i>. <i|Hope and resurrection |i>is a hendi*
                                     *adys (ref. note of Matt. 3:11). <i|Resurrection of the dead|i> is an idiom meaning <i|life after death|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|designated teachers|i>…Lit: <i|Scribes|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|That night|i>…Lit: <i|in the night|i>. As the Jewish day starts at sundown, for them it would be the next day.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|swearing that we would be cursed if we break it|i>…In Gk. reads <i|anathemati anethematisamev |i>(Ἀναθέματι ἀνεθεματίσαμεν), (Ἀναθέματι/St*
                                     *rong’s 332), (ἀνεθεματίσαμεν/Strong’s 331), which shares the same root as the word <i|anathema; |i>and the words are repeated as a figure of speech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|spirits|i>…Or perhaps: <i|the Holy Spirit|i>. The GT is somewhat ambiguous. The word <i|spirit |i>here is singular in the GT, just as the *
                                     *word <i|angels |i>is actually singular (<i|angel|i>). Since angels is singular but the intent is plural, logic suggests that the intent for <i|spirit *
                                     *|i>is plural as well. This also is consistent with the usage in v. 9.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|to enjoy a morsel of food|i>…Lit: <i|to taste|i>. This is an expression, as the text simply says <i|taste |i>with no predicate supplied. T*
                                     *he word <i|taste |i>is used as a metonymy; the entire thing is a figure of speech. This helps explains what Jesus said in Matt. 26:29; Mark 14:25; Luk*
                                     *e 20:10 about drinking of the fruit of the vine: he meant enjoying the fruit of the vine.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|two hundred soldiers in order that they hike all the way to Caesarea, plus seventy cavalrymen and two hundred javelin-throwers|i>…Scholars*
                                     * are uncertain what <i|javelin-throwers|i> (Lit: <i|those-who-grasp-with-the-right-hand|i>) refers to. Perhaps they were Roman velites, younger, less *
                                     *experienced men who served as the light infantrymen who threw javelins. By the size of the contingency, the colonel feared a confrontation which would*
                                     * escalate into a large skirmish, which might even trigger a revolt. Both the cavalry and the velites are fast-moving troops. Apparently, the strategy *
                                     *was to have some troops outrun any opposition, getting him on horseback to Caesarea quickly if the need arose.*

                                     *ubjunctive is out of politeness and respect and avoids the effrontery of being too direct when speaking to one in authority.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|the fact is, this new religion called ‘Christianity’ hasn’t been practiced in a way that it’s been kept in the closet|i>…Lit: <i|for this *
                                     *hasn’t been practiced in a corner|i>. Some liberties taken. Guessing that the <i|this |i>Paul’s refers to is Christianity.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[r]|s><i|the Bible|i>…Lit: <i|the prophets|i>. Technically, the OT not including the Law.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|It’s hard to swim against the tide|i>…Lit: <i|It’s hard to kick at|i> [or <i|against|i>] <i|a cattle prod|i>. Liberties taken. This is spu*
                                     *riously (but not erroneously) inserted in 9:5 in the Textus Receptus. The metaphor is of a steer or some other cattle being jabbed with a cattle prod:*
                                     * the more forceful the prod, the more it hurts the steer. When the steer kicks the prod, he hurts himself even more but doesn’t accomplish anything.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|close to God|i>…Lit: <i|upon God|i>. The appearance of the word <i|upon |i>(<i|epi, |i>ἐπί/Strong’s 1909)<i| |i>seems a bit idiomatic. The*
                                     * usage of <i|upon|i> is the same as 25:9,26 where Festus asks Paul if he’d like to have the trial held “before me” (lit: <i|upon me|i>), and<i| |i>whe*
                                     *re the word <i|before |i>(<i|epi|i>)<i| |i>is used twice in v. 26: “I brought him <i|before|i> us and especially <i|before|i> you<i|.|i>” Other usages*
                                     *, however, like Luke 1:17, “to turn the hearts of the fathers to [epi] the children,” suggest exact proximity, as the base definition of <i|epi |i>sug*
                                     *gests. Therefore, <i|close to|i> is the chosen rendering.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|the people whom God separated to Himself|i>…Lit: <i|God’s saints|i> [<i|separated-ones|i>]. Though this is somewhat ambiguous, the assumpt*
                                     *ion is that by the context, the people separated to God refers to the Israelites.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|in a little way|i>…Or: <i|in little time|i>…Lit: <i|in|i> [<i|a|i>] <i|little|i>, or, <i|with little|i>. Many scholars take this as a figu*
                                     *re of speech or reject it in lieu of a different interpretation, one which isn’t obvious. Some render it <i|almost, |i>while others render it <i|hardl*
                                     *y|i>. I see no reason not to render the remark literally, however.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|Italy|i>…Lit: <i|Italia|i>. The Roman province of Italia, as there was no “Italy” at that time.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|Battalion|i>…Lit: <i|cohort|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|Turkish|i>…Lit: <i|Asian|i>. The Roman province of Asia.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|abandoned|i>…Same word as used in v. 40 to describe the cutting loose of the anchors*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|Oh you guys|i>…Lit: <i|oh men|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|Don’t be afraid|i>…The Gk. verb tense insinuates that Paul was not afraid at the time the angel spoke to him, but is being encouraged not *
                                     *to fall into it.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|get ahold of this|i>…Lit: <i|behold|i>; <i|lo and behold|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|looking at|i> <i|what will happen|i>…Lit: <i|look at|i>; <i|behold|i>. The common Gk. word <i|theōreō |i>(θεωρέω /Strong’s 2334) is used h*
                                     *ere but in an uncommon way.<i| |i>Since the voyage had not yet taken place and since Paul had seen something, one may deduce that Paul had some sort o*
                                     *f premonition in which he saw what was going to take place.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|angel of God|i>…Generally speaking, the GT of the NT refers to an angel as an “angel of the Lord,” “angel of God,” etc., instead of simply*
                                     * “angel.” This is done to clarify the ambiguity between an angel and a messenger, as the word means either. But in English, we simply say “angel” inst*
                                     *ead of the word-for-word rendering “angel of the Lord.” But in v. 23, Paul takes opportunity of the word <i|God |i>to add appositives to which describ*
                                     *e his relationship with Him.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|not a single one of the hairs on your head will be lost|i>…Seeing that there were over two hundred who had to endure the storm and swim to*
                                     * shore, the likelihood that none of them lost a single strand of hair is slim. Therefore, Paul’s remark here is an expression, a figure of speech, and*
                                     * not to be taken literally. From the sounds of it, this is the same expression as is found in Matt. 10:30; Luke 12:7; what Jesus said there can also b*
                                     *e understood as an expression and is not to be taken literally.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|most prominent person|i>…Lit: <i|the first of the island|i>. Perhaps specific to Malta only, or used when a place has no name for the offi*
                                     *ce their leaders occupy.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|forcing|i>…Lit: <i|constraining|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|Paul went over to him, became acquainted with him|i>…Lit: <i|Paul entered to him|i>. An idiom; ref. note of 19:8.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|run down with maladies of some sort|i>…Lit: <i|weaknesses|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 4:23*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|healed or otherwise treated|i>…Or: <i|healed|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 4:23 (a different note than previous ref.).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|a ship called “Gemini”|i>…Lit: <i|with a figurehead Dioscuri|i>. Dioscuri is another name for Castor and Pollux, the Gemini twins.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|fellow-comrades|i>…Lit: <i|brothers|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|they cordially invited us|i>…Lit: <i|we were encouraged from them|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|strengthened his nerve and stiffened his composure|i>…Lit: <i|took courage|i>. The word <i|courage|i> here is derived from the same verb J*
                                     *esus used when he encountered the disciples while walking on water (Mark 6:50) and has the same meaning.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|solemnly stating the truthfulness of|i>…Lit: <i|witnessing|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|the Old Testament|i>…Lit: <i|the Law of Moses and the prophets|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|agreeable to his propositions and conceding his points|i>…Lit: <i|being persuaded|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|were politely told it was time to leave|i>…Lit: <i|were freed|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|redirect their lives in the right way|i>…Lit: <i|turn towards|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|rescue program|i>…Lit: <i|salvation|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|welcomed as guests|i>…Lit: <i|received|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|coming to interact with him in a friendly visit|i>…Lit: <i|coming into to him|i>. This is an idiom; ref. note of Acts 19:8.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|They gave us many donatives as an allowance|i>…Lit: <i|They honored us with many honors|i>. In this context, the Gk. words <i|to honor |i>*
                                     *and <i|honors |i>draws on a secondary definition which the lexicon says is “a reward, present” (the multi-faceted meaning propagated to the English <i*
                                     *|honor|i> vs. <i|honorarium|i>). This is in the form of a monetary obligation, pay, or entitlement. That the usage here of <i|honor |i>refers to contr*
                                     *ibuting financially is supported by these three facts: First, the words <i|many honors |i>insinuate something which is quantitative (cash or items) ra*
                                     *ther than qualitative (honor or respect). Second, the latter half of v. 10 (“put necessities on the ship”) also concerns itself with giving material g*
                                     *oods. Third, the word <i|honor |i>is also used this way in 1 Tim. 5:17.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|sailed the circuit|i>…Some disagreement in the wording of various Gk. manuscripts here, and some conjecture from bible scholars as to what*
                                     * exactly Luke means. I’m guessing that this refers to ships that shuttled from town to town on short hops which were on a fixed and repeated schedule,*
                                     * competing with one another one prices, etc., sort of like how airlines offer flights and compete with one another.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s>Verse 29 omitted from the better manuscripts*

HEADING1                             *Romans*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Paul, the great pioneer of Christianity, the great theologian of Christian doctrine, makes a treatise out of the first half of this long letter to the*
                                     * Romans. *
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *The combination of Paul’s mastery of Greek., the customizing of his writing to a non-Jewish audience, and his lucid prose make it easy on the translat*
                                     *or, as his works can be translated nearly word-for-word and the result be intelligible enough to serve as the final rendering. Therefore, if one compa*
                                     *res various works of translations, even the ones which deviate from the traditional, literal rendering, one finds that the translations are similar. P*
                                     *aul uses his powerful vocabulary and understanding of the grammar to pack nuances into a pithy text, rather than relying on figures of speech like a f*
                                     *ew of the other NT writers do.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Reasoning, philosophy, and the ability to look at various aspects of difficult questions are Paul’s bread & butter. Whereas Jesus’s teachings are rema*
                                     *rkably insightful, Paul’s teachings are remarkably philosophical—and the first half of Romans is the pinnacle of this. Paul takes the reader on a long*
                                     *, single thread until the ninth chapter, when he finally segues to another.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Since Romans delves into such thought-provoking theological and philosophical topics, the approach in translation is akin to the Amplified Bible, a co*
                                     *mpromise between preserving the literal wording and clarifying the end-result. As an analogy, scholars say that the writings of the philosopher Immanu*
                                     *el Kant should not be read directly by someone unschooled in the philosophical terminology Kant uses, as they will not understand it. This is partly t*
                                     *he case with Romans also, as Paul’s multi-faceted meaning of his use of, for example, the word <i|law |i>in conjunction with his inclusion or omission*
                                     * of the definite article is over the head of the unschooled reader, compounded by the fact that most translations don’t propagate through to the rende*
                                     *red version the inclusion or exclusion the definite article on a word-for-word basis anyways, as the final product in English would be awkward at best*
                                     *.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *To ameliorate this, I’ve preferred a word-for-word rendering of the definite article before <i|law |i>and <i|sin |i>in particular and before other wor*
                                     *ds as well because I believe that this is valuable information that Paul is communicating, that it has a large impact on what he’s trying to convey, a*
                                     *nd that it’s essential that the reader get this “unfiltered.” But by doing so, I must sacrifice some readability for clarity. To compensate and to ful*
                                     *ly explain the meaning of the preceding word in conjunction with its optionally-included article, immediately following, I add an explanation inside o*
                                     *f parenthesis and set off by <i|i.e|i>. Generally speaking, if the next occurrence of the word in the same chapter merits the same explanatory phrase,*
                                     * I omit the parenthetical note for brevity’s sake, assuming that the reader will understand that it’s the same as the previous.*

                                     *ggert Phenomenon.” The TV evangelist in his heyday in the ‘80’s was calling out other ministers for their sexual sins while at the same time visiting *
                                     *prostitutes. What Paul is saying here is that, generally speaking, people tend to judge others in the same areas they are guilty of themselves.*

                                     *ill receive a higher level of glory, honor, and peace for the same reason.*

                                     *<s|22|s>a righteousness of God through Jesus Christ-faith to all who believe: there is no distinction, you see: <s|23|s>For all have sinned and come u*

                                     *someone introduced a person whom he recommends to someone else, with the intention of the two becoming friends or joining together in a common cause.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|transacted and counted against a person|i>…Lit: <i|charged to one’s account; imputed|i>. Paul says here and elsewhere that sin cannot take*
                                     * place without God having published a list of His commandments. God doesn’t count deeds done in ignorance as sin. This is why when toddlers die, they *
                                     *don’t face condemnation: toddlers aren’t old enough to comprehend the commandments. It also explains Gen. 4:15, where God didn’t kill Cain for killing*
                                     * Abel but said he’d kill anyone who killed Cain.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|death reigned from Adam until Moses|i>…Paul is referring to the timeframe before the ultimate law, the Law of Moses, was delivered to the *
                                     *people. Even without the Law, which is the ultimate, definitive list compiled by God of what sin is, sin managed to wreak its devastation (i.e., death*
                                     *) during that time. Paul said a verse earlier that sin is not transacted (imputed) where law doesn’t exist; but he’s clarifying that remark by saying *
                                     *that sin indeed reigned in spite of the Law of Moses not existing.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|comrades|i>…Lit: <i|brothers|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|then-and-only-then will she be released|i>…Lit: <i|she has been released|i>. The perfect tense is the reason for the extrapolation <i|then*
                                     *-and-only-then.|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|bound to a different man|i>…Lit: [<i|with|i>] <i|a different man|i>. The dative case of <i|different man |i>is same case as <i|to her husb*
                                     *and |i>in v. 2, and refers to the same thing; hence the interpolation.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|produce aftereffects|i>…Lit: <i|bear fruit|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|released|i>…As this is the same word used in v. 2, Paul is connecting the analogy of a wife who’s released from her marriage to us being r*
                                     *eleased from the Law.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|what’s there to say about this|i>…Lit: <i|what shall we say|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|don’t even think about it|i>…Lit: <i|may it not be. |i>Ref. note of Rom. 3:4.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|every sort of coveting imaginable|i>…Lit: <i|all covetings|i>. A figure of speech. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|would reach its maximal efficacy|i>…Lit: <i|would become exceedingly sinful|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|God is so good|i>…Lit: <i|grace|i> [<i|kindness|i>, <i|mercy|i>, <i|benevolence|i>] <i|with|i> [also <i|to|i>] <i|God|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|married woman|i>…Lit: <i|the under-man woman|i>. The GT is saying that she’s under the power of a man. According to the Law of Moses, only*
                                     * a man could initiate a divorce. Ref. note of Matt. 5:31.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|newness of spirit|i>…Paul’s intentional omission of the definite article before <i|spirit |i>(and for that matter, before <i|law|i>) refer*
                                     *s to the way in which a believer conducts his life. It does not specifically refer to the Holy Spirit per se, but instead refers to a lifestyle where *
                                     *one walks with the Holy Spirit. Some translations assume that the definite article is implied (which there are plenty of examples of such implied defi*
                                     *nite articles in other NT prepositional phrases), and therefore <i|spirit |i>here refers to <i|the |i>[<i|Holy|i>]<i| |i>Spirit. They point to 2 Cor. *
                                     *3:6 as corroborating evidence. I disagree; Paul is consistent and precise in his inclusion or exclusion of definite articles in the preceding chapters*
                                     * of Romans, and he would’ve explicitly added one to specify Holy Spirit for the purpose of resolving the ambiguity he most certainly would’ve foreseen*
                                     *.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|the Law of Moses kept on telling me over and over|i>…Lit: <i|the Law was saying (|i>where<i| was saying |i>is an imperfect verb tense<i|)|*
                                     *i>. Unlike other NT writers (Mark comes to mind), and also because his epistles are treatises and not story-narratives like the Gospels, Paul uses the*
                                     * imperfect tense sparingly. This usage here feels as though Paul is being reminded of this over and over in his head, rather than seeing it appear ove*
                                     *r and over again in the Law.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|Thou shalt not covet such-and-such|i>…Lit: <i|you shall not long for|i>. The word <i|long for |i>comes straight out of Exod. 20:17 in the *
                                     *LXX, so a reader in ancient times who was familiar with the LXX OT would immediately recognize this reference to the Ten Commandments.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|So the thing which is good became a mechanism of death in me, right?|i>…Or: <i|So death became something which is good in me|i>, <i|right?*
                                     *|i>…Lit: <i|So death became good in|i> [or: <i|with|i>; <i|to|i>] <i|me|i>. The word <i|death |i>is in the nominative case and <i|good |i>is either no*
                                     *minative or accusative, and for the GT to fit into a strict grammar parsing, the English translation must put <i|death |i>as the subject and assume <i*
                                     *|good |i>is accusative rather than nominative, meaning that <i|good |i>takes the predicate rather than the subject. The rendering with <i|death |i>as *
                                     *the subject and <i|good |i>as the predicate doesn’t make sense, hence other translations (NASB translates this, “that which is <i|good |i>became a cau*
                                     *se of death for me”), change this according to the context. This means Paul made a mistake when he wrote this—a single-letter slipup, as <i|thanatos |*
                                     *i>(death, θάνατος/Strong’s 2288) need only be changed to <i|thanaton |i>(θάνατόν). On a side note, J.B. Phillips believed that Paul made a mistake in *
                                     *1 Cor. 14:22a (ref. note).*

                                     *word but appreciated the intimacy it conveyed.*

                                     *ion eagerly awaits the revelation of the sons of God|i>*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|people set apart to God|i>…Lit: <i|saints|i>. <i|Holy people |i>is what <i|saints |i>means literally. <i|Holy |i>also means <i|set apart. *

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|a part of him and from him|i>…Lit: <i|of him|i>. Any person who has the Holy Spirit in them is a believer.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|The Spirit himself in conjunction with our spirit|i>…A clear summary of Paul’s usage of the word spirit in this chapter and in his other e*
                                     *pistles. As the GT doesn’t use capital letters, it isn’t always obvious whether Paul is referring to the Holy Spirit or to the regenerated human spiri*
                                     *t—or to both. The context in addition to the inclusion or omission of the definite article (in line with rules for definite articles) is the only way *
                                     *of deciding.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|a token sample of celebration|i>…Lit: <i|the first-fruits|i>. The Gk. word <i|aparchā |i>(ἀπαρχή/Strong’s 536). Also used in Jam. 1:18. Wh*
                                     *ile the word <i|aparchā |i>refers to the classical Gk. pagan offering of the first produce of the harvest, we assume Paul and James are referring to t*
                                     *he wave offering of Lev. 23:9–11. In both cases, a first-fruit offering is a small sample of the year’s harvest—the most excellent sample obtainable—a*
                                     * token which is offered at harvest time to God (or the god) from whom is credited for causing the bountiful harvest. The first-fruits is the following*
                                     *: (a) a recognition and remembrance that God’s blessing, and not simply man’s labor, is the reason the crops grew and that there is a harvest; (b) a c*
                                     *elebration of the harvest; (c) a time of thankfulness like the Thanksgiving holiday in the US; (d) a holiday which marks a change in the calendar year*
                                     *; (e) the end of a season of work and an acknowledgement of the work done during that season; (f) the very best of the best. When the word <i|aparchā *
                                     *|i>is used in the NT, it refers to one, to several, or to all of these.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|intercedes on behalf of others|i>…<i|intercedes on behalf of|i>…In the GT, the word <i|intercedes |i>in v.26 begins with the preposition <*
                                     *i|huper |i>(ὑπέρ/Strong’s 5228) used as a prefix. In v. 27, <i|intercede |i>does not begin with <i|huper|i>; instead <i|huper|i> is used right after <*
                                     *i|intercede |i>as an ordinary preposition, rendered <i|on behalf of|i>. This is why <i|intercedes on behalf of others|i> was added to v. 26: it captur*
                                     *es the differences between <i|intercedes |i>as they appear in vv. 27,28.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|God works all things in unison|i>…Or: <i|all things work in unison|i>. The principal manuscripts are split fairly evenly between these two*
                                     * renderings, with the two oldest ones favoring <i|God works everything in unison. |i>Some claim that this verse says that God is the instigator of bad*
                                     * things, causing them to happen so that He can work them to do good; this may have been the reason why manuscripts were altered centuries ago. This ve*
                                     *rse does not say what the cause of bad things is; it simply says that if and when things occur—bad things included—God then works them for good. Since*
                                     * v. 31 says “if God’s on our side,” then it stands to reason that God is not the cause of bringing bad things into believers’ lives, otherwise, that w*
                                     *ould constitute Him being against them rather than for them.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|foreordained|i>…The word’s Gk. root means: to mark out the boundaries; to lay down; to mark out; to determine; to appoint; to settle; to a*
                                     *ssign. The prefix means <i|ahead of time. |i>Concatenating the meanings of the prefix and the root gives one a clearer idea of what <i|foreordain |i>m*
                                     *eans. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|what|i>…Lit: <i|who|i>. Paul’s using a figure of speech, a personification, to refer to the items which he proceeds to list, as though eac*
                                     *h item is a person. The items listed are delimited by ellipses in an effort to convey this figure of speech to the reader.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[H]|s><i|Satan’s agents nor demon-chieftains|i>…<i|unexplainable, supernatural, or miraculous powers|i>…Lit: <i|angels|i> [<i|messengers|i>; <i|age*
                                     *nts|i>] <i|nor rulers|i>…<i|powers|i>. All the items in the list are of incorporeal things. It can be understood with no doubt that the word <i|angel *
                                     *|i>here refers to demonic agents; ref. 2 Cor. 12:7 for confirmation. As the introductory word <i|angel |i>speaks of demonic forces, it’s safe to assum*
                                     *e that <i|rulers|i> refers to demonic forces as well. This is also confirmed by the word’s usage in Eph. 6:12 and Col. 2:15. The justification of addi*
                                     *ng the descriptive words <i|unexplainable, supernatural, or miraculous|i> before the word <i|powers |i>is (in addition to the other items being incorp*
                                     *oreal) the way <i|powers |i>is used in Matt. 4:12; Mark 6:2; 9:39 to refer to miracles, and in Matt. 24:29 to refer to the stars. *

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|that I would be granted this request|i>…Lit: <i|I would pray|i>. Quoting Max & Mary, “in Hellenistic Greek, the imperfect verb tense takes*
                                     * the place of potential optative”; this is the case here.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|brethren|i>…Lit: <i|brothers|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|the Lineal Descent Selection|i>…Lit<i|: the adoption|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|the Enactment of the Law of Moses|i>…Lit: <i|the legislation|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|Let us pause a moment for that to sink in|i>…Lit: <i|amen|i>. Ref. Rom. 1:25; Rev. 19:4.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|Israel doesn’t consist solely of everyone who was spawned from the nation of Israel|i>…Lit: <i|not all they out of Israel, these are Israe*
                                     *l|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|In other words|i>…Lit: <i|that is|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|at the right time|i>…Lit: <i|according to the season|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|Sarah will have a son|i>…Lit: <i|a son will be with|i> [or <i|in|i>] <i|Sarah|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|while doing on the marriage bed what married couples do,|i> <i|was impregnated|i> …Lit: [<i|she|i>] <i|having bed|i>. The bed is a synecdo*
                                     *che for having ongoing sexual relations (ref. Heb. 13:4). That she conceived as a result is a synecdoche.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|what’s the takeaway|i>…Lit: <i|what shall we say|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|Don’t even think about it|i>…Lit: <i|may it not come into being|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|Old Testament|i>…Lit: <i|Scripture|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|reputation|i>…Lit: <i|name|i>*

                                     *or honorable use (i.e., best dinnerware pieces or decorative pots) on the other|i>…Lit: <i|on the one hand it, a vessel, unto honor, but on the other *

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|the Shekhinah-Glory|i>…Lit: <i|the|i> <i|glory|i>. Episodes in the OT where God’s glory was present: Moses and the burning bush; the cloud*
                                     * on Mt. Sinai; Solomon’s dedication of the temple; etc.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|the children of the flesh are not the ones who’re the children of God|i>…Lit: <i|not the children of flesh|i>, <i|these|i> [<i|are|i>] <i|*
                                     *children of God|i>. The phrase <i|these are children of God |i>is a parallel construct to the literal rendering in v. 6, <i|these are Israel. |i>The u*
                                     *se of the word <i|this |i>or <i|these |i>in this way is a figure of speech (also appears in John 1:2/<i|this person|i>), one which is also used in Eng*
                                     *lish with the near and far demonstrative pronouns. In the NT, the use of <i|this |i>or <i|that |i>as a figure of speech, like in <i|this person|i> or *
                                     *<i|those people|i> means that the writer is spotlighting a person while presenting him to the reader; is emphasizing the distinction between one perso*
                                     *n and another (this is the case in chapter nine here).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|not as a works-outcome but rather as a calling-outcome, the free choice of the One Who calls|i>…(Ref. note of Acts 13:46 also.)This verse *
                                     *and the surrounding passage was a bedrock of Calvin’s teaching on predestination, and along with him most who taught and teach predestination. The que*
                                     *stion is not whether God chooses ahead of time or capriciously (or both), but how He so chooses. Although God reserves the right to choose irrespectiv*
                                     *e of what man does, on the other hand He has given us promises whereby a person can be sure that if he acts on such a promise, God will fulfill his pr*
                                     *omise. There are thousands of promises in the Bible, and these are given for our benefit, to know that God has guaranteed something. On the other extr*
                                     *eme is 1 Cor. 12:18, where God places each believer in Christ’s body capriciously. In the case of Jacob and Esau, where God chose Jacob and rejected E*
                                     *sau, reading into the story, God’s choice was not arbitrary, but was based on the heart of Jacob and of Esau. Furthermore, Jacob’s and Esau’s hearts w*
                                     *ere fixated while they were still in Rebekah’s womb—which is unusual. While, certainly, God chose Jacob over Esau before they were born and had “commi*
                                     *tted any good or bad deed” (v. 11), God saw their hearts before they were born and decided based on what was in them. When says in v. 15 that God will*
                                     * have mercy on whomever He chooses, it implies that no one is in a position to come to God and demand something by means of justice (ref. 3:19,20); th*
                                     *is excludes God from being “unfair” (v. 14). *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|only a select few will be spared from calamity|i>…Lit: <i|a remnant shall be saved|i>. The concept of the remnant is understood by studyin*
                                     *g its usage in the OT.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|wrap it up lickety-split|i>…Also: <i|shutting a piece of business down and wrapping it up quickly|i>…Lit: <i|finishing an affair off and c*
                                     *utting it short|i>. [very Lit: <i|for a word finishing and cutting|i>]. The two Gk. words for <i|finishing |i>and <i|cutting |i>rhyme; this is likely *
                                     *a paronomasia (pun) of a sort. The use of this figure of speech explains the abrupt transition to the sentence which follows.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|problem-causing rock|i>…Lit: <i|a stone of stumbling|i> [<i|Skandalon, |i>(σκάνδαλον/Strong’s 4625)]. The word <i|skandalon |i>is used in *
                                     *the LXX to refer to the hostile nations which surrounded Israel and harassed her; its meaning is based on this usage. Ref. note of Matt. 18:6.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|it/him|i>…It can mean either or both, as the GT is ambiguous. Perhaps when the OT was written, it was taken to mean <i|it|i>, as the antec*
                                     *edent <i|it |i>is <i|stone|i>, an inanimate object. But as Paul’s writing in the time of fulfillment of this prophecy, it’s known that the rock is a <*
                                     *i|he, |i>namely Christ. So Paul may have been intentionally putting this ambiguity to good use.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|comrades|i>…Lit: <i|brothers|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|in which they arrive at an understanding of what they’re doing|i>…Lit: <i|according to an arrived-at understanding|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|puts an end to|i>…Lit: <i|is an end of|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|he’ll stake his life on them|i>…Or: <i|he’ll be consumed by obeying them|i>; <i|he’ll suffer the consequences of them|i>. Lit: <i|he shall*
                                     * live with them|i>. An idiom, the meaning of which isn’t entirely certain.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|Old Testament|i>…Lit: <i|Scripture|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|in it|i>…Or: <i|in him|i>. Ref. note of 9:33.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|non-Jewish Westerners|i>…Lit: <i|Greeks|i>. Ref. note of 2:9.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|the Lord’s authority and reputation for|i> <i|being favorably inclined|i> …Lit: <i|the name of the Lord|i>. The “name of the Lord” is a bi*
                                     *blical idiom.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|civilized world|i>…Lit<i|: inhabited world|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|over|i>…Lit: <i|at|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|Don’t say in your heart, “Who will ascend into heaven” (that is, to bring Christ down), or, “Who will descend into the abyss (i.e., the wo*
                                     *rld of the dead; the place of eternal identity-loss)” (that is, to bring Christ up out of the world of the dead)|i>…This summarizes the two principal *
                                     *heresies of Christ: the first is “who will ascend into heaven to bring Christ down.” This is the view that Christ never became flesh and blood; that h*
                                     *e is God’s son, but he’s always been up in heaven and always will be. Though he’s the son of God, he’s inaccessible to us; too high up for us; not abl*
                                     *e to and never has come down to our level. The second is “who will descend into the abyss to bring Christ up out of it.” This view says that Jesus was*
                                     * a man, but was subject to the same demise of any other human being. Although he lived an inspiring life, he’s dead now like any other person is. Esse*
                                     *ntially, he’s no use to anyone anymore since he was mortal like us, but now he’s dead and can’t help anyone anymore.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|spoken-word|i>…Gk: <i|rhema |i>(ῥῆμα/Strong’s 4487). <i|Rhema |i>is a form of the Gk. word <i|logos |i>(λόγος/Strong’s 3056)<i|; |i>it app*
                                     *ears to be derived from an aorist participle from the verb form of <i|logos, |i>which is <i|legō |i>(λέγω/Strong’s 3004)<i|. |i>The lexicon definition*
                                     * of <i|rhema |i>is “that which is or has been uttered by the living voice; the thing spoken” (Thayer’s); “that which is said, word, statement, express*
                                     *ion, or statement of any kind” (Danker & Bauer). To add to the note of John 1:1, a note which explains the meaning of <i|logos, |i>it can be viewed as*
                                     * the comprehensive body of thought on a subject matter the ancient Greeks captured in a book (a scroll). Thus, the great philosophers wrote treatises *
                                     *on everything from science to politics. These treatises were the logos for a subject, the written word on that subject. On the other hand, a rhema is *
                                     *a spoken word on a subject, as indicated by its usage in Heb. 12:20. Since it’s spoken and not written, one infers a few things about it. First, it is*
                                     *n’t a comprehensive erudition on a subject. For this reason, John called Jesus the Logos and not the Rhema. Second, since it’s spoken, it’s applied to*
                                     * a particular situation at a particular point in time; it’s the logos applied in real-time; it’s a specific application of the logos. Third, the rhema*
                                     * spoken about in v. 8 the “word of faith” is the word which is “in your mouth and in your heart” and is spoken out “of faith.” Rhema is the logos, the*
                                     * written word, planted in one’s heart and spoken out of one’s mouth. The promise given in v. 9 is that anyone who speaks such a rhema about Jesus bein*
                                     *g Lord and God raising him from the dead is guaranteed to receive the promise, in this passage, to be saved.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|word of faith|i>…This phrase in v. 8 is where the Word of Faith movement gets its name from. The Word of Faith movement says that this pas*
                                     *sage here in Rom. 10 is a general principle of faith—an important one—one which applies not only to being saved (v. 9), but to any and all promise in *
                                     *the Bible.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|Oh, how beautiful are the feet (i.e., the course and direction of the lives) of those|i>…Feet in the Bible are a metonymy for the directio*
                                     *n one’s life is headed in; his decision to follow a certain path; his tendency to do so; his consistency in sticking to it.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|word of Christ|i>…The Textus Receptus and other manuscripts say <i|word of God|i>, but the manuscript support for <i|word of Christ |i>is *
                                     *stronger than for <i|word of God. |i>The Gk. word <i|rhema |i>(ῥῆμα/Strong’s 4487)is used for <i|word |i>here and throughout the chapter. By using <i|*
                                     *rhema |i>repeatedly, Paul refers to the same concept throughout the chapter. Also, Paul writes <i|the faith |i>at the beginning of v. 17 rather than s*
                                     *imply <i|faith |i>(no definite article). The use of the definite article before <i|faith |i>means that Paul’s continuing his train of thought and refe*
                                     *rring to the same principle of faith and the word that he started in v. 8.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|Don’t become too big for your britches/too big for your boots|i>…Lit: <i|Don’t become thinking with yourselves|i>. This appears to be an i*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|acceptable|i>…Since the same Gk. word for <i|acceptable |i>is used in here in v. 2 as was used in v. 1, the meaning of <i|acceptable |i>as*
                                     * it appears in v. 2 takes on the same meaning as was used in v. 1, where in that verse it refers to the requirements specified in the Law of Moses for*
                                     * the sacrificial animal to be offered at the temple. The acceptable will of God is therefore one which meets the set of minimum requirements.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|God has allocated an area of responsibility for every person|i>…Lit: <i|God as apportioned to each person a portion of trust|i>. The Gk. w*
                                     *ord for <i|faith|i> [<i|pistis|i>, (πίστις/Strong’s 4102)] also means <i|trust|i>. A similar word <i|pistos |i>means <i|faithful |i>or <i|trustworthy.*
                                     *|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|gifts|i>…There’s more than one NT Gk. word rendered <i|gift|i>;<i| |i>the one used in this verse is <i|charisma, |i>which is obviously der*
                                     *ived from the word <i|charis |i>[<i|grace,|i>(χάρις/Strong’s 5485)]; Paul uses both here, exemplifying and reinforcing the relationship between the tw*
                                     *o. To quote Max & Mary, a <i|charisma |i>is “a gift of God’s grace, for the benefit of the community.” A charisma is a gift that’s given by the grace *
                                     *of the giver (also, ref. note of Acts 8:20). It’s given irrevocably. The recipient did not and cannot earn it. The Greek word <i|dōron |i>(δῶρον/Stron*
                                     *g’s 1435)<i|, |i>which in general means <i|gift |i>as we know the word in English<i|, |i>is also used when describing the gift offerings given to God;*
                                     * the implication is that the gift is given based on the worthiness of the recipient; the obligation to give.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|overarching authorities|i>…The overarching authorities are a synecdoche for the entire authority structure from the top on down.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|the wherewithal to forcibly and violently impose their will upon you—and won’t hesitate to use it|i>…Lit: <i|don’t bear the sword in vain|*
                                     *i>. <i|The sword|i> is a metonymy for the arms that the law enforcement agencies use, and also includes their coordinated efforts when using them. Thi*
                                     *s is not only the use of violence to arrest criminals but to imprison them as well. Furthermore, that the violence is deadly violence: this verse says*
                                     * that law enforcement agents and the criminal justice system have the right, the ability, and the responsibility to inflict deadly violence up to the *
                                     *point of killing a criminal, not only while arresting him but as the sentence for the crime committed. *

HEADING1                             *1 Corinthians*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *The inhabitants of the Greek city of Corinth were better educated and more affluent than most of Paul’s other churches, and the contents of his letter*
                                     *s to the Corinthians show a church which is a mixture of polar extremes, of extremes in spirituality and carnality; extremes in maturity and immaturit*
                                     *y; extremes in fervency and apathy. The list goes on. But perhaps more than any other NT church, the church at Corinth was most like the church in the*
                                     * modern West, and for this reason when one reads the epistle, it’s as though Paul had us in mind specifically when he wrote it.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Paul’s many talents are on display in this letter. He’s not just a lofty theologian, but he can handle difficult people, doing so with a mixture of en*
                                     *couragement, rebuke, and reasoning. He appeals to their best side, he chastises them when their bad side dominates. But he never forgets to remind the*
                                     *m that they’re specially chosen people.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *The rich variety of content in this letter, and the great chapter on love, the chapters on the gifts of the Spirits, the chapter on death and resurrec*
                                     *tion are simply the highlights, reflects the breadth of the Corinthians’ spirituality. If we today are Corinth, then by proxy we are the recipients of*
                                     * a rich epistle, and this should give us hope.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|melded|i>…Lit: <i|in|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|Peter’s|i>…Lit: <i|Cephas’s|i>. <i|Cephas|i> is the Aramaic word for <i|Rock; |i>the Gk. translation of <i|Cephas|i> is <i|Peter|i>. John *
                                     *makes a point of quoting Jesus when he gave Peter his new name (John 1:42). Paul’s preference of the Aramaic name <i|Cephas|i> over the Gk. name <i|Pe*
                                     *ter|i> shows his respect for Peter, a respect rooted in Jesus having named him, which is determining who he is and what he’s about.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|absolutely sure|i>…Lit: <i|know|i>. The Gk. word for <i|know |i>used here means knowing something to be a fact by observing that it’s so; *
                                     *therefore, Paul’s talking about knowing something for certain. He apparently can’t recall for certain who he baptized and who he didn’t. One can infer*
                                     * that he baptized a lot of people.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|Christ didn’t send me to go about baptizing in order to build a camp of my own followers but to go about evangelizing instead|i>…Lit: <i|C*
                                     *hrist didn’t send me to go about baptizing but to go about evangelizing instead|i>. An example of the necessity of adding select interpolations; in th*
                                     *is case the phrase <i|in order to build a camp of my own followers |i>is not in the GT. One surmises from the context that Paul assumed that the reade*
                                     *r would supply these words. Not adding this phrase makes Paul’s statement oxymoronic at face value. Evangelization, when successful, results in people*
                                     * receiving Christ, and those who receive Christ should be baptized. Therefore, successful evangelization results in baptism; you cannot have the one w*
                                     *ithout the other. Since Paul was sent as an apostle to evangelize the Gospel, he must’ve been sent to baptize (either himself personally or someone wo*
                                     *rking with him) them as well.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|comrades|i>…Lit: <i|brothers|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|with a powerful demonstration of the Spirit that’s difficult to describe if you’ve never experienced it|i>…Lit: <i|with |i>[or <i|in|i>]<i*
                                     *| Spirit and power|i>. A hendiadys. Ref. note of Matt. 3:11.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|intimate details and intentions|i>…Lit: <i|those things|i>. As “those things” is vague, it means a number of different things.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|lacking vigor and strength and downright fearful, and was frequently trembling|i>…Lit: <i|in weakness and in fear and in much trembling|i>*
                                     *. Judging based on the context, Paul was exhibiting weakness and fear when speaking to the Corinthians—not when preaching publicly. The reason he was *
                                     *in weakness and fear was out of reverence for the message of Christ crucified accompanied by a strong presence of the Holy Spirit, which presence was *
                                     *manifesting itself (“demonstration of the Spirit”) in the gifts and miracles (the “power of God”) listed in the twelfth chapter. Paul made himself sma*
                                     *ller so as to not quench the Holy Spirit (1 Thess. 5:19), so as to give the Holy Spirit greater license to manifest his power. As we know from the NT,*
                                     * Paul was not naturally like this; on the contrary, he was the opposite. But the Corinthians put such a high premium on speakers with great oratory sk*
                                     *ills, those who speak persuasively and compellingly and who have great charisma and flamboyant personalities, that they viewed Paul with disdain.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|of the Spirit consisting of the fitting together nicely of Holy Spirit-related content with other Holy Spirit-related content…Lit: of Spir*
                                     *it, spirituals to spirituals combining|i>…Literal Gk: <i|pneumatos pneumatikois pneumatika sunkrinontes |i>[πνεύματος, πνευματικοῖς πνευματικὰ συγκρίν*
                                     *οντες, (πνεύματος/Strong’s 4151), (πνευματικοῖς/Strong’s 4152), (πνευματικὰ/Strong’s 4152), (συγκρίνοντες/Strong’s 4793)]. Note that the word <i|spiri*
                                     *tual |i>refers to the Holy Spirit. The successive words <i|pneumatos pneumatikois pneumatika|i> comprise an alliteration, rhyme, assonance, or pun of *
                                     *a sort, and it’s possible that Paul personally coined it. The word <i|sunkrinontes |i>means <i|combining; putting together so that they fit together w*
                                     *ell; drawing a conclusion by comparing|i>. Now, there is ambiguity as to whether <i|pneumatos |i>and<i| pneumatikois, |i>which are different forms of *
                                     *the same word <i|spirituals|i>, means <i|spiritual things |i>or <i|people who are spiritual. |i>The ambiguity permits the following renderings to be d*
                                     *efensible: <i|combining spiritual things with spiritual things; combining spiritual things with spiritual people;|i> <i|combining spiritual people wit*
                                     *h spiritual people; explaining spiritual things in spiritual terms; interpreting spiritual things in spiritual terms; interpreting spiritual things to*
                                     * spiritual people. |i>Such cases of ambiguity are resolved by the context and by how the words or phrases in question are used elsewhere, particularly*
                                     * if by the same author.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|A person who’s dominated by his mind, intellect, or emotions|i> <i|instead of by his spirit…|i>Lit: <i|a soulish-man|i>. The word <i|souli*
                                     *sh |i>is derivative of the word <i|soul |i>[<i|psuchā|i>, (ψυχή/Strong’s 5590)], where we get the word <i|psyche|i>. It refers to the mind, intellect,*
                                     * and emotions. The psyche and the spirit are two distinct and different parts of a person (ref. 1 Thess. 5:23; Heb. 4:12). Translations usually render*
                                     * <i|soulish |i>as <i|natural|i>, referring to a person who goes about life looking and acting as though the spiritual world doesn’t exist, as though t*
                                     *here’s no existence after death, etc. Also, ref. note of 1 Thess. 2:8.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|physically-speaking but present spiritually-speaking|i>…Lit: <i|in body but present in spirit|i>, or, <i|in body but present in the Spirit*
                                     *|i>. The ambiguity of whether it’s <i|in spirit |i>or <i|in the Spirit |i>is rendered <i|in spirit |i>because of the parallelism of <i|in body, |i>and*
                                     * also the phrase <i|the spirit of mine |i>in v.4. The argument on the flip side of the coin, to mean <i|in the Spirit:|i> <i|in the spirit |i>with the*
                                     * explicit inclusion of the definite article the majority of the time refers to the Holy Spirit.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|will avoid utter calamity when the Lord “settles all Family business” so-to-speak|i>…Lit: <i|will be saved in the Day of the Lord|i>. The *
                                     *<i|Day of the Lord |i>is the same as when Michael Corleone tells Carlo “Today I settled all Family business” in <i|The Godfather|i>—but of course, the*
                                     * Lord judges in righteousness, but the Don did not. The Day of the Lord is the swift, sudden, violent, decisive judgment upon those who obviously dese*
                                     *rve it, who, from a human perspective, should’ve received it earlier. Paul refers to the Day of the Lord in 1 Thess. 5:2, the concept originating fore*
                                     *most from Joel (Joel 1:15; 2:1,11,31; 3:14) but occurs in other OT books as well (Amos 5:20; Zeph. 1:7; Zech. 14:1).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|partake of the Passover meal|i>…Lit: <i|celebrate|i>. The Gk. word <i|celebrate|i> is a verb form of the Gk. word rendered <i|festival|i>,*
                                     * which in addition to meaning <i|festival |i>refers to religious observances which aren’t accompanied by festivity, including simple meals like the Pa*
                                     *ssover meal. But this verse demonstrates the metaphor Paul draws comparing Christians to the unleavened bread used in the Passover unleavened bread (m*
                                     *atzah). Starting with Moses commanding the Israelites to purge every spec of yeast from the entire nation and eat matzah instead of real bread for the*
                                     * Passover, yeast and bread infected by it symbolize sin, impurity, and the tendency for attitudes—sinful ones in particular—to spread.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|greedy and rapacious|i>…A hendiadys perhaps. The Gk. word for <i|greedy |i>means <i|to want more and more|i>; the Gk. word for <i|rapaciou*
                                     *s |i>means <i|grabbing|i> <i|or|i> <i|seizing things|i>. Also, Paul associates greed, fornication, and idolatry in this verse and in Eph. 5:3,5; there*
                                     * are more references in the NT as well. These sins are interrelated.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|I wrote to you just now|i>…Lit: <i|I wrote to you now|i>. Paul says <i|I wrote |i>instead of <i|I write, |i>using the past tense instead o*
                                     *f the present to refer to what he’s about to write at the end of the sentence. This would make sense if one were to assume that Paul first wrote a dra*
                                     *ft of this epistle, perhaps on wax tablets, made corrections, then copied the edited version onto the scroll which was sent to Corinth.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|catamites|i>…Also<i|: those who are effeminate|i>…Lit: <i|soft to the touch. |i>The commentators aren’t exactly sure what this refers to; *
                                     *some say it refers to a man who lives a soft life—which is reasonable. But considering that the context is egregious sexual sin, and that the other si*
                                     *ns listed in this verse are severe, this word here might refer to men who dress like and behave as though they’re women. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|To me, everything is permissible but not everything is beneficial|i>…Though Paul said that everything is permissible, it’s impossible to a*
                                     *ccept this statement at face-value, as he lists a few things in this chapter which are not permissible for anyone to do, stealing and being covetous f*
                                     *or example. How is this logical dilemma to be solved? Paul is stating his perspective—his philosophy—on whether he will engage in an activity or not. *
                                     *Rather than looking at some deed as permissible or forbidden, he changes the perspective to look at whether said deed is beneficial or non-beneficial.*
                                     * The understanding is that whether it’s permissible or not will logically align with whether it’s beneficial or not. The examples of greed and covetou*
                                     *sness Paul categorizes as non-beneficial, so it’s irrelevant whether they’re permissible or not, since Paul’s not going to do them anyways because the*
                                     *y’re non-beneficial. By this reasoning, whether something is permissible or not is moot. Adopting this perspective goes a long way to resolving the is*
                                     *sue of legalism which inevitably arises in the pursuit of religion.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|all sins that a person happens to commit are done outside the body, but the fornicator commits a sin which is done to (or even into) his o*
                                     *wn body|i>…The reason why fornication differs from all other sins, being a sin done to your body, is given in the previous verses: a fornicator unites*
                                     * his body with the person he commits the act with, and the two become a single body. When a couple is united sexually, their bodies merge into one bod*
                                     *y. Merging your body with someone who’s trash causes your body to be corrupted by the trash from the other body.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|a temple which is a dwelling-place for the Holy Spirit to dwell in, thereby living among us|i>…Lit: <i|a temple among us of |i>[<i|the|i>]*
                                     *<i| Holy Spirit|i>. According to Gk. grammar, the placement of <i|among us |i>between the two phrases <i|a temple |i>and <i|of the Holy Spirit |i>indi*
                                     *cates the tight coupling of the phrase <i|among us |i>to the other two phrases. So Paul’s saying that our bodies form a temple and within this temple *
                                     *the Holy Spirit dwells. The analogy is the temple of Jerusalem in which God’s presence dwelled in the Holy of Holies.*

                                     *ronoun <i|oneself |i>inserted between the definite article and the word <i|virgin |i>selects <i|virginity, |i>a secondary meaning of the Gk. word for *
                                     *<i|virgin. |i>Note Paul’s careful insertion of the reflexive pronoun both here and in v. 38.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|to go about touching a woman for the purpose of instigating|i>…First, the Gk. verb for<i| touch |i>[<i|haptō|i>, (ἅπτω/Strong’s 681)] appe*
                                     *ars in the present tense, insinuating continuous action rather than a one-time act—hence the added phrase <i|go about touching|i>. Second, this verb i*
                                     *s unusual in that it has one meaning when used in the active voice (<i|to light on fire) |i>and another meaning when used in the middle voice (<i|to t*
                                     *ouch|i>). Since the active voice is the primary tense, the meaning in the middle voice influenced by a hint of the meaning from the active voice. Most*
                                     * of the NT occurrences of this verb are in the middle voice, and they not only mean <i|to touch |i>but also acquire some of the active voice’s definit*
                                     *ion to more specifically mean <i|to touch for the purpose of instigating something. |i>This verb is used when Jesus touches someone to heal them; he t*
                                     *ouched the person but did so for a purpose. What is “lit on fire” so-to-speak is determined by the context, and the context of v. 1 here insinuates to*
                                     *uching sexually. To further reinforce the point that <i|haptō |i>means more than a simple touch, take a close look at Col. 2:21. Note how <i|haptō |i>*
                                     *appears in that passage with <i|thigganō |i>(θιγγάνω/Strong’s 2345)<i|. |i>They both mean <i|to touch |i>but thigganō<i| |i>means touching without ins*
                                     *tigating anything; to touch lightly; to brush up against something. Had they meant the same thing, Paul wouldn’t have used two different verbs.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|leave|i>…<i|divorce|i>…Different Gk. words are used for <i|leave |i>and <i|divorce |i>here; we infer from this verse here and from other N*
                                     *T references (such as Matt. 5:31) that, in ancient times, only the husband had the right to instigate a legal divorce. A wife, however, would at times*
                                     * simply leave her husband without fulfilling the legalities of a divorce. This might explain the two different words used here.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|God has called us to live in peace (i.e., live free of the conflict, duress, or affliction that many unbelieving spouse brings)|i> <i|what*
                                     *ever our situation might be|i>…Lit: <i|God has called us in|i> [or: <i|with|i>; <i|by|i>] <i|peace|i>. Apparently, “God has called us to live in peace*
                                     *” means that it’s not God’s will for a Christian to be married to a person who’s violent, who’s abusive, who’s reckless, who’s irresponsible to the po*
                                     *int of it causing harm to the family, etc. Notice that it says “God has called us to live in peace,” and not “God has called us to be happy” (Christia*
                                     *ns shouldn’t necessarily be “happy” but they should have joy). In other words, this isn’t a license for a person to divorce simply because he’s unhapp*
                                     *y. But it is a license for a Christian who was married before he became a Christian to divorce an unbelieving spouse if that spouse is causing trouble*
                                     *.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|have each person lead his life in the way that the Lord deems appropriate for the particular situation he was in when he became a believer*
                                     *|i>…Lit: <i|as the Lord partitioned|i> [<i|an inheritance|i>] <i|each as God has called|i>…Or: <i|as the Lord partitioned|i> [<i|an inheritance|i>] <i*
                                     *|as God has called each|i>. Some guesswork as to what exactly Paul was saying. He seems to be making a comparison to dividing an inheritance, the inhe*
                                     *ritance being a biblical theme that refers to the specific plans God has for an individual or a particular group, plans which are bespoke for that per*
                                     *son or group.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|Don’t obliterate the effects of circumcision|i>…What Paul meant by this can be seen in his own life. Paul used the fact that he was circum*
                                     *cised to his advantage from time to time, as he writes later in 9:22, “I am made all things to all men, that I might by all means save some.” Examples*
                                     * are found in Acts 18:18, 21:23–29.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|overly-ripe|i>…Or: <i|beyond her prime|i>…Lit: <i|beyond peak|i>. The passage of vv. 36–38 has puzzled translators, and every rendering is*
                                     * not without criticism. To a large extent it hinges on what <i|beyond peak |i>means in this context. Some believe it means that the virgin woman is <i*
                                     *|beyond her prime |i>in age, but the meaning of <i|beyond peak |i>which best fits the context is a woman who’s pregnant and beginning to show or perha*
                                     *ps or is a woman who’s late in her monthly cycle.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|their conscience are weak|i>. In his epistles, Paul talks about four types of consciences: a good conscience, an evil conscience, a weak c*
                                     *onscience, and a seared conscience. A person’s conscience is something that affirms when he’s doing right but condemns when he does wrong. From this c*
                                     *ontext, we can deduce that a weak conscience is one which has been programmed with an incorrect understanding of the truth and therefore misfires, sen*
                                     *ding the wrong signals for the wrong reasons, causing a person to experience guilt over something he shouldn’t and not experience it over something he*
                                     * should. *
