FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|the blood-descendants of the twelve tribes of Israel|i> …Lit: <i|twelve tribes|i>. The phrase twelve tribes is a metonymy for all Israelit*
                                     *es. By specifying the twelve tribes, James makes the distinction between the Jewish believers and the Gentile believers. Since James’s authority is ov*
                                     *er the church in Jerusalem, and perhaps all of Israel, he extends his pastoral care to all believing Israelites who for one reason or another are loca*
                                     *ted outside of Israel but nevertheless are Jewish like those living in Israel. At the time this epistle was written, there were more Jews outside of I*
                                     *srael than there were in Israel. But the schism in the early church between the Jewish and the non-Jewish believers would naturally cause the Jewish b*
                                     *elievers living outside of Israel to gravitate towards and affiliate with James.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|advise him to|i>…<i|admonish him to|i>…<i|adjust|i>…<i|get|i>…<i|make sure that|i>…etc…Lit: <i|have|i> [or <i|let|i>] <i|him|i>. James use*
                                     *s this third-person imperative form of the Gk. verb in a parallel fashion as a figure of speech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|likewise get the rich man to practice humility and self-abasement|i>…Lit: <i|the rich man in his humiliation|i>. (The interpolations are j*
                                     *ustified by the parallel construction.) Before making generalizations about the wealthy based on this verse, one should first read James 2:6–7; 5:1–6 *
                                     *and understand that the “rich man” of that passage is the same “rich man” in v. 10,11 here. Though there’s a tendency for wealthy people to be abusive*
                                     *, not all of them are. But all of them are reminded to stay humble.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|wild flowers of the field|i>…Lit: <i|grass|i>. Max and Mary claim that in this context this refers to wild flowers and not grass and that *
                                     *this is a picture of fragility from the OT (ref. Is. 40:6; Ps. 103:15*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|trophy of a deeply satisfying |i>life…Lit: <i|crown|i> [<i|victor’s wreath|i>] <i|of life|i>. This is a metaphor where obtaining a deeply *
                                     *satisfying life by persevering through trials is compared to a victor being awarded the victor’s wreath. The word <i|life|i> leans on the definition J*
                                     *esus put forth in John 6:53, “if you won’t eat the Man’s flesh and drink his blood, you don’t have life within you.” In the next verse Jesus goes on t*
                                     *o talk about eternal life, which is that special fullness of life that God gives. By this reasoning, the word <i|life |i>in v. 12 here does not refer *
                                     *to physical existence but rather is the same concept of life and eternal life which Jesus taught. What James is saying is that perseverance through tr*
                                     *ials and temptations results in a deep richness to one’s life.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|conceived|i>…Same word used in Luke 1:24 when Elizabeth managed to become pregnant, insinuating a bit that this was only achieved after so*
                                     *me difficulty. A few words later in this verse, James says <i|gives birth to sin|i>, where the word <i|give birth |i>is just that—a woman giving birth*
                                     *.<i| |i>This verse is a metaphor where temptation is compared to a man who impregnates a woman (i.e. a person) and she conceives a child sin and gives*
                                     * birth to it.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|Creator of Astronomical Objects (i.e. the sun, the moon, the stars, etc.), with whom there is no deviation in the movement of such objects*
                                     * and no hint or suggestion of change to them|i>…Lit: <i|Father of Lights, with whom there is no variation or shadow of changing|i>. The same Gk. word *
                                     *for <i|lights |i>used here in v. 17 is the same Gk. word used in Gen. 1:16 in the LXX, “And God made the two great lights…”; therefore, the “lights” J*
                                     *ames refers to are the sun, the moon, and every other celestial object which emits light. The word <i|shadow |i>used in this verse is similar in meani*
                                     *ng to the way it’s used in Heb. 10:1; i.e., it’s not a physical shadow but rather an imperfect representation of another object. The Gk. words for<i| *
                                     *variation |i>and <i|changing |i>are astronomical terms. In addition, it’s been known since ancient times that the movement of the planets, the rotatio*
                                     *n of the earth, etc. are extremely precise and entirely predictable. Therefore, James is saying that the same God who put into place such precision wi*
                                     *ll apply the same precision to His gift-giving.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[H]|s><i|forgot what he looks like|i>…James is describing what we all experience on a daily basis. While you’re looking in the mirror, you know exa*
                                     *ctly what you look like, but the moment you step away, you immediately forget what that was no matter how long you were staring into the mirror. Let’s*
                                     * say a woman looks in a mirror to see how her hair looks. She’ll step away, worry that this lock or that braid doesn’t quite match her outfit, then st*
                                     *ep back up to the mirror and look at herself again. Why did she step back to the mirror a second time?—Because she forgot what she looked like.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[I]|s><i|thinks that he strictly adheres to the do’s and don’ts of his religion|i>…Lit: <i|thinks to be religious|i>. Some liberties taken. The wor*
                                     *d <i|religious |i>insinuates the rituals performed by the Jews. This insinuation is confirmed by the selection of words James uses in v. 27, namely <i*
                                     *|pure |i>[<i|undefiled|i>] and <i|unstained|i>, which smack of Jewish religious purification rituals.*

HEADING2                             *James Chapter 2*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|1|s>My comrades, don’t have a faith in our Lord of Glory Jesus Christ which shows favoritism. <s|2|s>If a powerful businessman<s|[a]|s> wearing an *
                                     *expensive suit<s|[b]|s> were to join your synagogue<s|[c]|s>, and a poor man in ragged<s|[d]|s> clothing were to join, <s|3|s>you’d be naturally incli*
                                     *ned to favor the fellow in the expensive suit and tell him, “Let’s make sure you’re seated up front in the reserved section where all the important pe*
                                     *ople sit<s|[A]|s>,” and you would tell the poor guy, “Stand against the wall in the back or sit where the usher sits and be ready to fill in for him a*
                                     *nd run an errand when we call<s|[A]|s>.” <s|4|s>Have you not shown bias towards those among you, preferring one person over another, and have you not *
                                     *become decision-makers<s|[e]|s> whose thought process consists of really bad, downright evil, things?*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|5|s>Listen, my dear comrades: Hasn’t God chosen the world’s poor to be rich in faith and to get their individual slice of God’s involvement with th*
                                     *e human race<s|[f]|s>, which He promised to those who love Him? <s|6|s>But you’ve treated the poor with contempt. Don’t the rich oppress you and drag *
                                     *you into court? <s|7|s>Don’t they cuss at, slander, and revile your excellent, <i|hard-earned|i> reputation<s|[B]|s>? <s|8|s>If there really is a perf*
                                     *ect regal code <i|which we live by|i> and if the code is based on the Bible verse <i|which says|i>, “Love your neighbor as yourself,” <i|then|i> you’r*
                                     *e on the right track<s|[g]|s>. <s|9|s>But if you show favoritism, you’re committing a sin and are incriminated by the Law <i|of Moses|i>. <s|10|s>In f*
                                     *act, that particular individual who’s willingly trying to keep the Law but falls short<s|[h]|s> in one area is guilty of violating it as a whole.*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|11|s>Here’s an example: <i|the same Old Testament Law which |i>said “Don’t commit adultery” also said “Don’t commit murder.” Now if you didn’t comm*
                                     *it adultery but committed murder, you <i|nevertheless |i>became a Law-violator, <i|violating the Law as a whole even though you violated just one part*
                                     * of it|i>. <s|12|s>Talk and behave as though as though you’re going to be held to a standard defined by freedom’s code and judged by it. <s|13|s>You s*
                                     *ee, the judgment <i|that you will eventually face |i>will be merciless towards those who won’t show mercy. Mercy trumps judgment.*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|14|s>What benefit is it, my comrades, if (<i|using|i> <i|some person|i> <i|for the purpose of illustration|i>) this person says he has faith but ha*
                                     *s no actions <i|which normally accompany it|i>? That <i|sort of so-called|i> faith<s|[D]|s> won’t pull him out <i|of a bad situation|i><s|[i]|s>, will*
                                     * it? <s|15|s>If a comrade were to find himself or herself having no clothing whatsoever to protect his or her body with and lacking minimum-sustenance*
                                     * food, <s|16|s>and if you were to tell him, “See you later, take care now<s|[j]|s>. Stay warm and get plenty to eat,” but not provide physical necessi*
                                     *ties for him, what good is that? <s|17|s>The <i|sort of |i>faith<i| we’re talking about here |i>is the same way: if it were to not have actions <i|whi*
                                     *ch normally accompany it|i>, it would be<s|[k]|s> void of life, being <i|in a state which is|i> consistent with itself.*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|18|s>Putting that aside now—someone is bound to say, “You have faith <i|but no actions to go along with it|i> and I have actions <i|but no faith to*
                                     * go along with them|i>.” Show me your <i|kind of |i>faith apart from the actions <i|which normally accompany it|i>, and I’ll show you the <i|genuine k*
                                     *ind of |i>faith from out of my actions. <s|19|s>You believe that there is <i|only|i> one <i|true|i> God <i|and that|i> <i|He is|i> <i|of one mind and *
                                     *has His own will, and there is no other being comparable to Him|i><s|[E]|s>? Good job. The demons believe it as well and quiver in their boots over it*
                                     *<s|[l]|s>.*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|20|s>Oh you nit-wit—were you interested in knowing that the <i|sort of|i> faith <i|which is|i> apart from <i|actions which normally accompany it |i*
                                     *>amounts to nothing<s|[m]|s>? <s|21|s>Wasn’t our patriarch Abraham made right in God’s sight<s|[n]|s> from actions after offering his son Isaac upon t*
                                     *he altar? <s|22|s><i|In the case of Abraham offering Isaac|i>, one sees that the <i|genuine sort of|i> faith operates together with its <i|accompanyin*
                                     *g |i>actions and comes to fruition out of the actions. <s|23|s>The verse of Scripture was fulfilled which says, “Abraham believed in God, and it wound*
                                     * up being credited to him as righteousness,” and he was called a friend and close-companion of God. <s|24|s>Observe that a person is made right in God*
                                     *’s sight as the result of actions and not by faith on its own.<s|[F]|s> <s|25|s>Wasn’t the prostitute Rahab made right in God’s sight the same way—as *
                                     *the result of actions—cooperating with the agents and hurrying them out another way? <s|26|s>For as the body is dead <i|when it is |i>apart from a spi*
                                     *rit, in the same way the <i|genuine sort of |i>faith apart from works is dead too.*
SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|a powerful businessman|i>…Lit: <i|a gold-ringed man|i>. <i|Gold-ringed|i> is a synecdoche. The ring on the man’s finger is a signet ring, *
                                     *a ring used for making sizeable purchases or validating transactions.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|wearing an expensive suit|i>…Lit: <i|in bright clothes|i>. Some liberties taken. Only the rich and noblemen wore bright clothing. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|join your synagogue|i>…Lit: <i|enter into your synagogue|i>. An idiom; ref. note of Acts 19:8.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|ragged|i>…Lit: <i|filthy-dirty|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|decision-makers|i>…Lit: <i|judges|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|get their own individual slice of God’s involve with the human race|i>…Lit: <i|inheritors of the kingdom|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|then you’re on the right track|i>…Lit: <i|you do well|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|falls short|i>…Lit: <i|stumbles|i>. A less-common word for <i|stumble |i>[<i|patiō|i>,(πταίω/Strong’s 4417)] than the one usually used [<i*
                                     *|skandalon|i>, (σκάνδαλον/Strong’s 4625)], but both are Gk. renderings of the OT word <i|stumble. |i>Ref. note of Matt. 11:6.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|pull him out of a bad situation|i>…Lit: <i|save him|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|See you later, take care now|i>…Lit: <i|Go forth in peace|i>. A common parting remark.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|would be|i>…Lit: is. A grammatical error made by James, presumably.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|quiver in their boots over it|i>…Lit: <i|shudder|i>. Some liberties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|amounts to nothing|i>…Lit: <i|idle|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|made right in God’s sight|i>…Lit: <i|justified|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|Let’s make sure you’re seated up front in the reserved section where all the important people sit|i>…<i|Stand against the wall in the back*
                                     * or sit where the usher sits and be ready to fill in for him and run an errand when we call|i>…Lit: <i|Sit here good|i>…<i|Stand there or sit under my*
                                     * footstool|i>. Liberties taken. Unlike modern times, in ancient times, people at an event were not seated randomly but were seated in seats that were *
                                     *arranged so that one could tell their importance at the function by the location of the seat in proximity to whatever is the center. Also, the phrase *
                                     *<i|sit under my footstool|i> is a NT expression which means that such person is subordinate to whomever he’s seated under.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|cuss at, slander, and revile your excellent, hard-earned reputation|i>…Lit: <i|blaspheme the beautiful name|i> [or<i| excellent reputation*
                                     *|i>]<i| that’s been given as a surname to you|i>. Many scholars assume that James is talking about blaspheming God’s name, but a literal interpretatio*
                                     *n does not support this assumption.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|perfect regal code|i>…Lit: <i|perfect royal law|i>. James 1:25 “perfect law” refers to this same concept. The perfect law transcends the l*
                                     *egalistic practice of the Law of Moses and lays down a better, perfect, and higher code of conduct, the same one that Jesus talked about in the Sermon*
                                     * on the Mount when he said, “It is written but I say.”*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|That sort of faith|i>…Lit<i|: the faith|i>. In the Gk. James adds the definite article before the word <i|faith |i>to indicate that he’s t*
                                     *alking about a specific type of so-called faith. He adds a <i|the |i>before <i|faith |i>in in various places in the passage of v. 14–17.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|there is only one true God. He is of one mind and has His own will, and there is no other being comparable to Him|i>…Lit: <i|God is one|i>*
                                     *. Also appears in 1 Cor. 8:4; Rom. 3:29; Gal. 3:20: this is a quotation from Deut. 6:4. The brevity of the statement only enhances its profoundness, a*
                                     *s it speaks to so many things about God. This one statement is the foundation for all Abrahamic religions.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|Observe that a person is made right in God’s sight as the result of actions and not by faith on its own|i>…The passage consisting of vv. 1*
                                     *4–26 has been misunderstood for years, even to the point where Martin Luther refused to include the book of James in his translation of the Bible, as *
                                     *he thought James is promoting a righteousness based on works. He’s not. The point James makes is that genuine faith is always accompanied by works (ac*
                                     *tions) which reflect it and are the result of it. Genuine faith cannot exist without these accompanying actions. This does not mean that if a person m*
                                     *anufactures the actions they necessarily have the works, but it means that the two must go hand-in-hand.*
SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER              
HEADING2                             *James Chapter 3*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|1|s>There should not be a lot of you becoming instructors<s|[A]|s>, my comrades, knowing that we’ll be held to a higher standard<s|[a]|s>. <s|2|s>Y*
                                     *ou see, we all mess up or fall short<s|[b]|s> in many ways. If a given person doesn’t mess up in speech, that fellow has got his act together<s|[c]|s>*
                                     *, able to reign in his entire body<s|[B]|s> as well. <s|3|s>Now we<s|[d]|s> stick bits in the mouths of horses in order to prevail upon them to do our*
                                     * bidding, and <i|in doing so |i>we guide their entire bodies. <s|4|s>Ships too, for example, are gigantic and are propelled by stiff breezes, guided b*
                                     *y the smallest <i|thing imaginable|i>—a rudder—in whatever heading the helmsman selects. <s|5|s>Analogous to this, the tongue is a small part <i|of a *
                                     *much larger unit|i> and makes outrageous remarks<s|[C]|s>.*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *I’m telling you what, <i|it’s like they say: |i>“Just a tiny flame can set even an enormous forest on fire<s|[e]|s>.” <s|6|s>And the tongue is a flame*
                                     * <i|indeed|i>, an elaborate mechanism<s|[f]|s> of wrong-doing—the tongue occupies a position of preeminence<s|[g]|s> among our body parts—the defiler *
                                     *of the entire body and stoker of the Merry-go-round of Life<s|[D]|s>—and is itself stoked by hell.*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|7|s>In fact, human beings by nature tame wild animals. All sorts—land, aquatic, reptilian—are <i|in the process of|i> being tamed and have been tam*
                                     *ed, <s|8|s>but not a single person can tame the restless, unstable tongue, full of deadly poison. <s|9|s>With it we thank the Father-God<s|[h]|s> and *
                                     *with it we swear at <i|our fellow|i> man, those who have been created in the image of God. <s|10|s>Out of the same mouth come thanksgiving and cussing*
                                     *. This is not the way it’s supposed to be, my comrades. <s|11|s>Non-contaminated and contaminated <i|water|i> doesn’t pour out of the same spring, now*
                                     * does it? <s|12|s>It’s not possible, my comrades, for a fig tree to yield olives or a grape vine figs, or for <i|a |i>water<i| source|i> to produce <i*
                                     *|both |i>salt water <i|and|i> fresh water, is it?*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|13|s>Who among you is wise and understanding? Let him display his deeds which come from the good conduct <i|of one who follow’s God’s commandments *
                                     *|i>in wisdom’s gentleness. <s|14|s>But if you have bitter jealousy and rivalry in your heart, don’t distort the truth by bragging and lying<s|[i]|s>. *
                                     *<s|15|s>This is not the same wisdom which comes from the spiritual world where God lives<s|[j]|s>, but <i|is the cunning-sort of wisdom which|i> is <i*
                                     *|among other things |i>ruthlessly pragmatic, psychopathic, and diabolic<s|[E]|s>. <s|16|s>The fact is, where jealousy and rivalry <i|exist|i>, there i*
                                     *s turmoil, and every bad thing imaginable is done<s|[k]|s>. <s|17|s>But the wisdom from the spiritual world where God lives is pure and innocent, then*
                                     * <i|on top of that is |i>peaceful, considerate, reasonable, full of mercy, and without pretense. <s|18|s>The end-result where everything turns out rig*
                                     *ht has its origins<s|[i]|s> in peace by those who put peace into practice.*
SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|we’ll be held to a higher standard|i>…Lit: <i|we will receive a greater judgment|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|mess up or fall short|i>…Lit: <i|stumble|i>. Same word used in James 2:10, see note there.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|that fellow has got his act together|i>…Lit: <i|that man complete|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|Now we|i>…Lit: <i|Now if|i>. Appears to be a mistake in the autograph; some early manuscripts have redacted it out.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s>J<i|ust a tiny flame can even set an enormous forest on fire|i>…Lit: <i|How small a flame how great a forest kindles|i>. In the GT this is: <*
                                     *i|hālikon pur hālikān hulān anaptei |i>(ἡλίκον πῦρ ἡλίκην ὕλην ἀνάπτει). An obvious alliteration/assonance and presumably a commonly-used expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|elaborate mechanism|i>…Lit: <i|a world|i>. Keep in mind that <i|world |i>refers to the established order of mankind more so than the physi*
                                     *cal planet.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|occupies a position of preeminence|i>…Lit: <i|sits|i>. The meaning of the word <i|sits |i>as used in this verse is the same meaning as it’*
                                     *s used in Ps. 110:1.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|Father-God|i>…Lit: <i|God and Father|i>. A commonly-used NT hendiadys.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|distort the truth by bragging and lying|i>…Lit: <i|boast and lie against the truth|i>. Assuming this is an idiom and guessing what the idi*
                                     *om means.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|which comes from the spiritual world where God lives|i>…Lit: <i|coming down from above|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|every bad thing imaginable is done|i>…Lit: <i|all bad deeds|i>. The word <i|all |i>is used as a figure of speech, a hyperbole or metonymy *
                                     *of a sort. Same figure of speech used in 1 Tim. 6:10, “For the love of money is the root of all evil.”*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|the end-result where everything turns out right has its origins|i>…Lit: <i|the fruit of righteousness is sown|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|instructors|i>…Or: <i|teachers|i>. The Gk. word for <i|teacher |i>is both (or either) one who imparts insight and understanding and one wh*
                                     *o gives moral instruction (ref. note of Acts 15:1), telling the pupil how he should conduct his life. In relation to giving moral instruction, it beco*
                                     *mes clear why the instructor must be held to a higher standard.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|reign in his entire body|i>…Lit: <i|able to bridle his entire body|i>. The word <i|bits |i>in v. 3 is derived from the <i|bridle |i>in v. *
                                     *2. This combined with the repetition of the word <i|body |i>in v. 2 and <i|bodies |i>in v. 3 indicates that <i|reign in his entire body |i>is a metaph*
                                     *or which compares controlling one’s body by controlling one’s tongue to controlling a horse’s body by the use of bits. Coincidentally (or perhaps not)*
                                     *, the word <i|body |i>in the NT sometimes means <i|carnal nature. |i>Putting this together, like bridling a horse a person who can control his tongue *
                                     *will be able to bring his carnal nature under control.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|makes outrageous remarks|i>…Lit: <i|boasts great things|i>. The word <i|boasts |i>[<i|aucheo|i>, (αὐχέω/Strong’s 850a)] is used here inste*
                                     *ad of the commonly-used NT word <i|kauchaomai |i>(καυχάομαι/Strong’s 2744). This verse is the only place in the NT that <i|aucheo |i>is found, and the*
                                     * lexicon says that in a general sense it means <i|to protest, declare|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|the Merry-go-round of Life|i>…Or: <i|the Engine of Life|i>…Lit: <i|the Wheel of Origin|i>. James is using the well-known metaphorical conc*
                                     *ept of a wheel, where a wheel represents cycles which keep on repeating themselves. This metaphorical use predates James by centuries, having its root*
                                     *s in astrology and mythology. For example, the term “Wheel of Fortune (Rota Fortunae)” is derived from this same concept.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|among other things ruthlessly pragmatic, psychopathic, and diabolic|i>…Lit: <i|earthly, mental, demonic|i>. <i|Earthly |i>refers to a Mach*
                                     *iavellian-sort of cunning. Keep in mind that the Gk. word for <i|wisdom |i>means both wisdom and cunning. <i|Mental |i>means a wisdom which is mental *
                                     *and emotional in contradiction to being spiritual; is concerned with this life only. It is mental thought which like an animal has, where, for example*
                                     *, an ape can tear apart another ape or eat another ape’s baby and have no remorse for it. <i|Demonic |i>(<i|diabolic|i>)<i| |i>patterns itself after a*
                                     *n evil imp which goes around harassing people.*

HEADING2                             *James Chapter 4*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|1|s>Where do the long, drawn-out quarrels<s|[a]|s> and fights among you come from? Is it not from the pleasurable <i|carnal impulses|i><s|[A]|s> wh*
                                     *ich are a component of your human nature<s|[B]|s>, enlisted in a war against you? <s|2|s>You desire but don’t have <i|anything to show for it|i>—murde*
                                     *r and covet but don’t attain—fight and have long, drawn-out quarrels—You don’t have on account of you not asking. <s|3|s>You ask and don’t receive bec*
                                     *ause you ask <i|with|i> bad <i|intentions|i>, <i|asking for something |i>for the purpose of spending it on your carnal impulses<s|[b]|s>. <s|4|s><i|Sp*
                                     *iritual|i> adulterers, don’t you know that a close friend of the world (<i|i.e. the ungodly society of mankind|i>) is pitted against God? So now, he w*
                                     *ho wishes he were the world’s close friend puts himself in a position<s|[c]|s> where he’s God’s enemy. <s|5|s>Or do you think that the verse of Script*
                                     *ure which says “The Spirit that has taken up residence in us and among us jealously longs and desires <i|for hearts turned towards Him|i><s|[C]|s>” is*
                                     * a waste of time?*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|6|s>Now the Bible lets us off the hook all the more<s|[d]|s>; owing to<i| this |i>it says,*
SPACER_INTER_PROSE                 
VERSES_PROSE                         *God takes a stance against the arrogant, proud, and haughty*
VERSES_PROSE                         *But He lets the humble and abased off the hook<s|[d]|s>*
SPACER_INTER_PROSE                 
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|7|s>So submit to God.<s|[D]|s> Take a stand against the devil and he’ll run away from you. <s|8|s>Draw closer to God, and He’ll draw closer to you.*
                                     * Purge your life from wrong-doing<s|[e]|s>, sinners, and set your hearts apart <i|from impurity|i> and make them holy, <i|you who are |i>double-minded*
                                     *. <s|9|s><i|Recognize your deplorable moral and spiritual condition and |i>become wretched and miserable <i|over it|i>; become deeply sorrowful simila*
                                     *r to the way you would mourn the death of a loved one, and weep. Have your laughter turn into deep sorrow and your joy into gloom. <s|10|s>Humble and *
                                     *abase yourself before the Lord, and he will uplift and exalt you.*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|11|s>Don’t put others down<s|[f]|s> while talking, comrades. He who puts a comrade down or draws conclusions about his comrade so as to write him o*
                                     *ff<s|[g]|s> trashes the rules that govern us and writes them off by his speech<s|[E]|s>. Now if you write a set of rules off, you’re not a practitione*
                                     *r of the rule-set but instead are a person who decides if the rules themselves are right or wrong<s|[h]|s>. <s|12|s>There’s only One who’s lawgiver an*
                                     *d decider<s|[h]|s>, He who’s able to preserve<s|[i]|s> and destroy. Who do you think you are, you who writes off those around you regularly?*
VERSES_NARRATIVE                     *<s|13|s>Come on now, those <i|of you |i>who say “Today or <i|maybe even |i>tomorrow we’ll go to such-and-such town, spend a year there engaged in busi*
                                     *ness, and turn a profit.” <s|14|s>You all are the very people who don’t understand how your lives will turn out given the ups and downs that tomorrow *
                                     *brings<s|[j]|s>. You see, you’re a wisp of steam that appears for a little while then vanishes. <s|15|s>Instead, the statement you should make is, “If*
                                     * it happens to be the Lord’s will, and if we’re still alive, we’ll do this-or-that.” <s|16|s>You’re vaunting at the present time by your pretentious, *
                                     *ostentatious swagger. All such vaunting is evil<s|[k]|s>. <s|17|s>So it’s a sin for him who knows to do good not to do it.*
SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|long, drawn-out quarrels|i>…Lit: <i|wars|i>. A hyperbole.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|carnal impulses|i>…Lit: <i|pleasures|i>. Same word used in v. 1.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|puts himself in a position|i>…Lit: <i|sets|i>. Same word is translated <i|occupies the position|i> in James 3:6.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|lets us off the hook all the more|i>…Lit: <i|gives a greater grace|i> [<i|mercy|i>]*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|purge your life from wrong-doing|i>…Lit: <i|clean|i> [<i|the|i>] <i|hands|i>. An expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|put others down|i>…Or: <i|speaks down on|i> [<i|against|i>] <i|others; trash talks others|i>*

                                     * writing a science textbook.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|you rich people who act like the stereotypical rich|i>…Lit: <i|the rich|i>. The usage of the definite article <i|the |i>means that James i*
                                     *s referring to a stereotype. Not all rich people behave the way James describes, but plenty of them do.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|in this era in which God is doing the great things He promised He’d do|i>…Lit: <i|in the Last Days|i>. The <i|Last Days |i>is an expressio*
                                     *n used throughout the Bible. In the OT it’s the era in which God’s promises come to pass. This usually is not eschatological.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|have secured the attention of the Great Unseen Army Chief of Staff|i>…Lit: <i|have entered into the ear of|i> [<i|the|i>] <i|Lord of Hosts*
                                     *|i>. The common expression <i|enter into the ear |i>paints a picture of gaining the attention of a person who’s difficult to reach because of his limi*
                                     *ted accessibility due to his high position—but it implies that this high-ranking person is disposed to deliberate in a favorable manner. The title <i|*
                                     *Lord of Hosts |i>[<i|the army|i>] appears throughout the OT and naturally refers to God heading his army of angels. Angels in this case symbolize the *
                                     *exercise of God’s supreme power in judgment, and this often takes place when the longsuffering patience of God has been exhausted.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|don’t pledge any oath by the sky|i>…Swearing by something was a common practice in Israel at the time, one which Jesus spoke against in Ma*
                                     *tt. 23:16,17 and other places. This is like the oath Don Corleone made, “I swear on the souls of my grandchildren that I will not be the one to break *
                                     *the peace that we have made here today.”*

HEADING1                             *1 Peter*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *The final one of the multiple faces we see of Peter is contained in his epistle, and it’s hard to imagine them being the same person. The Peter of the*
                                     * Gospels is impulsive; the Peter of Acts is the first church leader; the Peter of Galatians is called out for wrong-doing—but the Peter of this epistl*
                                     *e is gracious and mature.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Peter the pastor admonishes the readers in a positive manner, steering them in the right direction, calling them to a higher walk with the Lord, encou*
                                     *raging them, reminding them of who they now are.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Like other epistles, the Greek text is choppy, as one expects in a letter. A translator finds himself gleaning the gist of what Peter writes and wordi*
                                     *ng it in his native language, deviating from the word-for-word methodology. Sometimes the letter appears to have grammatical errors or the literal rea*
                                     *ding isn’t so logical (an example is 2:5). The novice reader may have trouble following all of Peter’s OT references. In spite of the fact that what P*
                                     *eter says isn’t written in a straightforward manner, Peter’s message is clear. Case in point is the beginning of the third chapter, when Peter is talk*
                                     *ing about what women wear. Logical?—not exactly. But the point is clear.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Peter’s epistle is tender and commends what some would categorize as feminine virtues (3:8), and he has obviously been transformed from the impetuous *
                                     *fisherman of the Gospels. But his epistles hops about from here to there, randomly redirected to apocalyptic insights and symbolism found in the Old T*
                                     *estament a few verses later (3:19–22). The speed at which Peter makes points, but then hops to another topic, is breathtaking. He never lets the foot *
                                     *off the gas pedal, covering a lot of ground in a short letter. Upon reading the epistle in one sitting, the reader will likely affirm that everything *
                                     *which could have been said was said and that nothing more need be added.*

                                     * to the individual: a special gift or calling for each person.*

                                     *r a furnace used for melting and reforming gold.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|the rescue program, the program which keeps you from calamity|i>…Lit: <i|salvation|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|to offer up|i>…The Gk. verb tense is aorist and not present, which implies that it’s a one-time offering. This is unexpected.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|the Bible|i>…Lit: <i|Scripture|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|put in place|i>…This is the same word used in v.6 and refers to that verse*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|awesomeness|i>…Lit: <i|excellencies|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|those who aren’t Christians|i>…Lit: <i|Gentiles|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|upon close, careful examination|i>…Lit: <i|in a|i> [or perhaps <i|the|i>] <i|day|i> <i|of examination|i>. Note that <i|day of |i>is a bibl*
                                     *ical expression. Note that many translations use the word <i|visitation |i>[from <i|episkeptomai|i>, (ἐπισκέπτομαι/Strong’s 1980)] and not <i|examinat*
                                     *ion |i>[from <i|episkopeō|i>, (ἐπισκοπέω/Strong’s 1983)]<i|. |i>The Gk. word used here is <i|episkopas |i>(ἐπισκοπῆς), which is a noun form of episkop*
                                     *eō —not a form of episkeptomai (although episkopeō and episkeptomai are similar and are related etymologically).*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|come clean and tell the truth|i>…Lit: <i|glorify God|i>. An idiom; ref. note of John 9:24.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|to every man-made position of authority|i>…Lit: <i|in all human creature|i>. An idiom apparently.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|established through the Lord|i>…Lit: <i|through the Lord|i>. It’s not clear whether this phrase means to submit through the Lord or that t*
                                     *he positions of authority were created through the Lord. I’m guessing it’s the latter, and that this somehow extends the idiom.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|band of fellow believers|i>…Lit: <i|the brotherhood|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[l]|s><i|I assume you are but if not you should be submitting|i>…Lit: <i|submitting|i>. For the next several verses and into chapter 3, Peter uses *
                                     *participles in place of imperative verb forms, while the reader understands that the imperative form is meant. By using the participle, Peter takes on*
                                     * a less accusatory posture.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[m]|s><i|abuse and reprimands—even getting slapped around|i>…Lit: <i|beatings |i>[more literally <i|buffeting |i>or<i| cuffs|i>:<i| |i>multiple hit*
                                     *s with a fist or with the palm of one’s hand]. The picture here is of a slave being punched or slapped by his master because of displeasure or disobed*
                                     *ience.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[n]|s><i|from|i>…Or: <i|with|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[o]|s><i|wooden cross-beam|i>…Lit: <i|wood|i>. Ref. note of Acts 5:30.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[p]|s><i|the Great Leader, Overseer, and Protector|i>…Lit: <i|the|i> <i|shepherd |i>[<i|pastor|i>]<i| and overseer |i>[<i|bishop|i>]. A hendiadys; *
                                     *ref. note of Matt. 3:11.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[q]|s><i|minds, emotions, our very beings|i>…Lit: <i|soul|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|logical analogy to|i>…Lit: <i|logical|i>. Or: <i|Word|i> [<i|of God|i>]-<i|related|i>. There’s some ambiguity in what Peter means by the G*
                                     *k. word <i|logikos |i>(λογικός/Strong’s 3050)<i|, |i>the adjective that most other translations render <i|Word. |i>One could put up a substantial argu*
                                     *ment for either. Perhaps it means both.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|like a newborn baby yearns for milk, yearn for the (logical analogy to the) pure milk|i>…Lit: <i|like a newborn baby, you all yearn the lo*
                                     *gical |i>[or<i| Word-related|i>]<i| pure milk |i>This is a hybrid simile and metaphor, one of the most excellent metaphors in the NT. The most tremend*
                                     *ous growth spurt that a human being experiences is when a one is a newborn baby between the ages of three and seven weeks. During this time, a baby is*
                                     * continuously hungry for milk, crying around the clock to be fed. A baby grows substantially during this four week period. Peter is telling Christians*
                                     * to mimic the hunger which a newborn baby has; he is not telling them to imitate babies in any other respect. Just as this baby hungers, is fed, and g*
                                     *rows enormously, is the same way should Christians hunger for the Word. Their growth will be like the baby’s.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|since—surely now—|i>…Lit: <i|if|i>. The rendering of this word [<i|ei, |i>(εἰ/Strong’s 1487)] has caused confusion to the point that sever*
                                     *al ancient manuscripts have altered this word from <i|ei |i>to <i|eiper|i> (εἰπερ/no Strong’s word) forcing it to say <i|since |i>instead of <i|if. |i*
                                     *>There are secondary meanings to the word <i|ei |i>that Peter is likely drawing on here, but nevertheless some ambiguity remains.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|A stone which causes one to veer off into a ditch resulting in wrong-doing and also a rock which offends…Lit: a stumbling stone and a rock*
                                     * of stumbling|i> [or, <i|offense|i>]. Liberties taken. The word <i|stumbling|i> is an idiom; ref. note of Matt. 11:6.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|they slander you as being a bad person|i> (etc.)…What Peter is saying here in v. 12 is that although non-Christians will slander you simpl*
                                     *y because of prejudice, stereotypes, rumors, lies, misunderstandings, etc., when they’re pressed to get down to the brass tacks and look at the specif*
                                     *ic circumstances about someone they know who’s a Christian, they’ll have to (or perhaps will reluctantly) admit that, based on that Christian’s good b*
                                     *ehavior in the specific situations he was observed in, he is a decent person after all.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|submit|i>…The Gk. word here for submit [<i|hupotassō|i>, (ὑποτάσσω/Strong’s 5293)] literally means <i|to arrange oneself under|i>. There a*
                                     *re multiple words in the NT which essentially mean <i|to order, to give a command, |i>etc. The stem from which the word <i|arrange |i>comes means to g*
                                     *iven an order, and it was a military term used when a commander issued orders to deploy units of phalanxes, etc. on a battlefield. A good arrangement *
                                     *of the units, and one which was carried out successfully, was crucial to victory on the battlefield. So <i|hupotassō|i> means to allow oneself to be “*
                                     *arranged” by the person in command, knowing that the one in command has the overall view of what needs to be put and where and is placing you in posit*
                                     *ion according to a master plan—a plan which you might not even be familiar with. This shade of meaning to the word <i|submit |i>differs from a shade o*
                                     *f meaning of an underling being crushed by an oppressive overlord.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *In this regard, the Gk. word <i|hypakouō|i> (ὑπακούω/Strong’s 5219), which corresponds <i|to obey|i>, literally means <i|under the giving-ear-to. |i>T*
                                     *his refers to being under the audible sound—the voice commands—of another person. The nature of the word is that one person is to simply obey the spok*
                                     *en-orders (and this would apply to any order, not just a spoken one) of the one above him. The emphasis is on simple obedience to the order, without q*
                                     *uestions asked and without an expectation that the one obeying will understand the big-picture. And this is where submit and obey diverge. The one who*
                                     * submits understands that his submission is necessary to accomplish the overall goal; that he should understand the overall goal and understand that h*
                                     *e is one of multiple parties, all of whom must do his part and comply with his specific command for the sake of the overall strategy, vision, or long-*
                                     *term plan, which is planned and executed by the one in charge. Therefore, a child or a slave is expected to obey, not submit, but an adult, one who ha*
                                     *s heavy responsibilities, such as a soldier, is told to submit, not obey.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *Throughout history, there have been two methods whereby the common soldier takes orders from a superior: the soldier can submit or he can obey. Genera*
                                     *lly speaking, armies where the soldiers submit are more effective than armies where the soldiers obey. Those who submit are encouraged to think beyond*
                                     * their individual contribution, and because of that, a person who submits may at times improvise according to the need of the moment, not doing what h*
                                     *e was directly ordered to do for the sake of the overarching plan. Soldiers who simply obey will fear potential retribution due to improvisation and n*
                                     *ot exploit opportunities or adapt to changing conditions on the battlefield.*

                                     *to|i> <i|not be persuaded; to not believe; to be disobedient. |i>The more common word for <i|to believe |i>is <i|pisteuō |i>(πιστεύω/Strong’s 4100)<i|*
                                     *; to not believe|i> is <i|apisteuō |i>(ἀπιστέω/Strong’s 569). <i|Apisteuō|i> has connotations of stubbornly refusing to believe out of hard-hearted di*
                                     *sobedience . Acts 28:24 shows by example the difference between these two Gk. words. But the point of the matter is that Peter said that those husband*
                                     *s who are <i|apeitheō |i>will be won over—he did not say that the <i|apisteuō-|i>husbands can or will be won.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|getting your hair done and putting on expensive jewelry or wearing stylish or alluring clothing|i>…<i|stylish or alluring clothing—what yo*
                                     *u put on to make yourself look good|i>…Lit: Gk. <i|kosmos |i>for <i|what you put on to make yourself look good|i>. <i|Kosmos|i> (κόσμος/Strong’s 2889)*
                                     *<i| |i>in this context uses a secondary meaning, which is <i|adornment, dress, decoration. |i>It’s hard to imagine that this secondary definition of <*
                                     *i|kosmos |i>doesn’t acquire overtones from its primary definition (world/worldly), which, assuming that is the case, justifies the rendering <i|stylis*
                                     *h, cosmopolitan, |i>and even <i|alluring. |i>In addition to this use of <i|kosmos|i>…Years ago, Christians who were part of the holiness movement (whi*
                                     *ch includes Pentecostals) interpreted verses to mean that Christian women shouldn’t braid their hair, wear jewelry or wear nice clothing. This is not *
                                     *the point Peter is making. (And as Jeanne Wilkerson used to say in rebuttal to this flaky teaching, “If the barn needs painting, why then: paint it.”)*
                                     * Peter is saying that a woman shouldn’t consider herself to be a beautiful person because of her outward appearance but because of her inward nature.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|quiet (in the sense of being at-rest and at-peace)|i>…The Gk. word used here for <i|quiet |i>appears nowhere else in the NT. Had Peter mea*
                                     *nt a woman who doesn’t talk a lot, he would’ve used a different, more commonly used word which means quiet. But this verse is referring to a woman who*
                                     * isn’t consumed with drama; playing games; false suspicions of the motives of others; easily angered; prone to jealousy; etc.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s>a <i|person whose wide range of human expression is put to use|i>…Lit: <i|vessel|i>. In the NT, the word <i|vessel |i>when referring to a per*
                                     *son and not to an actual container is a figure of speech, a metonymy and an idiom. Ref. Acts 9:15; Rom. 9:21; 1 Cor. 4:7; 1 Thess. 4:4; 2 Tim. 2:20. A*
                                     * vessel is a container that holds something which is worth storing; the vessel’s ability to hold and store that thing is what gives the vessel value. *
                                     *Our physical bodies are containers which hold our spirits and the Holy Spirit, and this is what gives our bodies value, as our bodies are animated by *
                                     *the Spirit inside of us. But vessels are not only bodies but human beings.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|spirits in prison|i>…According to the context, these are all the people on the earth except for Noah and his family, those who didn’t make*
                                     * it into the ark. The assumption is that the “prison” referred to here is hell and that Jesus “preached” to them when he was in hell after his death a*
                                     *nd before his resurrection. Perhaps Jesus was preaching to them about the fact that he was going to be rescued from that place in the same way that, w*
                                     *hen they were alive, Noah preached to them that he was going to be rescued from the flood coming on the earth. This is speculation of course.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|kept on pushing out|i>…Also: <i|kept on postponing. |i>Peter is saying that God was doing His best to get the people on the earth to repen*
                                     *t so He wouldn’t have to send a flood, and kept on postponing the time of the flood to give them yet another opportunity to repent. The oldest living *
                                     *person recorded in the Bible is Methuselah, whose name means “his death shall send.” His name itself is a prophecy of the coming flood, and the prophe*
                                     *cy is that when he dies the flood will come (and upon correlating the dates, the flood occurred the year Methuselah died). In God’s longsuffering, He *
                                     *postponed the date of flood, but also had to lengthen Methuselah’s life because of the prophecy. Methuselah’s long life is a testimony to God’s longsu*
                                     *ffering.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[G]|s><i|demonic agents, demon spirits with authority over other demon spirits, and evil forces|i>…Lit: <i|angels|i> [<i|agents|i>] <i|and authorit*
                                     *ies and powers|i>. Based on a preponderance of NT teachings, this verse is talking about demonic spirits and not about humans. The word <i|angels |i>h*
                                     *ere means <i|messengers |i>(which is <i|agents|i>)<i| |i>instead of fallen angels. These agents are demonic spirits (“messengers of Satan”, 2 Cor. 12:*
                                     *7, NASB) which Satan sends to fulfill a specific mission. The word <i|authorities |i>refers to demons which are given authority over other demons, and*
                                     * the same word is used this way in Eph. 6:12. The word <i|powers |i>refers to demons that are simply a force for evil. Before Jesus ascended into heav*
                                     *en, these wicked spirits were made subordinate to him.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|Pastor (i.e. lead; be a shepherd to)…|i>Lit: shepherd. The word <i|pastor|i> only appears in a couple of places in the NT (in this verse a*
                                     *nd in Eph. 4:11); the word for <i|pastor |i>is the same as <i|shepherd. |i>The word <i|shepherd |i>in the OT refers to a leader (Ez. 37:24 is one exam*
                                     *ple). The implication is that people are difficult to lead like sheep are difficult to lead, so the word <i|pastor |i>is one who faces the difficultie*
                                     *s in leading people, who are by nature difficult to lead.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|with a leadership style|i>…Some of the older manuscripts include a variation of this interpolation explicitly in a single Gk. word [<i|epi*
                                     *skopountes, |i>(ἐπισκοποῦντεσ/Strong’s 1983)]<i| |i>rendered <i|exercising oversight; |i>the word <i|bishop |i>[<i|episkopos|i>, (ἐπίσκοπος/Strong’s 1*
                                     *985)] is obviously the noun form of this verb. As the two principal Alexandrian manuscripts omit the word <i|episkopountes|i>, it is my opinion that t*
                                     *his word is a spurious addition—although it fits nicely in the context. As Christianity evolved into the late first and early second centuries, church*
                                     *es governed by elder bodies were replaced by churches governed by a single person—a bishop. They sought to stamp out any suggestion in the NT that chu*
                                     *rches can or should be governed by elder boards and not by bishops; hence, the addition of the word <i|episkopountes |i>to some of the manuscripts. Th*
                                     *is controversy persists to the present day.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|stand in and stick to the grace!|i>…Lit: <i|stand to it|i> [<i|“it” referring to “the grace”|i>]<i|!|i>…Or: <i|stand in it |i>[<i|“the gra*
                                     *ce”|i>]<i|!|i>. The words <i|the grace |i>are a clarification for the reader, and this interpolation is justified by matching a pronoun with its antec*
                                     *edents by gender. The GT literally reads <i|stand to it|i>, but scholars argue that Peter actually meant <i|stand in it.|i> Some guesswork was used to*
                                     * come up with “stand in and stick to.”*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|The sister-church in metaphorical Babylon (which is Rome)|i>…Lit: <i|the fellow-called |i>[<i|church|i>]<i| in Babylon|i>. The word <i|cal*
                                     *led |i>in <i|fellow-called |i>shares the same root word for <i|church|i>, so <i|fellow-called |i>is <i|fellow-church |i>or <i|sister-church. |i>Some B*
                                     *ible “experts” incorrectly render this verse <i|she who is in Babylon (etc). |i>This is an incorrect understanding of Gk. grammar, as the prepositiona*
                                     *l phrase <i|in Babylon |i>, inserted between the definite article and the noun, must be moved, leaving the definite article to couple tightly with the*
                                     * noun, rendering it <i|the fellow-church |i>instead of the dangling word <i|she |i>etc<i|. |i>Moving along…many scholars agree that Peter is speaking *
                                     *metaphorically when he speaks of Babylon. In the same verse, he refers to Mark as his son, and as this is metaphorical, it lends credence to assuming *
                                     *that Babylon is metaphorical as well.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[E]|s><i|Mark my son|i>…Peter is referring to John-Mark, the same Mark who wrote the Gospel of Mark. Mark was not Peter’s actual son, but was Peter*
                                     *’s close companion and son in the faith. Church tradition tells us that Mark served as Peter’s translator, and that Mark wrote the Gospel of Mark shor*
                                     *tly after Peter was executed. This Gospel is essentially a compilation of all the stories which Mark translated for Peter time and time again througho*
                                     *ut the years.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[F]|s><i|with hearty handshakes and warm hugs of love|i>…Lit: <i|with a kiss of love|i>. Liberties taken. Kisses were normal greetings, and were ex*
                                     *changed irrespective of gender. Judas greeted Jesus with a kiss in the Garden of Gethsemane.*

HEADING1                             *2 Peter*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *2 Peter is a long, brilliantly-written diatribe against evil people and has a different flavor than 1 Peter, and this is one reason why the authentici*
                                     *ty of its authorship is in question. 2 Peter and Jude are similar books and both faced opposition when the canon was first formalized, with several di*
                                     *ssenters who wanted to exclude it.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *The Greek writing style is a bit choppy in parts, but fluid overall. There is a beauty to the prose as it keeps on a subject while moving from point t*
                                     *o point. The transitions are smooth, the verses are sprinkled with metaphors. Overall, the book is as enjoyable to translate as it is to read. It’s a *
                                     *pity that this translation squashes beautiful figures of speech such as found in 2:9 which in the Greek text literally reads, “the Lord knows to rescu*
                                     *e the pious”; the figure of speech means that the Lord has a long history of rescuing the pious and will certainly continue to do so.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *This epistle has many vocabulary words not found elsewhere in the NT. Between this and the fact that it has not received the attention and scholarship*
                                     * that the more popular NT books have received makes it more difficult to resolve the meaning of certain words, an example being 2:17 where the word “m*
                                     *ist” is assumed to be “drizzle.”*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *The assertion that the author makes in 3:16, namely that he considers Paul’s epistles to be on par with Scripture, is a view which didn’t evolve until*
                                     * later; when writing his epistles, Paul didn’t believe he was penning Scripture.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *The author goes out of his way to assure us that this letter is in fact the second epistle (3:1), but giving that assurance is not reassuring: the let*
                                     *ter smells like a fraud—howbeit, a well-written one. The epistle expends too much vitriol railing against the corrupt and too little encouraging belie*
                                     **

HEADING1                             *1 John*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *The epistle of 1 John repeats several phrases from the talks Jesus had at the Last Supper and shortly after, chapters 14–17. Since a large percentage *
                                     *of the Gospel of John consists of the last couple of weeks of Jesus’s life, namely the Last Supper, John was profoundly moved by it and repeated it in*
                                     * 1 John.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *1 John is enigmatic, and appears at times to contradict itself. John presents things in binary form, in diametrically opposed qualities: love vs. hate*
                                     *, light vs. darkness, sin vs. righteousness. Like his Gospel, many of the words he prefers take on their own peculiar meanings, words such as <i|recei*
                                     *ve|i>, <i|witness|i>, <i|dwell|i>, <i|children|i>, <i|fathers|i>. To appreciate this epistle, the reader must approach it from a different perspective*
                                     * than the other epistles, one that’s less cerebral and more spiritual. Naturally, this is the very aspect which many have come to love, as this epistl*
                                     *e has endeared itself into their hearts.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *The Greek text is perhaps the simplest in the NT; this is the preferred first non-textbook reading assignment for the novice Greek student. John inten*
                                     *tionally uses a small set of words and simple grammatical constructs. It comes across the same way in the rendered text.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT

                                     *<i|worker |i>or <i|servant. |i>Ref. note of John 21:5.*

                                     *s in you, and you’ve defeated the Evil One|i>…The repetition of these two statements just a couple verses before is a figure of speech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|a special dispensation bestowed on you|i>…<i|special dispensation|i>…Lit: <i|anointing|i>. Also, ref. note of Luke 4:18. The word <i|anoin*
                                     *ting |i>refers to pouring oil over someone (ex: John 11:2). Throughout the Bible, anointing a person marks that person with extraordinary abilities, a*
                                     *bilities which originate from God and are actuated by means of the Holy Spirit (are a manifestation of the Holy Spirit). These special abilities are s*
                                     *pecific to that one person and are for a particular purpose. In this context of 1 John 2, John’s usage of the word <i|anointing |i>is an extraordinary*
                                     * ability bestowed on each believer, but like any anointing, the extraordinary ability is unique to that person; no other person receives the same anoi*
                                     *nting. The 1 John 2 anointing is the ability to understand how exactly one should conduct himself in a godly manner on a day-to-day basis. The 1 John *
                                     *2 anointing gives a person the ability to discern for himself what the correct thing is for him to do in life. Incidentally, this passage here refutes*
                                     * the notion that any church leader (especially a cult leader) should be deciding what an individual church member should do in their circumstances of *
                                     *life, especially to a fine detail.*

                                     *down |i>[where <i|down |i>means <i|in opposition to|i>; <i|against|i>; <i|a negative or oppressive action|i>]<i|. |i>Compare this to katakrinō, which *
                                     *is condemnation rendered as a verdict by a deliberative body, that is, an impartial, external party.*

HEADING1                             *2 John*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *In 2 John, John continues to speak in a similar way as 1 John, again confirming the supposition that John spoke this way all the time. John’s writing *
                                     *style from his first is not a one-off. But as the epistle is directed to a specific person and as the goal is to thwart false teaching, he breaks from*
                                     * his normal style at times to address a pressing issue.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *But the fact that he had to address false teaching reminds us of how severe the challenge of heresy was in the early church and how good we have it to*
                                     *day in that respect.*

HEADING1                             *3 John*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *In the epistle of 3 John, there is much less resemblance to John’s Gospel and his other two epistles. It’s as though it’s an off-the-cuff letter, one *
                                     *captured at random and preserved for posterity. John, the Apostle of Love, must deal with a rotten apple named Diotrephes, and he does not dodge the c*
                                     *onfrontation. This is an alternative glimpse into the life of love. And we are again reminded how good we have it in modern times in this respect, not*
                                     * having to deal with such trouble-makers.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Verse 2 is one of the pillar scriptures of the prosperity message (a.k.a. the prosperity gospel). Oral Robert in his poverty stumbled across this vers*
                                     *e in this oft-neglected epistle and from that moment taught it until he died.*

HEADING1                             *The Epistle of Jude*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *This epistle written in an unambiguous, fluid, textbook-like style not only demonstrates the writer’s command of Greek but also shows his clarity of m*
                                     *ind and ability to express himself throughout a long warning about “certain people who have infiltrated our community.” But at the bottom of the epist*
                                     *le, there is some meat for Christians to feed on, and most gravitate towards this.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *The author of this epistle writes in a style which is similar to that of 2 Peter, and the subject-matter of both epistles is the same. In fact, some u*
                                     *ncommon words—and even phrases—are common to both 2 Peter and Jude. For example: <i|gloom |i>(v. 6); <i|glories |i>(v. 8 & 2 Pet. 2:10); the specific *
                                     *usage of <i|blasphemy |i>(v. 9); <i|ridiculous creature in nature |i>(v. 10 & 2 Pet. 2:12); plus several more. Is it plausible that the same author wr*
                                     *ote both epistles? The commonality of words and phrases means that, at a minimum, both authors were members of the same tight circle of associates.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Verses 6 and 7 build on a theory about fallen angels which scholars believe comes from the Book of Enoch, which the epistle quotes in vv. 14,15, treat*
                                     *ing the source material as though it’s canonical. And in v. 9 he draws from an account about Moses which comes from a writing other than the OT, but a*
                                     *t the same time assumes the reader is familiar with the story.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *It’s no surprise, then, that when the church fathers gathered to settle the NT canon, these two books were heavily contested.*
SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER

HEADING1                             *Revelation*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *The final piece of John’s portfolio of writings differs from the others. Revelation is a continuation of the prophesies in Genesis, Ezekiel, Daniel, a*
                                     *nd Zechariah, and the novice reader, lacking an overall view of the Bible, jumps into Revelation without first getting up to speed on those other book*
                                     *s. This is explained in the author’s book <i|A Path through Revelation.|i>*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *There are, however, numerous grammatical mistakes in Revelation, and this leaves one to wonder what the cause of these mistakes is. Can we assume that*
                                     * John wrote the book with the help of a scribe?— Scribes normally edit out such errors. In addition, it appears that John jumbles verb tenses througho*
                                     *ut. This might be him seeing a vision in the present of something that will happen in the future as though it happened already but as though he witnes*
                                     *sed it in real-time. Some of these mistakes are probably John not remembering the form of a particular verb. He does have a mastery of what the forms *
                                     *do, but Greek is convoluted. Some of the “mistakes” can be chalked up to John’s writing style, his peculiar figures of speech. The long note in Rev. 8*
                                     *:3 captures an example of such grammatical errors.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *Revelation does follow John’s propensity to utilize a smaller vocabulary than the likes of Paul, but the Greek text is both simple and complex at the *
                                     *same time. When translating it, one finds himself not so much following the literal meaning of the words and the nuances of the forms, but standing ba*
                                     *ck and getting the gist of what’s being said and then putting that down. It’s as though one is listening closely to someone speaking to the broken-Gre*
                                     *ek, then putting the pieces together. At times, this becomes difficult because Revelation is so bizarre, and one doesn’t know if he’s encountering wei*
                                     *rdness or John’s weakness in describing something. For example, Rev. 13:18, “it’s a man’s number”—not quite sure if that’s something ordinary that’s n*
                                     *ot explained well or if it’s yet another mystery of Revelation.*
NON_VERSE_CONTENT                    *John’s final book complements his other writings since it differs in style from his gospel and his epistles. After a close reading of the Greek text, *
                                     *he appears to be a strong-willed person who does things his own way. He’s not as loud as Mark (and Peter by extension), but isn’t one who submits to a*
                                     *ccepted conventions of writing like Luke. To read John’s books is to enter his world and to go to him, for he will not go to you.*
SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|post-haste|i>…Lit: <i|quickly|i>. This doesn’t necessarily mean that he’s coming soon; it means that he’ll travel quickly when he does com*
                                     *e, like a thief in the night. Ref. usage of <i|quickly |i>with regard to travelling in 1 Cor. 4:19.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|statement of Jesus|i>…Lit: <i|testimony of Jesus. |i>This phrase is repeated throughout Revelation.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|Father-figure-God|i>…Lit: <i|God and Father|i>. This is a hendiadys; ref. note of Matt. 3:11.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|so be it|i>…<i|Let it be so…|i>Lit: <i|amen. |i>Ref. note of Rev. 19:4.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|breaking through|i>…Lit: <i|coming with|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|comrade|i>…Lit: <i|brother|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|on the island|i>…Lit: <i|in the island|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|on a Sunday|i>…Lit: <i|in the Lord-day|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|ideal embodiment of a human being|i>…Lit: <i|a son of man|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|a large volume of rushing water|i>…Lit: <i|many waters|i>. Like the sound a waterfall makes.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|personal attendants|i>…Lit: <i|priests|i>. In this context, a priest is one who carries out the ritualistic duties demanded by the holy pr*
                                     *esence of the Almighty, similar to how priests in the OT had duties in the temple.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|tribes of the earth|i>…Using the word <i|tribes|i> as a metonymy for the present-day ethnic groups and nations; the assumption being that *
                                     *all ethnic groups and nations were spawned by a single, specific tribe at their inception, in the same as is recorded in the OT, Gen. 10 in particular*
                                     *.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|in the Spirit|i>…A strong presence of the Holy Spirit (1 Cor. 12:3) comes upon a person, often accompanied by some sort of prophetic utter*
                                     *ance.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|mysterious world of death|i>…Lit: <i|the death and the Hades|i>. A reference to death as alluded to in the OT and to death as portrayed by*
                                     * Greek mythology. As Christians, John and those who read the revelation will take this as a figure of speech, as they are taught in heaven vs. hell my*
                                     *thology (mythology meaning the understanding of the components in the unseen world, not a fictitious story).*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|Citadel|i>…Lit: <i|throne|i> *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|to contrive and implement a plan that would attract and thereby lure the Israelites (and—boy—weren’t they your typical Israelites?) into s*
                                     *in|i>…Lit: <i|cast a stumbling block before the sons of Israel|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|cause her to be bedfast|i>…Lit: <i|cast her onto a bed|i>. An expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|her devotees|i>…Lit: <i|her children|i>. It’s inferred from the use of the word <i|children|i> in 1 John, 2 John, and 3 John that these ar*
                                     *e not her actual children.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|I’ll cause them to die an awful, agonizing death|i>…Lit<i|: I’ll kill using death|i>. A figure of speech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|a voting ballot, one that casts a vote in his favor, and one that has a new name written on the ballot|i>…Lit: <i|a white pebble|i>…<i|and*
                                     * upon the pebble a new name|i>. Liberties taken. The pebble referred to by John is a pebble used for voting; white is a vote for a candidate and black*
                                     * is a vote against a candidate.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|I won’t burden you with anything more|i>…Lit: <i|I won’t toss another burden upon you|i>. An expression, likely a metaphor which compares *
                                     *a person to a beast of burden, a pack animal which is already loaded with materials to carry and its master refuses to weigh it down with any more mat*
                                     *erials.*

                                     *5.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|system of thought|i>…Lit: <i|word|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|what I stand for|i>…Lit: <i|my name|i>*
