FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|his Angels|i>…Angels are affiliated with the holiness of God, and God uses them as attendants in the same way that priests used to attend *
                                     *to the temple in Jerusalem. They are bystanders, in other words, so they hear anything which is presented before God’s throne.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|Philadelphia|i>…The Quakers named the city of Philadelphia in Pennsylvania after the city this church was in, as they aspired to emulate t*
                                     *his church, since the church received all praise and no censure.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|I’ll write my God’s name upon him|i>…The significance of writing a name on a person is that it puts a stamp of approval on a person, and a*
                                     *dditionally advertises that approval to everyone.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|buy gold from me|i>…An elaborate metaphor of buying purified gold, clothing, and eye ointment from Jesus. The buying aspect is to allow Go*
                                     *d to do His work in one’s life, rather than for a person to attempt it on his own. The purified gold represents trials which are allowed in one’s life*
                                     *, the purpose of which is, in the pressure exerted by them, to remove life’s impurities. White clothing represents righteousness that’s received by Go*
                                     *d and not a righteousness generated out of one’s own efforts. The eye ointment allows one to see plainly what the issues are in one’s life, seeing wha*
                                     *t should already be obvious.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|sealed shut|i>…The seals may have consisted of melted wax which was affixed to the scroll after it had been tightly rolled up. Before the *
                                     *wax cooled and hardened, the seal was stamped to give it an inscription. After the wax cooled, the scroll could not be unfurled, and the scroll thereb*
                                     *y read, unless the wax was broken. Therefore, the seals served two purposes. First, they ensured that the scroll had never been read before. Second, t*
                                     *he inscription was proof of the scroll was genuinely written by whomever claimed to have written it. Ref. note of 2 Cor. 1:22.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|break the seals and open the scroll|i>…Lit: <i|open the scroll and break the seals|i>. The assumption is that the literal wording of openi*
                                     *ng the scroll and breaking the seal is backwards, being an expression of a sort, and that the reader at the time would take this for granted. This is *
                                     *analogous to us telling a child, “Put on your shoes and socks,” which we don’t mean for the child to do it in that order, but to put on the socks firs*
                                     *t before putting on the shoes.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|millions and millions and billions and billions|i>…Lit: <i|ten-thousand ten-thousands and thousands of thousands|i>. This is more of an ex*
                                     *pression than a precise numbering.*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|broke|i>…Lit: <i|opened|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|incense dispenser|i>…Lit: <i|censer|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|upon|i>…Or: <i|at|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|the set-apart-people|i>…Or: <i|saints|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|grass which was still growing|i>…Lit: <i|green grass|i>. <i|Green|i> is rendered <i|freshly-cut |i>in Luke 23:31.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|Bitter-Flavoring|i>…Lit: <i|Wormwood|i>. This is an actual plant.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|vulture|i>…Or: <i|eagle|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|ushered over and made to stand|i>…Here in this passage are some of the brass tacks that Ray Summers in his book <i|Worthy Is the Lamb|i> c*
                                     *laimed were grammatical mistakes. The verb <i|stand |i>here is in the passive voice but most translations, such as the NASB, translate it as active. T*
                                     *he word <i|give |i>in v. 3 translated <i|offer up|i> is future tense but should be subjunctive. The words <i|the prayers |i>is in the dative case, whi*
                                     *ch is unexpected. In v. 5 the verb <i|to take |i>is in the perfect tense, but is used like it’s aorist. Some observations on the claim that these are *
                                     *grammatical errors. First, looking at John’s contributions to the NT as a whole and not just at Revelation individually, Revelation is the only book w*
                                     *ith these kinds of errors. In the grammatical incidences enumerated from this passage, it’s hard to imagine that these would not have been mistakes ca*
                                     *used by ignorance of the language. Now, grammatical mistakes are made when someone’s careless, perhaps writing while he’s tired or writing in too much*
                                     * of a hurry. And that may be the case. But inspecting a couple of the verb forms which are listed here, the passive form of <i|to stand |i>and the per*
                                     *fect form of <i|to take |i>are less common than the expected forms. Someone who’s sloppy, careless, or rushed would use the more common forms instead *
                                     *of the less common. So what’s the conclusion? Perhaps John couldn’t remember some of the forms of words and knew that the reader would be able to figu*
                                     *re it out. Or he understood what he was writing and deliberately chose to write it and these are not mistakes. This leaves a translator with the task *
                                     *of figuring out what he meant on a case-by-case basis.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|very|i> <i|high up in the sky|i>…Lit: <i|mid-heaven|i>. In NT times, the sky and heaven as we know it were conflated into one, and there w*
                                     *ere multiple layers (many say there were seven). Progressing through these layers, one goes from the atmosphere surrounding us; to very high up in the*
                                     * sky; to where the sun and the stars are; then from there into the various layers of heaven, which presumably include paradise and the throne of God. *
                                     *According to such a gradation scheme, mid-heaven would be half-way through, and therefore very high up in the sky, perhaps even in their minds near wh*
                                     *ere the stars are. Seeing that v. 13 mentions a vulture (or perhaps an eagle), vultures (and eagles for that matter) have been known to fly as high as*
                                     * 37,000 feet/11,275 meters). *
SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|exclude the outer courtyard from the measurement, since it’s been given to the Gentiles|i>…The reason for measuring the temple is to confi*
                                     *rm that it complies with God’s exacting standards of perfection, a prerequisite for His approval, and assuming it does, God will condescend to dwell i*
                                     *n it. When God dwells in it, it will receive His protection. Now, the outer courtyard is not measured since God will not dwell in it, just as in the s*
                                     *econd temple at the time of Jesus Gentiles were allowed in that outer courtyard. Furthermore, the outer courtyard extends into the Holy City, which do*
                                     *es not receive God’s protection. *
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|And if at any given moment someone wants to harm them, fire comes out of their mouth and devours their enemies. And if at any given moment*
                                     * someone would want to harm them, he must be killed in this manner|i>…Two consecutive conditional sentences, where the conditional clauses are almost *
                                     *identical. The conditional clauses differ in the verb tense for the verb <i|to want. |i>The repetition of these clauses and sentences is a figure of s*
                                     *peech used throughout the Bible. The shift in the verb tense of <i|to want |i>is a figure of speech called a <i|polyptoton|i>. The subtlety of this po*
                                     **
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|I watched events unfold|i>…This interpolation was inserted for the benefit of the reader, as, generally speaking, the verbs in subsequent *
                                     *passage use the past tense, whereas in the previous they were using the future.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|spirit of life|i>…In this context, the word <i|spirit |i>does not refer to an angelic spirit, but refers to a supernatural, physical refre*
                                     *shing. See usage of <i|spirit |i>in other verses such as 1 Pet. 3:4.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|way, way up in the sky|i>…Lit: <i|mid-heaven|i>. Ref. note of 8:13*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|come clean with Him|i>…Lit: <i|give Him glory|i>. An expression; ref. note of John 9:24.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|under the scrutiny of|i>…Lit: <i|before|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|the set-apart-people|i>…Or: <i|the saints|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|who believe in and serve the Lord|i>…Lit: <i|in the Lord|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|someone who looked like a perfectly-proportioned man—the ideal man|i>…Lit: <i|the same as a son of man|i>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|Get out in the field and get to it with the sickle…took his sickle|i>…Lit: <i|Send|i> <i|your sickle |i>[into the field to work]…<i|cast h*
                                     *is sickle|i>. A figure of speech, as the sickle itself is not sent but the person swinging it is; the sickle is just a tool.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|shoulder-high|i>…Lit: <i|up the horse’s bridle|i>. Liberties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[k]|s><i|200 miles/300 km|i>…Lit: <i|1600 stadia|i>. Ref. note of Luke 24:13.*
SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|undiluted mixture|i>…In ancient times, wine was often times diluted with water. The metaphor has God’s wrath at maximum potency.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|The fact is, as they parade in, their deeds are showcased|i>…Lit: <i|For their works follow after them|i>. A metaphor to the triumphal ent*
                                     *ry of a general into a city, with the spoils of war carried behind him. Same metaphor used in 1 Tim. 5:24.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|since the timing is perfect to reap the earth’s harvest|i>…Lit: <i|the harvest of the earth has dried out|i>. Some liberties taken. The sp*
                                     *ring rain (the “latter rain”: ref. James 5:7, Joel 2:23, Jer. 5:24) arrives at the end of the growing season, and prepares the grain for harvest. Afte*
                                     *r receiving the rain, the crop must dry out, otherwise it’ll get moldy. The moment it dries is the exact moment to harvest it.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|the winepress was tread outside the city|i>…In those times, grape juice was extracted from grapes by putting the grapes in a vat and havin*
                                     *g the workers step on them, crushing them, causing the juice to seep out of the vat and into a pot or something. In the NT, something done <i|outside *
                                     *the city |i>was something which was dirty, messy, or disgusting and consequently should be prevented from contaminating the city.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|majestic splendor|i>…Lit: <i|glory|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|harassing spirits|i>…Lit: <i|demons|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|filthy, disgusting|i>…Lit: <i|unclean|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|up the ante|i>…Lit: <i|double the doubles|i>. An expression*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|I’ve been awarded the status of|i>…Lit: <i|I’ve been seated|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|inventory|i>…Lit: <i|cargo and freight|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|slaves who do manual labor, slaves in generals|i>…Lit: <i|bodies and lives of people|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|the sumptuous and splendid|i>…Lit, in Gk: the <i|lipara|i> [λιπαρὰ, from λιπαρός (λιπαρός/Strong’s 3045)]and the <i|lampra |i>[λαμπρὰ, fro*
                                     *m λαμπρός (λαμπρός/Strong’s 2986)]. An alliteration, rhyme, assonance, or pun of a sort, evidence that this is an expression.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[i]|s><i|disintegrated right in front of you|i>…Lit: <i|perished from you|i>. Some liberties taken.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[j]|s><i|works the docks|i>…Lit: <i|at a sailing place|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|Using the same cup she did her mixing in, mix a cocktail for her which is twice as concentrated|i>…The ancients mixed wine with spices and*
                                     * other flavorings similar to the way we mix cocktails. When hosting a dinner, they would prepare a special wine-based mix for the guests.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|poured dirt on their heads|i>…Lit: <i|threw dust on their heads|i>. Attempt to emulate the ancient form of grief, mourning, or repentance,*
                                     * as it says in Job 42:6, “Wherefore I abhor myself and repent in dust and ashes.”*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|any sound of harp players and their accompanying band of musicians and flute players and trumpet players|i>…In ancient Rome, harps and flu*
                                     *tes were the principal instruments played in amphitheaters in front of large crowds. To put this in perspective, harps and flutes were to them what el*
                                     *ectric guitars and keyboards are to rock bands. Famous performers—the pop stars of their day—went from city to city and played in front of large crowd*
                                     *s, and all were enchanted by their music. Trumpets were third behind harps and flutes in popularity.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|protecting us|i>…Lit: <i|salvation|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|absolutely correct in their truth|i>…Lit: <i|true and correct|i>. A sort of hendiadys; ref. note of Matt. 3:11.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|ornamental headbands|i>…Lit: <i|diadems|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|the end at last|i>…Lit: <i|amen|i>. This well-known Hebrew word which, depending on the context, has one or more of the following meanings*
                                     *: <i|the end at last|i>;<i| that is so true|i>; <i|that is the last of it|i>; <i|let it be so|i>; <i|so be it|i>; <i|the final word has been spoken|i>*
                                     *; <i|I/we affirm what you just said/did; the end|i>; <i|the end at last|i>.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|up in the upper atmosphere blocking the sun|i>…Lit: <i|in the sun|i>. The ancients’ perception of the sun is that it was a lot closer to t*
                                     *he Earth than it actually is. Consequently, a liberty taken to adapt the wording in a way that fits the modern perspective of astronomy.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|any bird that’s capable of flying at a high altitude|i>…Lit: <i|all birds the ones that fly in mid-heaven|i> In regard to <i|mid-heaven|i>*
                                     *, ref. note of 8:13. Birds which are “capable of flying at a high altitude” refers to eagles and vultures and perhaps a few other carrion-eating types*
                                     * of birds. In any case, what’s referred to is birds which pick at dead carcasses and tear their flesh off.*

FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|the farthest reach of the planet|i>…Lit: <i|the four corners of the Earth|i>. This is an expression. Though the ancient Greeks knew that t*
                                     *he world was round, expressions continued to be circulated describing it as though it were flat and had four corners.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|all the way to Timbuktu|i>…Lit: <i|the Gog and Magog|i>. Gog and Magog are used as a metonymy for any nation of peoples who settled at an *
                                     *extreme distance from the center of civilization and over the centuries their whereabouts and any contact with them or knowledge of them had been lost*
                                     *.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|the graveyard|i>…Lit: <i|the sea|i>. Some liberties taken. The sea is used symbolically in the Bible to represent the masses of humanity.*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|God’s setting up camp with mankind|i>…Lit: <i|the tabernacle of God with the men|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|ever true in their faithfulness|i>…Lit: <i|faithful and true|i>. A hendiadys.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|It has come into being|i>…Almost the same word and almost the same inflected form as used in 16:17; ref. note for that verse.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|the A-to-Z|i>…Lit: <i|the Alpha and the Omega|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|1500 miles/2400 km|i>…Lit: <i|12,000 stadia|i>. Ref. note of Luke 24:13 for conversion of units.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|being who lies about doing detestable things|i>…Lit: <i|that doing detestable and a liar|i>. A hendiadys.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|god-figure|i>…The word <i|God |i>in the GT of the NT is usually preceded with a definite article; this occurrence is not. This is not to s*
                                     *ay that God is simply a god-figure and not God. A god-figure is one who supplies what is necessary for survival. Pagans, in fact, view their idols as *
                                     *god-figures and credit them with providing what is needed for their survival. In the OT, the Jehovah-names for God do, for the most part, describe God*
                                     * as the ultimate god-figure, the one who promises to supply our survival needs. Hence, Jehovah Jireh (the Lord our Provider), Jehova Rapha (the Lord o*
                                     *ur Healer), Jehovah Nissi (the Lord our Banner), Jehovah Rohi (the Lord our Shepherd), etc.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|measure|i>…Measuring the city verifies that it is perfect, in the same way that exact dimensions of the tabernacle are specified in the To*
                                     *rah. The act of measuring confirms that it perfectly complies with God’s exacting standards; in this context, that it is made by God and not by man. A*
                                     *lso, ref. note of Rev. 11:2.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[C]|s><i|215 ft/ 66 meters high|i>…Lit: <i|144 cubits|i>. A cubit is approximately 18 inches/450 millimeters.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[D]|s><i|daytime all the time|i>…Gates in ancient cities were normally kept open during the day but shut at night, as to protect against bands of m*
                                     *arauders who roamed the night and other such threats. With there being no night, there is no need to ever shut the gates.*

SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES            
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[a]|s><i|ever true in their faithfulness|i>…Lit: <i|faithful and true|i>. A hendiadys. Same phrase used in Rev. 21:5.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[b]|s><i|deny access to|i>…Lit: <i|seal|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[c]|s><i|right|i>…Lit: <i|authority|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[d]|s><i|outside the city|i>…Lit: <i|outside|i>. Ref. note of 14:20*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[e]|s><i|quite fond of lying and lies all the time|i>…Lit: <i|all loving|i> [<i|phileō, |i>(φιλέω/Strong’s 5368)] <i|and practicing a lie|i>. The a*
                                     *wkward wording is a figure of speech.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[f]|s><i|the direct-descendant|i>…Lit: <i|the stock|i> [<i|root|i>] <i|and the lineage|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[g]|s><i|confirm|i>…Lit: <i|testify|i>*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[h]|s><i|let it be so|i>…Lit: <i|amen|i>. Ref. note of 19:4.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                   
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[A]|s><i|God of the prophetic utterances of the prophets|i>…Lit: <i|God of the spirits of the prophets|i>…The phrase <i|spirits of the prophets |i>*
                                     *is an idiom. It also appears in 1 Cor. 14:32. These two passages qualify the idiom’s meaning.*
FOOTNOTES_NORMAL                     *<s|[B]|s><i|I have cash on hand to pay each person according to the work he’s done|i> <i|for the day…|i>Lit: <i|the wages of mine with me to give out *
                                     *to each as his work|i>. The metaphor, used in the Gospels, is a man who hires day-workers and is expected to pay them in the evening of each workday.*
